151223577.review:
A nice Metroidvania, and one of the classic indie titles of the last decade. I had only seen a bit of fanart of this game, so I had zero expectations about this one. And I believe that was a good way to approach a game like this.
I was pleasantly surprised by the fully-voiced dialogue (Which for an indie game is always something to praise) and wowed by the beautiful hand-drawn visuals (every single pixel of Dust's animations is amazing).
I'm certainly a big fan of the "Dust flying around as long as there are flying enemies" kinda thing. Moreso if there's a chest at the end of that "flying" session.
I'm not much one to comment on the story, but I can at least say it's right up my alley, so no complaints there. Some details felt familiar, some others felt fresh. 

The only couple of minor complaints I have: 
1/- while the upgrades for Fidget's magic attacks are nice, I would have preferred another move or skill for melee combat, since unlike most games in the genre this one's more action-focused. Since you can level up how you wish (with some "backup auto-balancing" on the side), I ended up one-shotting everything halfway through the game, but still for variety's sake it would have been nice; 
2/- yeah, since It has a lot of combat, you don't exactly move so fast, and the fast travel being one-sided felt kinda weird at times. However, that also means that the areas aren't that big anyway, so moving fast would mean skipping combat and just speedrunning the game. 

Overall, I can see why this has been well-received. It was an enjoyable 15 hours of my life (I have some extra hours of standby time). Not too short, not very long, just right.

150300074.review:
A hidden gem that for some reason haven't achieved the popularity I truly think it should have achieved.

In this somewhat short 2D platformer/slasher wtih a Metroidvania-style exploration system you are playing as Dust, antropomorphic animal, who lost his memories but found a sentient sword. Along his journey he recovers his memories and helps different creatures of this world. The game feels really good at controls. It's really a pleasure to slash all those enemies that are coming at you. 

A small advise: if you stumble upon some region that you cannot clear (meaning collect all the treasure chests) - don't bother too much. Most likely you'll unlock a new power later, that will allow you to collect that treasure. 

Powers are a separate topic. Thanks to the well paced story progression you unlock skills that bring new features to the game, which makes the game completion rather interesting.

Overall - if you like platformers and slashers or like metroidvania exploration style in a fairy antropomorphic world and you are not afraid of slightly weird graphics - I'd recommend you to try this game. It feels good. It plays good. It provides some fun and sad moments. What else a proper video game requires?

I love this game.

If you enjoy Metroidvania titles such as Hollow Knight and Ori and the Blind Forest, or even if you've just started with the Metroidvania scene in general, this is an absolute classic and still holds up very well, even by today's standards.

This game is filled with fantastic hack-and-slash combat, a well-developed story, plenty of secrets to discover, and a unique, hand-drawn art style that stands the test of time.
Albeit a bit more story-focused than most Metroidvanias, there's still plenty of freedom to go off of.

148679926.review:
TL;DR: 8/10, story focused, fully voiced dialogue, metroidvania with with fun combat, will leave you crying and wanting more

INTRO:
If you're trying to decide if you want to buy this game, this is my recommendation: if you like games focused on good story that also come with fun and enjoyable gameplay, this is a hidden gem waiting for you. If you seek challenging gameplay and just skip dialogue even if the story is the main point of the game, you will hate this game. This review has no spoilers, but I will be revealing some information that is not important.

STORY:
This is the main reason why you want to buy the game. The main character is Dust, an amnesiac who is almost instantly joined by a companion Fidget and an ancient wise talking sword, forming the core trio that travels together. The dynamic between the characters is honestly great, and the banter between stoic Dust and emotional big-mouthed Fidget is just comedy gold that made me laugh out loud several times during my playthrough.
The story is split into several chapters, with the first chapters being mostly aimless wandering after quest markers and helping people, which later transitions into seeking the truth about Dust, and who he really is. Each chapter ends with a strong emotional beat: a twist, a revelation or just a tough pill to swallow. The emotional beats are great and have a very strong emotional payoff at the end of the adventure. The ending will leave you in an emotional turmoil, absolutely heartbroken, and with a faint hope for a sequel that is probably never going to happen. T_T
The theme of finding one's own identity will make not only Dust, but also you as the player, reflect on your actions from the first chapters, and the story conveys a positive message about finding one's place in the world. While everyone can connect with Dust's struggles, this message will resonate mostly with teens/young adults, who are currently going through a similar phase of self-discovery.
Oh, and one more thing: EVERY SINGLE DIALOG LINE IS VOICE ACTED!

GAMEPLAY:
This game borrows gameplay mechanics from several different genres. It is mostly a metroidvania: you travel through distinct areas, unlock new movement abilities, then backtrack to previous areas to collect treasure from previously unreachable places. It even has a built-in tracker that shows you the rough location of undiscovered treasures, alleviating the need for an online wiki to be open on your second monitor.
It also has RPG mechanics, which see you collect XP, gold and materials to craft gear. With these mechanics you can boost your stats and generally make Dust stronger over time. There are also a few sidequests (but not too many) that don't really detract from the main story; they actually enhance it as they mostly take place during the early chapters while you are aimlessly wandering around and helping people.
And finally, the combat. Most of the time, it's just a power trip that sees you cutting up mobs of enemies and collecting plenty of loot. The game has a combo-based combat, but it has only 3 ground combos and 1 aerial combo that are unlocked from the start. I wish there were more combos that unlocked as you progressed through the game. Thankfully, it's not really a problem. By the end of the game, while you will feel proficient in the combos, they have not started feeling stale yet. It also has a parrying and dodging mechanics that you use mostly when fighting big monsters and bosess. And there is also a unique mechanic with Fidget casting a spell and Dust performing a SPIN TO WI- I mean Dust Storm. When these two are combined together, you deal TONS OF DAMAGE.

GRAPHICS:
About 95% of the game's visuals are hand-drawn sprites and hand-painted environments, which allows the game to never get graphically outdated. While the enemies and villagers you encounter are mostly animated using Flash-style animation with skeletons, Dust himself has fully drawn traditional animations and it's very hard not to stare at him while he slashes stuff. The environments are well-painted, but what steals the show for me are the background paintings that are just gorgeous to look at. The few 3D objects you will see are noticeable, but visually they try to comply with the rest of the game's style and don't detract from the overall 2D aesthetic.

SOUND & MUSIC:
For me, this is the weaker part of the game. While the combat sound effects are mostly fine and the game plays a sound cue when you need to perform a dodge, there is a lack of sound cues for enemies where the only way to defeat them is to parry them. For non-combat sounds, sounds for important world objects are very satisfying, and while standing on a teleporter, the background music volume goes down as a sign of safety and reprieve from the monster-infested world. Unfortunately, in most areas, there are very few environmental sounds, with only the music playing in the background.
And when it comes to the music, the first forest areas have great, uplifting music that pulls you into the fairytale fantasy world of Dust, but the music in other areas just... didn't do that. It felt like generic music matching the area it played in, but it didn't feel like it had the same identity as the music in the forest areas. It could be just me, but... I feel like music should tie the whole game together, and music in Dust just didn't seem to do that.

OTHER:
My playthrough of the game clocked in at 13 hours while playing on "Tough" difficulty, the 3rd of the 4 difficulty tiers, and I got almost 100% completion, which makes this quite a short game. But I can confidently say that I enjoyed every single minute of it.
Even on the "Tough" difficulty, I didn't feel like it was difficult to defeat enemies. I just chopped enemies up like nothing and bosses usually fell down under half a minute. The hardest aspect of this difficulty setting was the fact that the only way to heal was to use consumables, which was forcing me to actually use consumables (which I usually don't do), but later on enemies were dropping so many healing items it didn't really matter that much, it was just annoying. I would definitely recommend playing through the game on "Normal" difficulty instead.

PERSONAL NOTES:
I played this game for the first time shortly after it came out, when I was a teenager with no money, sooo... let's say I got a free copy. It was the first game ever to affect me emotionally, and even make me cry during a few cutscenes. When I finished the game, I was left completely broken, unable to process the fact that my adventures with Dust have come to an end, and I just stared at the main menu for an hour, with its sad, yet hopeful simple piano tunes hitting me even harder in the feels.
This game gave me a reason to pick up drawing. It gave me a dream to one day construct a game with traditional animations and gorgeous environments, an impactful story what will leave a lasting impact on others. That dream will sadly never come true as I don't have much free time outside of my job, but right now, I am a software developer, and I am still drawing in my free time. And this game is probably the reason why I love artwork with furry characters. I am not going to deny it, this game affected me as a teenager for the rest of my life.

FINAL THOUGHTS:
This was my second playthrough after 10 years, and I can say that this game still holds up exceptionally well. 
While I would objectively score this game as a 8/10, I 100% recommend it. It's gorgeous to look at, the controls are responsive, not janky, combat is a fun power trip and the story (WITH FULLY VOICED DIALOGUE!) has once again emotionally destroyed me. If you give this game a chance, you will begin to love furries and you will regret playing it. Now I need to get my blanket, some ice cream and try to recover from the emotional damage this game has inflicted onto me. I will definitely play it again after another 10 years have passed.

148527464.review:
First things first: There are a few spots where you can tell the limitations of one guy doing most of the work, like the limited animation on the NPCs, and the final level can be a little too chaotic in that it's hard to even see your character in spots. Also, you'll likely spend at least an hour grinding for experience and materials to be able to complete it.

That said, there are so many good things about this game that it's hard to list them all. The story is really solid and goes in a direction I didn't see coming, the gameplay is tight and responsive, the music fits the mood perfectly, and the overall game has a perfect length. It doesn't overstay its welcome or leave the player wanting more (beyond a sequel of course). It is very impressive that one person did most of the work with this title, and I'm happy it got the acclaim and sales it richly deserves.

148111548.review:
(How has it taken me THIS LONG to review this game? Whatever, better late than never)

Before there was Guacamelee, Ori and the Blind Forest and Hollow Knight, there was Dust: An Elysian Tail. Am I suggesting that Dust paved the way for these other amazing Metroidvanias? No. Am I saying that it was among the first in the time-honoured genre of 'Hand-drawn Indie Metroidvania?'? Yes, and it deserves a recognised place amongst its more famous successors. The fact that it was among the first Steam games I ever bought, and my first Indie might colour that opinion though.

That being said, the game does certainly show evidence of the fact that it was the designer's very first game. On the other hand, it's this good considering that it is the designers very first game.

This game sits somewhere between a Metroidvania and a linear Action RPG. You progress through six main areas along a mostly straightforwards path to complete the main story, using a simple but expressive (and very stylish) combat system augmented with simple loot and levelling mechanics, unlocking several new abilities that, if you so choose, you can go back to earlier areas or optional side-areas to get some extra loot or find some secrets. You can also complete sidequests for the various one-note, but very charming NPC's you meet across the game. And fortunately, whilst one note, there are at least a lot of different notes - for example, whilst there's four child characters who's personality really doesn't go past that, they're very much still different children. So the characters remain extremely memorable and charming.

As for main protagonists, you play as the titular Dust, accompanied by Fidget the Nimbat and the Blade of Arah, both of whom you meet very early. Their personalities all bounce pretty well off each other once the dynamic is established - Dust is a deeply compassionate Amnesiac who helps literally everyone, and handles both sincere seriousness and sarcastic wit equally well. Fidget is the 'comic relief' and morality pet of the group, a Naive and earnest little 'Nimbat' who tagged along because she was supposed to guard Arah. She's very much your 'best friend', intensely supportive and optimistic, even if she does question you somehow putting a sheep in your inventory. Arah is the wise old mentor - which, yes, does mean he's the Tutorial NPC. He does however, occasionally weigh in with typically nonjudgemental commentary on a situation - and whilst I won't spoil, on replay much of his behaviour makes a lot more sense.

Combat, as mentioned, is simple but manages to be highly expressive. The game is not claiming to be Devil May Cry, but with attacks that can cover the screen, send opponents flying, or yourself hurtling into the heavens only to bring your foes crashing down, once mastered fights in the game are visual spectacles. And to its credit, the designer did clearly know that the Aerial Dust Storm could be cheesed to fling yourself to great heights - some puzzles or areas seem almost designed to allow you to manipulate this for speedruns.

Artistically, the game is gorgeous, with one main fault. The art is, to my knowledge, entirely hand-drawn and has a distinct style, not entirely taking from any one culture or region enough to conclusively pin anything down. The character designs are very simple, but still charming and distinct, and regardless of whether or not you're a Furry, they remain visually appealing. The backgrounds, too, are also breathtaking, and each area remains distinct from one another, if being a little generic in most cases. The only downside is that, whilst Dust is fully animated, most of the cast uses fairly limited puppet animation, and there's occasionally some artstyle differences (Arah and the Generic Soldier characters, for example, are 3D models whilst everyone else is hand-drawn?)

Lastly, the music is also exceptional. Standouts being Abadis Forest, Everdawn Basin and 'I am Dust'. Hyperduck Soundworks blew it out of the park with this soundtrack. Unfortunately, I lack the expertise to lavish praise on this, so I can't say more than that.

All in all, Dust: An Elysian Tail isn't a perfect game, but it is a damn good one. It's definitely the sort of game that's crying out for a sequel to buff out the few flaws or undercooked ideas and expand on what was already great. And, despite the 10-year gap, Hints and rumours abound, so perhaps we will get one. In the meantime, Dust as it stands is a wonderful game and is highly reccomended.

147953090.review:
Overall, very disappointing for competitive players, while designed for playing competitively:
- Fast combat pace combined with very slow dialog and story progress
- Random and unpredictable enemy movement, combined with 0-second turning delay for enemies
- Casually having 25 enemies on the same screen, causing a chaotic combat mess where you lose track on where your character is, get stressed out by the strict combo counter, and lose track of key combinations completely
- Normal attacks were completely unusable because it was designed for the first level with at most 6 enemies on the same screen, and this game completely broke it
- All enemy attack sequence were designed for 1v1 with player, which it works with at most 6 enemies on the same screen, and this game completely broke it
- Boring, lengthy and intrusive story telling (pausing me in a middle of fight to tell something, seriously?!)
- *Auto-save Fail*. Yes, you may get sent back a few save-points ago, which finally broke me, this was one of the worst thing I have experienced, and it happened 2 twice in a row, and this is completely unacceptable
- **Recommendation to developer: remove the combo system from the game, or design your combat game-play with competence**

EN REVIEW :
Apart from the soundtrack, there isn't much to salvage. It's probably the most boring Metroidvania I've ever played; the story is absolute garbage, and the gameplay boils down to mashing the action button (I won't even mention the absurdity of having a button for left dash and another for right dash). Graphically, I'm not a fan, and I can't quite put my finger on it, but I feel that the cartoonish aspect is rather poorly executed, and the fact that the camera is zoomed in so close to your character not only triggers my motion sickness but also makes the graphical limitations even more apparent. Anything related to dialogue is also a lost cause; I've already mentioned the story, but the side quests aren't any better, and everything feels incredibly "forced." Furthermore, the game constantly interrupts you to explain obvious mechanics or just to say nothing at all: LET ME DISCOVER THE DAMN GAME ON MY OWN.

In short, it's terrible. I'm completely baffled by the 95% positive reviews; maybe the game has just aged very, very poorly. I clearly haven't finished the game (dropped it at chapter 2 in the caves), but I doubt it gets any better from there.

147026612.review:
"Dust: An Elysian Tale" es un juego de acción y aventuras que se destaca por su hermosa estética, emocionante jugabilidad y una historia conmovedora. Desarrollado por Dean Dodrill, este juego independiente ha ganado elogios por su impresionante arte dibujado a mano y su música envolvente.

La trama sigue a Dust, un misterioso guerrero acompañado de su espada parlante, Ahrah, y un pequeño ser llamado Fidget. Juntos, emprenden un viaje épico a través del mundo de Elysium para descubrir la verdad detrás de la identidad de Dust y enfrentar un mal antiguo.

El combate en el juego es fluido y satisfactorio, con combos y habilidades que evolucionan a medida que avanzas. Además, la historia se desarrolla de manera intrigante, explorando temas de identidad, amistad y redención.

"Dust: An Elysian Tale" es un ejemplo destacado de lo que los desarrolladores independientes pueden lograr. A mi personalmente el juego me parecio bastante precioso, tanto sus ambientaciones de mapas como los "cameos" de personajes de otros juegos indie de la epoca (Entre ellos destacando a: Yuki de Dishwasher: Vampire Smile, Bandage Girl de Super Meat Boy y a Tim de Braid) Asi que sii te gustan los juegos de acción, la narrativa envolvente y los mundos visualmente impresionantes, este juego es una experiencia que no querrás perderte.

The story is full of cliches about fate, destiny, the circle of life and souls, plus Fidget's role as the designated small quippy flying companion is what it is due to many fantasy adventure games insisting on having a witty Navi expy.

I liked what I played. I played through the main story on Normal. I am not the kind of player to really go back and do side quests, I like to follow the main story all the way through. I didn't ever have to go back and grind to make it through the game, which I liked. I didn't finish the final boss though, because by the time I got there I had pretty much exhausted all of my healing items except for a few I could purchase before I got to him. I don't mind that, I tend to do that with games, wanting to move onto something else.

Something I didn't like about the game though was it was kind of repetitive. There wasn't much enemy variety throughout it. There were just melee attackers over and over, re skinned and made more difficult.

Regardless, I enjoyed the 9 hours I spent playing this game. I do recommend it to others. Normal difficulty isn't too hard. 

[spoiler]The last stage ended up severely spiking in difficulty compared to the rest of the game, especially the final boss, so you may end up getting frustrated by this if you are like me, so consider yourself warned.[/spoiler]

Overall I give this game a 7/10, worth getting if you're interested in a chill-ish metroidvania experience, especially on sale.

146288824.review:
Dust an Elysian Tail Review

Review is after completing the main story missions and a few of the initial side quests.
[hr][/hr]


[b]Story[/b]
The story is about Dust, a typical amnesiac trying to discover who they were before. Our amnesiac gains a new friend and ally named Fidget and a talking sword Ahrah. There are some side characters but they are not very noteworthy, except for the mysterious shop vendor and the main antagonist of the game. The main story revolves around Dust and Fidget and their journey as they slowly piece together what is going on in the world. There is an unexpected twist near the end of the game, near the 80% mark. It’s interesting but not explained in much detail: simply dismissed as powerful magic. The ending is satisfying, but there is some sequel baiting at the end credits scene. But seeing this game was released in 2013 a sequel is unlikely.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
Hack and slash gameplay with combos is the main gameplay element; coupled with new traversal abilities. I played on normal difficulty and initially, up until the 70% mark enemies were manageable. After that point enemies become damage sponges. I realize it's a hack and slash game but these levels require much more  tedious hacking and slashing. So much so that gameplay became tedious and more like a chore. The later stage enemies such as soldiers are especially difficult and grindy. Another issue I had with the game was resurrection crystals, as they would be auto used if Dust fell in combat. Instead of being able to choose to use them, e.g. in a boss fight, they would get used up in a meaningless fight with fodder enemies. These crystals are also exorbitantly expensive. Another issue was the cost of the healing items. I had spent so much cash on those that I had no cash to craft any upgrades. I collected all the upgrade materials along with the blueprints required to craft the best armor and weapons only to find that the blacksmith charged thousands upon thousands of coins to craft these items. I had to finish the game without getting to see a single upgrade. The parry mechanic was not very precise. Sometimes the parry worked and sometimes not. Also instead of dropped items getting sucked in towards the player I had to use Dust to mop the ground to collect all the scattered material and coin drops. The mini map was just plain bad; that set of cubes that was in place of the mini map is simply not enough, especially in a genre that requires backtracking. Due to this I did not bother to backtrack. 
Apart from these issues, combat was enjoyable. Fidget’s attacks did significant damage and helped take the pressure off from Dust. Puzzle solving and getting to hidden areas was also fun and required some creative thinking.


[b]Graphics[/b]
Nothing to complain about but nothing to praise either. The graphics and art style got the job done here. 


[b]Controls[/b]
Played using the Xbox controller attached to the PC. Parry mechanics registered at certain times and not so at other times. 


[b]Side Missions[/b]
There are a few side missions in this game. But they are fetch quests and I had no motivation to backtrack as the mini map was not clear.


[b]Music/Soundtrack/Voice[/b]
Dust, Ahrah and Fidget’s voice acting are done well. And that was sufficient as the other characters were not memorable.


[b]Performance[/b]
Experienced no crashes and the game was not too hard on my PC (which is a mid-range PC). It did not cause undue heating of the CPU and GPU.


Overall Score 6/10

144903484.review:
Short Summary: 8/10
A game that sat in my "I should play list" for many years, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a charming indie Metroidvania-style game with an artstyle akin to that of a well-crafted cartoon.  The locations are vibrant and the story enjoyable to experience.  There's an emphasis on combat, with many areas teeming with enemies, but even on Tough difficulty, the adventure is very manageable, especially if you take the time to beat up every enemy as you explore.  A solid game overall.

The Full Review:
Dust an Elysian Tail presents as your standard Metroidvania indie game with a bit of a beat 'em up flair, but to me stands out thanks to it's art direction and style.  You play as a character named Dust, guided on an adventure by a mysterious talking blade, Ahrah, and it's flying guardian, Fidget.  Dust recalls nothing of his past, but as you progress, you learn the truth of his past, and of the events unfolding in the world around you.  The dynamic between this unlikely trio, as well as some of their interactions with other characters, was a highlight of the game for me.

The story is straightforward but enjoyable nonetheless. And if you don't bother to collect every hidden treasure, you can probably breeze through the story in a few hours. However I can't help but feel more could have been done to fill in the story.  More insight into the mysterious Moonbloods, explaining the motivations behind General Gaius's campaign, learning about Fidget's clan, or fleshing out the backstories of some of the other main characters would've been welcome, in my opinion.  I completed my playthrough satisfied overall but still craving to know a little bit more about the game's world.

Gameplay and combat is satisfying overall as well, and for the most part you'll probably slaughter most enemies like it was your birthright.  My only gripe with combat is that the parry mechanic felt a little odd, since you parry by holding the melee attack button at the proper time.  I would've preferred it to be on its own button, but it functioned just fine nonetheless.  Dust's walk speed is also a bit slow, and his jumps and dodges felt less nimble in comparison to other games I've played recently (notably Ori and the Blind Forest).  It was cool because it made Dust feel like he had weight to him, but it did make some of the platforming sections feel a little clunky.

At the end of the day, I'm glad I finally got around to playing this game.  I remember trying the demo WAY back when it released on the Xbox 360 and finding it enticing, but never bought it back then.  I'm happy to have found it here on Steam.  If you want to enjoy a charming Metroidvania-style adventure on a lazy weekend, in my opinion, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a perfect game to play.

144457922.review:
Beautiful game.  Runs well.  Got it for about $4 on sale, and I say it is entertainment money well spent.  Despite my criticisms I elaborate below, this game is well polished.

That said, this is not an E 10+ game for teenagers and unfettered adults like *Hollow Knight* is.  This an E 10+ game for E 10+ gamers.  

For this, I can excuse the voice acting for being hammy and the skill floor being pretty low on all but the higher difficulty settings and challenge areas.  As a completionist, I'd say Tough difficulty was good but that the game is probably most enjoyable on a lower setting.  Backtracking through swathes of samey enemies would have gone smoother.  

The tale this game has to tell does not break new ground, and its twists, almost all foreshadowed, seldom surprise.  For a kid's game, I accept such detriments.  However, this does not give the player much to meditate upon when backtracking and exploring through the aforementioned swathes.

Despite the underwhelming difficulty, I certainly saw potential for a high skill ceiling.  If ever there were a sequel that I had any say in, I would venture to appeal in this direction.  

Sounds and music are beautiful.  The menu and saving sounds remind me of *Ys Origin*.  The art drips of style, and the colors hearken to the likes of *Bastion*, which this game gives a nod to.  Lip flaps on the talking animations leave a bit to be desired at times, but I tend to nitpick that.

142480687.review:
I genuinely have no idea of how this game has such positive reviews. like seriously it just blows my mind

The first thing i felt when playing this game was cringy character designs and dialogue, right at the start of the game. However, that was just the main cast, and in particular i was annoyed at Fidget. And i was very surprised to have my first impressions over fidget change : 
The side characters, their designs, and the two other main characters managed to be so utterly atrocious, cringeworthy and painful to witness, that fidget actually somehow manages to be a more interesting and fun character than everyone else.
Theres nothing inherently wrong with childish-styled animal-people characters. But the ones in this game, much like their dialogue and story, just fill me with pain. They're not like the ones in pieces of media that anyone of any age, even adult ones, can still enjoy. It just extremely insanely cringeworthy, and i dont even think that kids will enjoy these characters very much either.
The main character and the talking sword in particular are awful, they feel like a 12 year old wanted to make the cool badass and somewhat edgy character, then decided they wanted the character to have some soft moments.
The worst thing is when you have a game and characters that are basically impossible to take seriously, and then the story tries to have more mature elements and death. I realised i couldnt put up with the cringe after i defeated the first boss that had just massacred the a village, somehow made the mc feel bad for him with their dialogue that started edgy and suddenly turned into a sob story, and then the dialogue ends by the two saying
" Ashes to ashes.. "
" [i][b]Dust[/b][/i] to [i][b]Dust[/b][/i] " 
and then the boss dies.
I said the word "cringe" a lot. I simply have no other way to describe it, because thats literally all it is. This game is just the absolute epitome of that term.

The combat in the game is honestly more atrocious than the story and characters. With your weapon you're just mindlessly spamming the same small selection of moves against hordes (and i really mean, HORDES) of braindead dumb damage sponge enemies that can hardly attack you effectively, but that get stunlocked by almost anything. Except theres 9999 of them, which would get kind of annoying in the highest difficulty, because i would get hit once every several hundred enemies killed, and that single hit would probably take a huge chunk of my hp or one shot me instantly, so i just lose more progress and have to do the chore even more. Which gets even more annoying when you die to something with no wind-up from off-screen. It gets even worse when some enemies that do nothing except slow everything down and force you to take it slow, instead of ending the chore faster, are introduced. The movement is genuinely floaty and imprecise as balls, sometimes geometry launches you into orbit with the flight move. 
And then you have the fidget attacks, which are a substantial portion of the relevant unlocks in the game. They're basically just a few different flavors of braindead, effortless, spammable AoE nukes that will hit the entire screen. You can either have it alongside your sword as another tool to slowly chip away at extreme damage sponge enemies, or you can invest it all into fidget so you spend the entire game nuking and stunlocking almost all the enemies (except this time at an actually decent pace) by doing nothing except pressing two buttons.

People told me this game had cool metroid-elements and it advertises itself as a metroidvania. But all separate regions are completely unconnected from eachother and are all accessed via fast-travel. The metroid-style powerups do nothing except to create an arbitrary obstacle between the player and some (often garbage) treasure that will require backtracking after.

I genuinely have no idea why this game has a gear and level up system. Its all the exact same gear with better numbers, its just completely superfluous and adds nothing except maybe making you grind for the highest difficulty. There really wasnt a need to come up with 90000 different kinds of materials and gear that change nothing except numbers

summed up :
- the characters are mentally painful to look at and listen
- the story is mentally painful to think of in retrospect, let alone actually witness
- the combat is mind numbingly boring, until you get one-shot by a single hit and then it turns into an aneurysm
- the highest difficulty somehow manages to be 0% challenge 100% chore. I am not even exagerating
- all the elements like metroid-styled unlocks, gear stats, etc feel completely half assed, insignificant at best, and a complete detriment at worst.
Dont get me wrong, its somewhat impressive that a single dude made almost every single thing in this game, thats admirable effort. But just because it takes a lot of effort, that doesnt mean it cant be bad. The only pro i see in this game are the hand drawn visuals and graphics, which clearly took a lot of work for a one-man-job, and i admire that... but i still think it mostly looks dull.

This is one of the very few games that i straight up could not get myself to finish them. dropped it about halfway in so i dont know if it gets better after, but from what ive seen, think this might be the game with the lowest quality/effort ratio i have ever played in my life. I even feel like playing through the entirety of YIIK was (and is) more worth doing than enduring half, let alone the entirety of Dust: An Elysian Tail. In fact, if i ignore literal shovelware games, this is easily the worst game i have ever played

I have absolutely zero idea of how this game is reviewed so positively. Im just going to assume that people want to fuck Fidget.

I rate games based off of five categories: 
• Gameplay (Mechanics and Story) 
• Controls (Consistency of input)
• Visuals (Graphics, Aesthetic, and Tone)
• Audio (Voice and Music)
• Enjoyability (Immersion and/or Desire to keep playing)

Dust: An Elysian Tail:
Gameplay: 7/10
Controls: 7/10
Visuals: 8.5/10
Audio: 8/10
Enjoyability: 7/10

Overall: 7.5 out of 10

138789591.review:
I initially bought Dust in August 2014, played it for about 4 hours and forgot to continue.
Now I finally started a new playthrough yesterday and finished it within 2 days with all achievements. 
Warning regarding the achievements: Two achievements belong to the same quest, and based on your decision at the end of said quest gives you either of the achievements. Luckily I looked through the achievements beforehand and just picked what I didn't do 9 years ago.



Dust is certainly not a bad game, but its age shows.
The controls are all very responsive, but the problem is, that the controls are partially unreliable, if that makes sense. Dust has a spin move, which you can use to move around in the air.
Thing is, when enemies are around, the ability often just decides to shoot you upwards. And I mean UPWARDS, like a rocket to the top of the screen where no enemies are.
From then on you just gotta wait until you fall again to get back into the fight. And that happens ALL the time.
However, when you want it to shoot you up to reach a platform/ledge, it sometimes just doesn't want to move you upwards at all.

Another thing I disliked was the difficulty. I played on the highest difficulty for about 30% of the game. I had to lower it to the second hardest difficulty setting unfortunately, since the developers idea of high difficulty is to get Oneshot by literally everything. One small monsters attack? Dead. One flamethrower hit? Dead. 
After I invested in some defense and noticed that its useless, as I still got killed in one hit by everything, I lowered it to the second-hardest difficulty, where it was actually decently balanced.

As previously mentioned, the game is a little aged, but considering it's now pretty much exactly 10 years old, it's still a rather decent Metroidvania. Rather short though, so maybe wait for a sale.

138731264.review:

Easily under 20 hours for all achievements or if you'd like to take it slow for the story possibly 30. Either way, it's a hidden gem.

10/10

138528752.review:
I absolutely love this game. I only just completed it today in fact. (two days after purchase lmao)
The gameplay is fun and engaging, but also challenging to get good at, very rewarding.
The world is well-built, it certainly established itself thoroughly.
There weren't any major bugs on my playthrough, and I never experienced a crash no matter how much I forced it to have onscreen.
The music is absolutely perfect, I could sit with the title screen alone open for hours to relax and reflect, but that's quite literally only scratching the surface.
And the story?
Ohohohohhhh, the story.
I refuse to say anything specific about the story, in fear of accidentally or indirectly spoiling it for anyone like myself (before purchase) who has yet to experience any form of gameplay or info on this game other than the steam page.
And as a die-hard Metroid fan, all that I will say is this: "I came for the metroidvania tag. But God dammit I stayed out of respect for this story."

I literally can't explain enough how phenomenal this is.
It has the writer's side of me giddy with satisfaction and inspiration, and it has my artist side in the mood for fanart.

Overall?
I give it a 110/100, because it scored 10 points of extra credit.

People, this game is a perfect example of why you shouldn't write off a game due to its age, even if it only has a cult following

138021922.review:
Good game.
[list]
[*]Combat is fun and challenging on Tricky difficulty, though it falls off in the endgame when spamming magic becomes extremely powerful and enemies annoyingly prone to parrying attacks.
[*]Sound effects are satisfying.
[*]Music... exists. I don't really remember it.
[*]Story is very simple, save the good guys and fight the bad guys. The twist regarding the main character's identity was interesting, but not really explored beyond the basic idea.
[*]Characters are fairly flat, feeling like archetypes rather than real people. 
[*]The voice acting only reinforces it; it's not bad, as the voices do sound like the characters rather than some guy with a microphone - but it's hard for me to get emotionally attached to a character that sounds like a squeaky toy.
[*]Graphics... for the most part quite beautiful, but the art style for the characters is really basic. The remarkably smooth animation kind of hides it, but when entering dialogue with characters it can be jarring going from the detailed backdrop to these simple designs with oversized eyes, lack of details, and flat coloration.
[/list]
Overall 7/10, enjoyable and worth buying, but with some shortcomings.
Compare with Oboro Muramasa for a similarly beautiful and fun game with a much higher budget; some of the same issues with flat characters and wonky end-game balance, but a more intriguing story, and the budget really shows in the art.

137455560.review:
Decent little slasher game and a "lite-vania".
I've had it in my backlog for years, and I was blown away by the quality of it, despite being mostly a solo project. While still insanely impressive now, in comparison to some other games in the genre, it is not really exceptional I think.

Gameplay has a moderate amount of depth, kinda reminds me of the "vagrant" game I played a bit before this. Combo potential is pretty similair, but the minion abilities and comboing them adds that extra flair and special sauce, that is recognizably Dust. With spin move allowing some pretty creative puzzle, and a surprisingly free-flow movement. There is quite a bit of potential, and you can squeeze really long combos (as evident by 1000 combo achievement), but it kind of boiled down to rotation of several buttons, light attack, timed light into parry, directional dodge to get out of the center of the horde, aerial spins to build up combo fast, magic+spin to have some additional chain hits while using the bar (which fills by using light attacks). If you wanted to be extra fancy, you could also do the slide attack, light to heavy grab, aerial light to heavy grab, or quick light+heavy for launcher. Took a while to list the moves, but the biggest factor is chaining normal melee with spins (if you want high combo), otherwise normal melee for major damage.
The world isn't exactly interconnected, it's a set of open levels, that have story missions in them for a specific chapter, while you can revisit them freely for sidequests and puzzle secrets. The secrets are pretty damn fun to figure out, and sometimes a highlight of my gameplay. It's a good time, above average quality for sure.

The visuals are amazing in terms of smooth animations and nice use of vfx, especially with it being 10 years old now and once again - made solo. The furry faces of most characters are pretty damn generic, which ended up almost uncanny compared to other visuals. Some of the backgrounds were pretty nice too.

The sounds are good, if sometimes a bit imbalanced in volume, some effects are slightly repetitive after over 10 hours of playtime. Music is decent and works nice with the fairy tale aesthetic of the game, though I know that part was done by other people. The amount of voice acting surprised me, but the direction of VAs never struck me. Dust for example has the same tone over the 99% of game's runtime, sounding confused even by the end, a lot of minor characters were one note and cartoony, reminding me of some really low budget cartoons made in early 2000s.

The story can take you a bit by surprise, I was expecting something generic all the way, but the twist near the start felt like a neat shocker. The only shame being how predictably it plays out after that initial reveal. There is another twist with the protagonist's backstory, but that felt a little hollow, and borderline "OC do not steal", part darkness, part light, with inner conflict despite the goal of saving the world and uniting nations. I guess how unoriginal it ends up is a somewhat of a "twist" too, but not a satisfying one for me.

I bet you can get it pretty cheap, considering how old it is by now, and you should have a decent time with it for quite a few hours, even if the story stops doing it for you, gameplay is solid enough for sure.

This is a must-play game for anyone who loves Metroidvanias.

The gameplay is classic Metroidvania, with exploration, platforming, and combat. The character animations are smooth as silk without interfering with the responsiveness of the moves, attacks, and specials you get access to as you level. The voice-over work in the game is great which is a refreshing change from the walls of dry text you're usually greeted with, especially at the low price point this game is available for.

The visuals are outstanding from start to finish, the 2D characters, effects and backgrounds are lovingly produced in vivid clear colours. Even when there are dozens of enemies and the screen is full of action it's always clear what's going on.

Overall, this game is an absolute gem and I hope you love it as much as me.

135935626.review:
Where to start with this one... 

I guess I'll start by saying that I genuinely can see where people like this game. Even as an achievement hunter, I can see why this game is still well liked. 
HOWEVER, while I did not hate this game with ever fiber of my being, I cannot say that I enjoyed it. 

So I guess this is more of a neutral review? Let me explain. 

Pros:
-The art is actually stunning. I originally had a problem with the simplicity of the characters versus the backgrounds and other aspects, but I realized that that was maybe too critical. The backgrounds and general art though are beautiful, actually pleasing to my eyes. 
-Soundtrack is pretty nice. 
-Combat system: This will also show up on the cons list but I say the combat system is a pro because it is a good beat'em up combat system, but it's so ridiculously repetitive that it hurts (more on that later)
-Improper leveling: So, this may honestly be on me and I'm not afraid to admit it. I tend to start games on the hardest difficulty possible (usually because there's an achievement tied to playing games on the hardest difficulty), and that may be the cause of this. BUT, I feel like the last two stages of the game are ridiculously hard for no reason. I never needed health items until I got to the snow area. This game also did the same thing that Mass Effect 1 did and made the final boss "hard" by just giving him a ****-ton of health and that bothers me to no end. Making the final boss difficult is great, but More Health does not equal more difficult. It just makes the fight boring, like, mind numbingly boring. I had more trouble from the minions leading up to him than the final boss himself and that just doesn't sit well with me. 

Cons: 
-Generally boring. This game is beautiful art/sound wise, but man does the story and world building need work. The underground is about the only part of the game that was even remotely interesting world-building wise. That was the only place where I found myself wanting to explore, but that's only 1/4th of the game. The story and the characters? They have the bare minimum required and that's it. They all feel shallow to me, which is honestly depressing because I feel like there's so much more to pick at. It's like we got to the edge of the top of the mountain and stopped climbing before ever actually reaching the top. The characters have so much more to explore and it's just not there. They give you what you need to know for the main story and that's it. Which, if I'm honest, doesn't really make me fall in love with any of them. The characters also don't have much personality if I'm honest. I feel like the one with the most personality is Fidget, who is also probably my favorite character for that reason. However, even with fidget, I want to know more about where she comes from and why exactly she's been tasked with guarding this sword and why the sword is even in her clan's possession. 
The main story-line is also incredibly predictable and even if it wasn't, they tell you the plot twist before it even happens. There is such a thing as too much fore-shadowing and this game is a perfect example of it. So, about 3/4ths of the way through I didn't feel a need to play any further because I already knew what was going to happen. the last 1/4th of the games was even more boring than the rest. 
-Combat system: It's good but man is it DRY. By the time you get to late game there's essentially one attack you're using specifically with the occasional Parry and that's it. I love a good beat'em up game, I love watching those combo numbers go up, bu not when I have to do the exact same move on repeat to do so. This is especially true with the final boss where you literally have to do the same move just to survive throughout his ridiculous amount of health. (Or that's how it felt to me anyways)
-Voice acting is super cringe and also goes back to the same thing I said about the characters feeling like they have a lack of personality. It just doesn't really feel alive to me with the exception of Fidget. 

A lot of this might be preference, or It happened to me on the account of the difficulty I had it set to. That being said, I can not recommend this game to anyone who is story-driven like myself. If it weren't for the fact that I'm an achievement hunter, I don't know that I would've sat through all of that for as long as it did for me to finish it. Even now I'm dreading having to open this game back up to finish getting the achievements, because I already know I'm uninterested and that it's going to be incredibly boring. 

If you get it on sale, go ahead and try it if you really feel a need, but otherwise, I don't recommend it.

135699375.review:
If you enjoy Metroidvania style games, this one is a good choice.
Overall, I rate it at an 8/10

For a 100% completion (I ended with 114% after doing everything, as far as I am aware) will take around 16 hours.

The story is decent; don't expect any major unseen twists, as the side plot following the big baddie kind of gives any twists away before the main character is made known of the revelation, so you will already know before the story hits that point (main baddie mentions alludes to it at maybe 15% in, but the MC isnt made aware until like the 90%).

That aside, its a fun game, with very fluid combat (most of the time). 20 side quests in total, so you wont get too sidetracked from the story. Plenty of gear to customize the playstyle. Icing on the cake, it runs without a hitch on the Steam Deck.

If there were anything lacking, it would be world building/story. The story is there, but it is bare-bones amnesiac story for about 80% of the play-though. The world building is minuscule, and again, I think that last 15-20% of the game is where the most world building occurred. But if you look as it as Castlevania inspired, and ignore the town sections, then world building can be ignored.

135444130.review: [h1]Schizzoid Humanoid Metroivadnioid[/h1][*][b]This game can best be summarized as "passion without polish"[/b][list][*]It may bungle some key aspects of the execution, but conceptually speaking, this game did have a [i]lot[/i] of potential. Clearly, there was a ton of passion and dedication put into this game, from the variety of gorgeous locations to the intricately-constructed item economy; if there is anything one can say in favor of Dust:AET, it is the artistry with which is was made. Sadly, this does not extend to the [i]effort[/i] put into it, or at the very least, that effort was not channeled into the correct places. Specifically, the pitfalls occur in the world design, story, and combat.[*][b][i]The world design[/i][/b] is seriously lacking. Each screen is immaculate and efficiently instructs the player in where the game expects you to go, but how they are strung together is the problem. Reread that last sentence; thereïn lies the problem: that the game [i]expects you to go in a certain direction[/i]. In transitional screens, this is fine, even perhaps a good thing, but every screen of the game, from beginning to end, behaves this way, and that it emblematic of the core failing of this game: it is not a metroidvania. Speaking personally, I picked up this game because it was billed to me as a metroidvania, and the whole time, I kept waiting for the game to "open up" (become less lineär), only for that time never to arrive. Even the different areäs are segmented into separate locations on a map screen, completely eliminating possibilities for traversal. Some connections sans map persist to the final product, but they are few in number. Some ares are nonlinear in structure, but most are not. What few paths one encounters that are initially untraversable lead at best to a chest or one or more keys to use on such chests. At the same time, the game can't be called definitively a sidescrolling beat-em-up, since there are so many branching pathways and permanent mobility upgrades; there is mandatory backtracking at certain points, but [i]locating[/i] that backtracking is almost always trivial. As a beat-em-up, it has an annoying amount of backtracking. As a metroidvania, it lacks substantial rewards for exploration. The characters from other games that one finds locked in cages offer almost nothing in terms of mobility/combat and absolutely nothing story-wise. All this is not even to call attention to the fact one needs to use clearly-glitchy exploits or take advantage of invincibility frames to traverse certain areas, both of which one will likely encounter in the "mansions" areä (which, as a sidenote, is where I spent most of my time in the game; it's seemingly designed to frustrate you as a player, featuring invincible flying enemy-generators in a game where you can't go to the next screen if there are enemies nearby, platforming which only becomes possible with exploits, and more). [b][i]The world design needed more effort.[/i][/b][*][b][i]The story[/i][/b] is, in concept, very good. In print, even, the execution of the story is kinda good, but there are simply too many angles that don't go explored. Even the sidequests (which are by and large well-implemented) generally contribute fairly little to the broader story. Given the fact the central mystery centers around events that occurred in the recent past, this should have been, at the very least, possible. Perhaps one could hide such sidequests (the activity or the issuer) in the hard-to-access reaches of the map, instead of random chest, keys, or videogame characters. This was even implemented in one instance, but the sidequest in question had such dizzyingly little connection to the story that it broke my immersion. I'm just spitballing, but perhaps a regretful member of the enemy faction decided to hide out in a remote areä due to fear of reprisal from their former superiors or victims? However, all this is not even to acknowledge the obvious: the voice acting is terrible. Every character sounds believably themself, but their inflections are so often...[i]aliën[/i], as though every line was recorded separately with no indication as to the context it would occur in. I am thankful for my ability to play without listening to it. [b][i]The story needed more effort.[/i][/b][*][b][i]The combat[/i][/b] is something I can't rightly call bad, but only because I doubt I would have enjoyed the game had it been more complex. For what it is, it's a good system, even if most of it is just pressing the attack button with specific timing or a specific amount. The "dust attack" (which was spoiled for me by looking at the controls, so I don't feel too bad mentioning it) is incredibly versatile, and by the end of the game, I found myself using it much more than before. The chief problem with the combat is, rather, the enemies. The first boss is incredibly demanding, requiring repeated perfect timing to parry a very fuzzily-timed move, while bosses instantly become laughable afterwards, none but the final boss even coming close to the difficulty of the first. Inversely, while the rank-and-file enemies are trivially easy for most of the game, the last 2 chapters contain absolutely absurd difficulty spikes in even defeating the most low-level enemies in the areä. I never needed healing items until I got to the snow areä, after which I consumed them so fast I had to grind money to buy healing items. [b][i]The combat balancing needed more effort.[/i][/b][/list]If there's ever a rerelease of this game with fixing these things, I'll recommend it. At the moment... stay away. Read a summary of the story somewhere and imagine what it would be like, since that'll probably be better than playing it.

135354151.review: I might just be a sucker for the genre, but ss far as metroidvanias go, this is a good one to add to the collection. While there are certainly games of this genre that I enjoyed more at an objective level (Hollow Knight and Ori), I couldn't really put Dust down until I beat it.As all proper metroidvanias should be, Dust is fun to explore and scatters its secrets throughout. It flows well and I never found myself lost.I do have some criticisms that prevent me from giving it too high of a score though. Disclaimer: I feel like this game was made for children, and most of the criticisms I'm about to bring up here can be explained away due to that. As a result, don't take these too seriously as negatives, as they can just as easily be positives with the right perspective.First, it's story is pretty basic. It strings you along with a grand mystery that is then revealed and then the final encounter happens. Nothing revolutionary but the characters and plot weren't bad.Second, the game's balance is weird. Levelling and gear increase power at a near exponential rate, meaning old areas will be really easy, but being underlevelled is severely punished through 2 hit kos and taking ages to kill things. Again, this is likely intentional as it means that kids can overlevel any area they are struggling with. This seems to be true for every difficulty level. The combat gets repetitive as well, but the game isn't super long so it didn't matter to me that much.The only "real" flaw I see with the game is its parrying. Parrying isn't something you have to worry about for the most part, but there are a few larger mobs that you can only kill via parrying. It's weirdly inconsistent and I found myself getting annoyed at it. Maybe it's just a skill issue on my part though.7/10 do play if you like metroidvanias.

134739445.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail es un juego de acción y aventuras que ofrece una jugabilidad emocionante y desafiante. El sistema de combate es fluido y satisfactorio, con una amplia variedad de movimientos y habilidades para desbloquear y mejorar a lo largo del juego. Los combos son una parte integral del sistema de combate, lo que hace que las batallas sean aún más emocionantes y dinámicas.

El juego también cuenta con un mundo vibrante y detallado que es un placer explorar. Los personajes y entornos están bien diseñados, y hay muchas misiones secundarias y secretos para descubrir en el mundo del juego. La música y los efectos de sonido también son bastante buenos, aunque no son lo más destacado del juego.

Una pequeña crítica es que, aunque la historia es interesante, el desarrollo de los personajes y la trama podría haber sido un poco más profundo. Algunos jugadores también han señalado que el juego es relativamente corto, lo que es una lástima considerando lo entretenido que es.

En general, Dust: An Elysian Tail es un gran juego de acción y aventuras que ofrece una jugabilidad divertida y un mundo bien diseñado para explorar. A pesar de sus pequeñas fallas, el sistema de combate, los combos y las habilidades lo hacen muy emocionante, y el diseño visual y la música lo hacen muy atractivo. Si eres fanático de los juegos de acción y aventuras, deberías darle una oportunidad a Dust: An Elysian Tail.

I remember watching my older brother play this game way back when it was a free game of the month on Xbox 360 and I was enraptured by it. It was one of my first experiences playing a more advanced video game myself, since he often hogged the console from my sister and I, and I absolutely fell in love with everything about it. From the art style, to the fantastic soundtrack, and most of all, the story, Dust was so very special to me as a preteen. And even now, as a full-grown adult, I've gone back to replay it several times on multiple consoles and it still holds up. I genuinely just wish it were longer or had gotten a sequel. I would love to be able to explore more of Elysium some day.

To me, this game is a 10/10, though I may be biased due to my nostalgia. Nonetheless, it's a great game that was beginner friendly enough that I was able to beat it as a kid, and still fun and challenging enough to enjoy as an adult, with more gaming experience under my belt.

134038688.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail stands as a shining example of what indie developers can achieve with a bit of support behind them. After three and a half years of hard work, Dean Dodrill created a great game – one that, while not flawless, is criminally underrated and is definitely worth your time. With a strong story to boot and a well-rounded cast of characters, all wonderfully complimented by a beautiful hand drawn art style and a world that’s just as engrossing as the mystery it presents. The main story clocks in about ten or more hours, plus there is heaps of side content to tackle too. It does occasionally stumble with its boss fights, voice acting and combat system, but there’s no doubt this is a Metroidvania title to remember for years to come.

PROS:
✓ Gameplay is great
✓ Fantastic visuals, it feels like you’re playing a cartoon
✓ Soundtrack is very good
✓ Metroidvania and action RPG elements
✓ Fantastic story
✓ Lots of content aside from story missions

CONS:
- Some later platforming sections are a tad annoying
- Low difficultly level
- Repetitive combat
- Hit and miss voice acting
- Underwhelming boss fights

130778150.review: A metroidvania game with a beautiful art style and a pretty competent combat system. I played this years ago on PS4 and I felt a but nostalgic to try it again. Well I can say that those rose tinted glasses didn't really have to work hard because the game is still great!  The game tells a story of an amnesiac warrior that is entrusted with a legendary blade. Said blade happens to have a tiny creature as a guardian named Fidget and she is arguably the best part of the game to me. The main character Dust has pretty good back and forths with her keeping him grounded in the moment. She kept the conversations light and occasionally got a pretty good laugh out of me. The overall story is a bit light but still good for what it is giving you around a 10 ish hour campaign. There are a few side missions but most of them are usually on the way to what your already doing so it's more of a way to get resources more often then not. The combat has a pretty good flow to it where you actually get an xp bonus for higher combo counts making you really not want to get hit and abuse high juggling ranged attacks from Fidget. For level ups you get to choose what stats get bumped up and for the most part attack and Fidget are the 2 most important stats followed by defense and then health. That's what I used and on the second highest difficulty I made it through with little to no worries, just make sure to save often. The maps are pretty open and there's a pretty good variety of styles between the different areas so I never got bored going into new areas every few hours. I'm glad that this game is as good as I remember and I'll definitely come back to it again. This is well worth the $15 it's asking for.

Easy Mode = GREAT Game. Absolute fun and enjoyment.
Hard Mode = Not hard, just tedious. Not difficult, just slow. Not intense, just repetitive.

Absolutely recommend the game be played on Easy mode and you completely forget about Hard Mode. It was simply a bad experience playing this game again thinking hard mode would resemble doing more, just with strategy. Instead the Developer sided with less is more and removed the players capabilities in Hard Mode instead of incorporating new move sets, new mechanics or difference of enemy play-style (aggressive vs tactical). You do less, have less and take more damage in Hard Mode. Removing things from your game to present a harder difficulty is one way to increase how hard a game is, but isn't the best way to go about showing difficulty.

If you do plan to play on Hard I recommend you 100% the rest of the game before fighting the end-boss. It'll just make things easier for you all-the-while still allowing you the accomplishment of saying you beat it on hard.

124165548.review:
I was once a young teenager who loved this game and enjoyed it wholly— but now? I'm older and a lot more skeptical, and I can't say that I have enjoyed my return to Dust: An Elysian Tail.

This is most definitely a game for younger people; the characters, writing, and story-telling all fall in line with what you'd expect for a game rated Everyone 10+. Not to say that it's bad, but it's just not for me anymore.

But what does age quite poorly is the gameplay. The enemy variety is low, with there being very little functional difference in how you engage enemies, because in all my experience, you can perform an Aerial Dust Storm that combos all enemies and does huge damage constantly. There's not really a lot of skill involved even on Hardcore. The only difference I could notice is that you'd die extremely quickly [i]if[/i] an enemy could hit you.

I do think the art is still nice and for it to be made by one person is still a huge achievement. I just don't think I'm the audience for this game anymore.

124089263.review:
TL;DR:
Inde game from 2012. you feel the jank but it doesn't take away from your ability to play it for the most part.
The game's [b]development[/b] story is more interesting than the game's story.
It's still an experience. 

Dust is a tiny little inde Metriodvania game with a strong 2010 inde game vibe.
Its not the greatest game, but its easy to get through. There are other parts of the game that aren't nearly as polished as others. It's still fun, no doubt, but if you have a hyper-critical eye- im sure you'll see areas in which the game feels undercooked.

Like the RPG elements, as an example. You can powerscale yourself so fast that you're taking down most enemies with 1 hit. Your ability to make things excessively easier for you come down to how you allocate stat-points that, should of locked the player off a lot more than it did.

The story isn't much to look at, comes off as silly sometimes. 
Dust loses his fckin' mind over a little rock guy's dad, [spoiler] who you never see onscreen till he's dead[/spoiler]
But you know, plenty of stories ask you to care a lot more about a character you've never met.

Honestly the games development story is more interesting, and you kind of appreciate the game more knowing it was one guy doing all of the work.
This game came out when Xbox had an inde arcade marketplace, and it shows that it was running off Xbox money. Gleaming from what i know about the development about Psychonauts, you met microsoft's deadlines, or they didn't publish you.
So the fact that Dodrill, the developer of dust, was in with their XBLA releases, leads me that the crunch he put in was not self-imposed. Which explains why some of the game's areas feel undercooked- the dev slammed ass in 2011-2012 to meet a microsoft-imposed deadline.
Which, again, shows in its gameplay- but not so much that its annoying or frustrating. 

I suppose my recommendation comes with a asterisk.
This game brought me back to a time when Braid, Fez, and Meatboy (games that are referenced as secrets for you to find, with their own stat buffs) were THE inde games. It reminds me of the times where the hot new inde games were the talk of the schoolyard, so to speak. That is, to say that you'll appreciate this game more if you have 2010's nostalgia.

For the price there really isn't much to lose, and as someone who hasn't really been able to get into platformers since playing Prince of Persia (the Fallen King) on the DS, this appeals to a pretty wide audience.

I really hope someday we get some version of a sequel, because this game developer deserves more attention.

I disliked every single aspect of this game.

Combat is boring. Magic spam followed up with the same melee combos over and over (I beat this game on the hardest difficulty). This wouldn't be a big problem if the enemies were interesting, but all enemies and bosses are mindlessly easy to dispatch. You're also essentially invulnerable, as you can't be killed in one hit if you're over quarter health AND you can pause the game to use healing items instantaneously. 

I also did not enjoy any amount of exploration in this game.  Environments that you visit are dull and uninteresting, as well as the music paired along with it. Navigating these environments was also pretty boring no real challenge or interconnected-ness. Movement in this game is very jank as well, with the dash being tied to your mana meter and a whirlwind move that is so jank that it will fling you into space.

The characters have to be the worst part. Not only do the characters look like they were ripped straight from DeviantArt, but the voice actors sound like they were ripped from your average anime English dub. I would've muted the dialogue, but there was no voice audio slider. This lead to me skipping all dialogue, as I could not stand the voice acting. 

I fail to understand why this game is rated so highly. I love Metroidvanias, and I still despise this game.

123246375.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is in a genre I've previously had great difficulty getting into; Metroidvania. But a combination of stunning art, compelling gameplay, strong music and excellent controls make this the closest I can think of to baby's first Metroidvania.

The story's pretty simple, which isn't a bad thing. You're Dust, an amnesiac swordsman chosen to defeat an evil force terrorizing the land. The game's anthropromorphic cast, which ranges from cute to uncanny to downright disturbing, is enjoyable to watch and there's a neat twist to the story that I won't spoil. The writing's also surprisingly solid, with some very good jokes sprinkled in. The banter between Dust and Fidget is the highlight. The biggest thing to note about this game isn't the story, but how the story's told. Everything in this game was hand-animated by one person. Everything. From the cutscenes to all gameplay animations and background elements, it's hand animated. HAND ANIMATED! On top of that, the combination of Eastern and Western artistic elements turn the game into a unique hybrid being without an easy analogue.

The gameplay's also surprisingly solid. The game's primarily a metroidvania, with a combination of exploration through segmented 2D environments and new abilities being unlocked to allow for previously-inaccessible zones to be explored. The combat, while basic hack and slash in nature, has some interesting nuances with the inclusion of AOE abilities, juggling that can even be incorporated into navigation, and combo counts which increase experience. Yes, this is also something of an RPG, with leveling and equipment and stats and sidequests. There are also six challenge zones which test your dexterity and speed, but some of these can border on the unfair and I've only completed four with the top score (one was a pure fluke). I think I wouldn't have enjoyed the game as much as I did were it not for the modern and fluid controls. It makes playing the game an actual joy, not the plodding appearence that put me off most Metroidvanias.

On the sound front, all is well. The voice acting is more than servicable, adding real life and energy to Dust and Fidget especially.  The sound effects are also sound, if generic in places, and fit the odd mixture of Eastern and Western in this game. The music, co-composed by Alexander Brandon of Deus Ex fame and music group HyperDuck SoundWorks, is atmospheric and enjoyable, with a few standout tracks such as "Aurora" and "The Blackmoor Mountains".

This game is an absolute steal even at its standard price. Please support this incredible creator. We need more games like this, combining slick controls and a fascinating bled of genres with stunning art and enjoyable music. It's also technically a very sound PC port, with no framerate drops, crashes or glitches. The only minor critiques I have are its simple story, some fiddly elements within its navigation, and the sometimes-unfair challenge rooms. I don't say or feel this often. This is an absolute must buy.

9.5/10.

122748465.review:
This game is very polished. The Movement feels fluid, the combat system is simple, but it has this nice sort of rhythm to it, which makes for some fun gameplay, the level design is very well thought out, teaching the player about their new movement abilities until the point of mastery, there's a certain charm to the dialogue, the characters are unique in their own ways, the scenery makes each area you explore different in their own way, evoking different emotions on the player. 

The Negatives: The Story itself is kind of bland, it hints at things that might make it more interesting, but thee's never really any payout. The lack of a proper fast travel system makes the gameplay repetitive if you are looking for a completionist run. This is made worse by the fact that there aren't really any major shortcuts that you can discover through your progress. This made worse by the fact that the map is not very useful as each block represents a very large area, this in itself wouldn't be a problem except for the fact that you can't label it for posterity. The parry system feels inconsistent, but the payout is too good not to try it, not to mention that it's almost necessary for certain enemies. On the other hand, the bosses were a complete joke, and had very little difficulty with them despite the fact thta I was playing on the second hardest difficulty. Finally, despite how much I liked the dialogue, it has far too much of it for my personal taste.

All things considered, I think it's a pretty solid MV with fun gameplay, but with some questionable design choices.

Final Rating: 8/10

122523193.review:
Fun Metroidvania with a few quirks I'm not a fan of. Game crashes on map screen if you hold a direction while entering it, Xbox Series X controllers seemingly don't work, and the game is way to easy to accidentally close if you spam escape, all issues I feel like a studio published by Microsoft should know to fix by now.

On the contrary, this game's story does a delightful job [spoiler]luring you into a false sense of security with "rawr XD" era humor and starting out with all of the iconic "chosen one" Mary Sue tropes, then thrusting you into a world where Dust has an apparently-detestable upbringing and our heroes are never guaranteed to do the right thing in time. Bad stuff happens in this game, and you just sort of have to accept it. It's a nice twist on what looks to be another happy-go-lucky furry-made product.[/spoiler]

It goes without saying that this game is obviously trying to appeal to furries at the time of its release, with a noticeably "2010 DeviantART" artstyle, Fidget being a goofy *X3 nuzzles* cookie-munching bat creature who I refuse to comment on further, and tons of faux-Japanese tropes that play into the anime uprising of that era. It sounds cringy in a modern light, and just once in a while Fidget will say something along the lines of "evil x of dooooooom!" that makes me want to tear out my ears, but for anyone who frequented the internet space at the time, especially as a young teen, it will definitely come off as somewhat nostalgic to experience a product of that era you might have missed.

There's obvious comparisons to other Metroidvanias like Hollow Knight and Blasphemous, both games which share similar elements with this game's combat, but admittedly this game stands on its own as one of the more unique games I've played. Melee is strong, magic is weak, and your "combo" attack can multiply the magic effects to make them viable in combat. It sounds annoying to do, but experimenting with all of the different spells you unlock is pretty fun. This also long-predates the rapid influx of Metroidvanias using the Dark Souls flasks, which is a huge breath of fresh air for me as somebody who plays a lot of these kinds of games and is growing sick of dropping my fucking healing item because I got slapped in the face while using it.

While some of the digital drawings in this game might have aged a bit (they 100% look like the kind furries were drawing a decade ago, with hard fade-to-black shadows and a hard-on for the blur tool), I actually find myself enjoying a lot of it. The environments are appealing, some of the character designs are great, and the combination of 2D art and a 3D model on the sword just looks cool. 

There's a lot here that a lot of people are going to have to put aside and overcome to enjoy this, especially if they're put off by furries, but I won't act all high-and-mighty and pretend this isn't just a solid game. Buggy, but solid. Worth the price, especially on sale.

122516436.review:
Not a super long game by any means, but still worth your time.

For newer players who also don't want a game that's too easy, I recommend playing on Tough, rather than Hardcore or Normal. I've completed the game on Hardcore and... it's pretty damn rough if you don't know what you're doing, plus Hardcore isn't necessary for completion.

Other than that, the game is rather simple in its combat, and it has a bit of that dated quality, but that's what gives it charm. There's no over-acting, no memorizing 17 different control schemes; you just get in and play, and enjoy the story. The characters themselves have some pretty nice chemistry, too, which develops as time goes.

And that last part is what frustrates me about some of the negative reviews. They won't get very far, then complain about the dialogue? Like, of course it's not gonna be some grand exchange at TWO HOURS IN, especially if you're not someone who naturally plays through things quickly like myself. The story actually progresses, and even if it's not the most amazing thing in the world, it's still something worth talking about.

Oh, and it's also because a lot of the game's aspects were handled by a single person.

Rambling aside, definitely try the game. If you just don't like Metroidvanias or Hack and Slashers, that's fine, but otherwise get through at least a chunk of the game first.
