122452271.review:
I first found out about this game from a fairly popular YouTuber by the name of Iteachvader. In his videos, he makes a few jokes and references to this game here and there. So eventually, my curiosity got the best of me and I decided to try it for myself. And let me just say, the fact that this game was developed in most part by just one person is honestly astounding. This game does so many things that are impressive on all fronts. The story is amazing (serious tone with plenty of fitting themes such as loss and redemption, but it also knows when to be light-hearted and humorous), the characters are loveable and memorable with lots of great interactions and dialogue (Dust and Fidget make a great protagonist duo, technically trio if you count Ahrah), the environments are all visually breathtaking and fun to traverse and explore, the combat is fluid, responsive and fun to execute (simple and easy to learn, but tough and satisfying to master), and that soundtrack. Oh, that soundtrack. Hyperduck Soundworks and Alexander Brandon really killed it making the music for this game. Each and every single piece does a great job serving its purpose and is absolute ear candy to listen to (seriously, the second I first booted up the game, I just sat there in awe listening to that menu theme. To me, that was the first sign that I knew this game would be something special). 

My only real issue with the game is the third area in the main story. For a Metroidvania-inspired title, backtracking is never really an issue in Dust since you can get through areas pretty quickly and have plenty of opportunities to return to the world map from save stations (provided you have the required item to do so) and revisit areas from other entrances for ease of access. But in the third area of the game, getting back to the main section after taking a branching path takes forever, and since said main section is placed right in the middle of the area, warping back to one of the entrances doesn't really shorten that travel time at all. This is especially annoying if you enjoy doing item cleanup when arriving late in the game and have to constantly wander through several long rooms just to pick up one item on one path, only to backtrack all the way to the main section and repeat the whole process on a completely different path. This may seem just like a completionist thing, but doing this is also required in order to beat the main story. And it's the only part of the game to branch out into such long paths with no shortcuts or ways to ease that travel. Personally, that's the only part of the game that kind of bogged down the experience. But that doesn't stop me from loving the game to bits regardless.

All in all, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a breathtaking, heartbreaking experience that stands the test of time thanks to its smooth and responsive controls and combat, memorable story and characters (huge props to the voice director and all actors involved, phenomenal job here), and incredible soundtrack and art design that rival that of most modern day triple-A studios. I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Metroidvania-esque titles, sidescrolling hack-and-slashers, or story-driven games. You will have a blast with this one.

Dust an Elysian tail is an Action game that mixes metroidvania with Hack N slash elements, creating an unique gameplay that I never seen before. The level design is really good, It's not as labyrinthic as Metroid or Castlevania, but it does the job done, offering you some alternative routes, secret passages, skills and other stuff to access new areas. 

The Combat resembles hack n slash games, with a Combo system, moves and other elements that gives that charm, as well as some RPG mechanics like Clothes, experience and Stat upgrades.

The Story is Smooth like Silk and really good, at first it looks like a regular story but it really offers a fair amount of depth and some crude parts which I really liked, the main characters as well as the main antagonists are very well made, which it really hooks you, especially Fidget, love that character ngl.
Excelent Voice Acting most of the time, as well as a great OST, thumbs up.

Although, the game has a few issues, for example:
The designs of side characters, NPCs or even enemies are a bit odd? I can't explain why but it kinda ruins slightly the experience cuz It doesn't seem to match the style of other characters such as Dust or Fidget.
Another issue is the animations which feels a bit odd and some color choices.

Considering the fact this game was made by only ONE person It's a titanic step and not to throw hate, but this is a gigantic game that justifies it way more than undertale (since it was also developed by one person)
A great game that deserves more support and recognition.

119220098.review:
Overall, I would recommend. This game is really solid. The controls are nice, smooth, and feel precise. I can tell that a lot of time was spent on making the gameplay feel good. The story is decent. The writing is pretty fun. There is a decent amount of humor tossed in along with more serious themes, but it doesn't feel out of place or inappropriate.

My issues with the game are fairly minor to me, but others may feel different about them. On normal the game doesn't offer much of a challenge, but you can always increase the difficulty. The parry mechanic feels underutilized as a result. A few enemies pretty much require it in order to defeat them, but it doesn't feel like it offers much to the normal playthrough experience. This may be different on higher difficulty playthroughs. At first I was annoyed that the leveling system forced you to keep your stats somewhat balanced, but it made sense when I got to a location where the only way to defeat specific enemies was to use the magic system. It makes sense not to put the player in a situation where they can't defeat an enemy at all or where it would take a large amount of time to defeat them. The standard enemies feel a little basic. They don't seem to attack very frequently, but they are fun to mow through. Some may be turned off by the furry characters, but if you don't take that and yourself too seriously it isn't that big of an issue.

118590387.review:
Way way back in the far off year of 2014, I decided to get a gold membership on my Xbox 360. And back in this long forgotten era, you got 2 free games every month when you had a gold membership. (No gamepass yet kids!) I was super excited to get a bunch of free games, and the very first one I got? It was Dust: An Elysian Tail. It was super difficult, and I didn't get very far, but always thought the main character's design was really cool. I gave up around half way in, but watching my sister play it was a lot of fun. And then, 8 years later, I noticed it was on steam and picked it up.

Dust is really easy. This is baby's first metroidvania through and through. Don't let that be a deterrent though, this game is still really good. Just moving through the levels is really fun, with all of the movement options they give you. The progression feels really nice, and while the difficulty never really changes, its pretty easy throughout, getting new moves and watching your damage numbers get higher is always a joy. 

Outside of gameplay, the game looks really pretty. Dust is really well animated, as are the effects on all of his moves, making it a spectacle every time you get into a fight. The environments are all gorgeous, and all feel distinct, making it really easy to remember where everything is for backtracking. The enemy designs don't stand out very often, but when you're destroying them in mass, they don't really need to stand out as individuals. The story is interesting enough, and while the writing can be really corny sometimes, its still really charming, and the dynamic the main trio has is really enjoyable.

Overall, it was really cool revisiting a nostalgic game, and while I was kinda disappointed how easy it was, I really enjoyed my time with Dust. If you want to get into metroidvanias but are intimidated by the big guys, this is absolutely worth giving a shot. 8/10

118465848.review: Oh what a wonderful adventure it was. It reminded me of the PSX title from Squaresoft - Brave Fencer Musashi which I also enjoyed greatly. The voice acting in this game should be an example to others how to make believeable and immersive dialogues. The music was up to par as well. Enough reading praise! Just buy it and have fun.

116894965.review:
Finished on TOUGH. 100% completion on map.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

Very gorgeous graphics. Hand painted. Ambience and characters alike. Items and everything feel alive and there is a special shine to it.

[h1] Sound [/h1]

The music fits the ambience, it's a sort of exploration and action osts, so it fits the genre. There is enough variation to not get the player bored. The soundtracks are on par and responsive to the player's actions.

All lines are voice acted and are good which gives a plus.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

While the game gives you a lot of freedom, controls are very responsible and you will learn more moves skillsets, you will end up doing the same combos and things, because there is barely any need to do fancy stuff. At maximum you will need to hold the button to counter very few enemies but that's it. In other words, it's very repeteable. If you love hack & slash games you will not mind it too much. And some enemy designs are very annoying, like you have to keep doing the same specific thing a lot to kill them (it doesn't feel like a challenge, but a chore), specially because they keep ressurrecting indefinitely. The final boss battle repeats the same annoyance I said before, but since it's the final one, it's passable.

The shops do the basic function of selling things, but they aren't what I would expect of a shop. You would expect new things on shop, like a rare new thing, a certain ingredient, but they sell all the same items, and they resell what you sold. You will be crafting your own gear a lot more. You also cannot sell blueprints for some reason. Think of a shop as a supply of health items/materials. Which kinda is not needed that much because...

The game is EASY. I played on TOUGH because a lot of people were saying there was barely any challenge. And on TOUGH, you can die easily, so I'd say TOUGH is the way to go, you at least need to mind your actions a little more.

[h1] Story [/h1]

Story is allright. It's the cliche of a guy who wakes up and don't remember anything and is in a conflict between evil and good to find about himself. You get barely any choices though. There is one certain quest where you can choose what happens but it's minor. The ending is also... nothing unexpected.

Characters/NPC personalities are very good and distinct. You will feel as they are very different from each other. It's not those games where all of them are generic and you don't care at all.

[h1] Bugs / Troubleshooting [/h1]

This game is quite old, but it ran smoothly to me.

I didn't notice any bugs, although, you CAN keep attacking to reach higher places that you shouldn't yet. I don't know if it's intended, but it doesn't break anything aswell, so I guess it's okay.

[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]

7.5 / 10

Gameplay, while responsible and action directed, is repeteable. Some design choices are questionable/annoying like shops/few monster battles, but everything else is good or great. I recommend it, but wait for a good promotion as there is frequently one.

116459910.review:
One of my favorite games of all time. Far from without flaw, but a fantastic experience that anyone with eyes and ears should at least consider. 

It goes without saying that this game is gorgeous; I don't think anyone in their right mind is arguing otherwise. The artstyle, while obviously being a bit 2010 furaffinity-ish, is extremely well executed. Not to mention the game has 2D animated cutscenes?? That's rare in games to begin with, let alone independently developed ones. While they can be a bit stiff and are quite low-framerate, you have to commend the effort put in to have such spectacle. 

The in-game animation doesn't disappoint either; all of Dust's animations are animated by hand, with his sword, Arah, being pre-rendered 3D animation. That said, Arah doesn't stick out very much, and the animations as a whole look very natural. Background characters and enemies are obviously animated on a 2D skeleton rig to save some time, but they also don't tend to stick out too much. Plus, you're gonna be focused on Dust himself most of the time, anyway. 

I've seen people complain about the voice acting, especially Dust for sounding like too much of an edgelord. While I can see where this comes from, it's never bothered me. The voice acting sounds very natural to me, the amateurish nature of it frankly only adds to the game, and Dust has more than enough character in not just his performance but also in his writing that I don't see the problem. Fidget I could imagine getting on people's nerves since she's quite high-pitch and can get loud, but these scenes are rare and usually just for comedic effect (e.g. "No, no! Mash the buttons! DO SOMETHING!!"). Plus, Fidget is an adorable companion that I love having by my side at all times. I think she really only ever improves scenes she's in.

Speaking of, the game's story and writing. I love it. Every character is a joy to hear from, and none of them ever feel too one-dimensional. Even the villain, a cold-hearted genocidal army general, is given at least a hint of humanity, though never enough where it feels like you're supposed to sympathize with him. He's still obviously a terrible person. And without getting into spoilers, the ending, while a bit sudden in my opinion, is very well done. Well-animated, well-written, emotional, thematic...how can you go wrong? 

The theming of the game is also one of its stronger points. Its themes mostly consist of the nature of power and sympathy, and how the two co-exist, with subthemes of inevitabilities. I'm no literary analyzer, so I'd recommend watching [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LMzkCNpIO8Y]this video[/url] for a better literary analysis (spoilers though, be careful!), but in my personal opinion, I think the game executes exploring these themes fantastically, and they add another layer of enjoyment to what is already a fantastic experience. 

Now for the gameplay, and this is where the game sadly draws a lot of ire. In my opinion, while it's serviceable, it's nothing special. This is very much so a game you play for the story, with the gameplay being there to keep you entertained in the time between story events. If you came here for a gameplay-oriented experience without an emphasis on story, temper your expectations. That said, the gameplay is far from BAD, it's just fairly run-of-the-mill beat-'em-up stuff. Well executed, but especially with the game's world being so fantastic, it can be a bit disappointing if you don't know what you're in for. 

And for my final part we have technical issues. This game is fairly bug-free, and I've yet to experience a crash. However, sadly the game syncs graphical data to the cloud. This can be problematic if you have a second PC or, like me, have a Steam Deck, as not having the correct graphic settings results in a black screen until you delete the settings or navigate the menu - blindly - to change them. Not fun. Not fun at all. I hope this'll be fixed in the future, but I wouldn't hold my breath. The game is 10 years old after all, and basically all updates have ceased. That said the Linux port of the game is fantastic and basically the exact same as the Windows version, no problems on that front. The game even has cloud saves between OSs properly configured unlike SOME games *cough cough metro series cough cough postal 2*

All and all, play this game. The game isn't too expensive for what you get, and there's no shame in waiting for a sale if you think it is. I am so glad I found this game, and I cannot sing its praises high enough.

116120522.review:
If you enjoy playing Sonic '06 you will enjoy playing this; a buggy mess that'l have you falling through the map and laughing at the terrible AI. Wondering "who is this character and why do I care about them". Save points that randomly decide whether they work or not. interacting with objects you walked away from and being unable to interact with objects you are next to. Some enemies require you to time an attack to 'parry' their attack in order to kill them, good luck doing this when they refuse to attack you and you need to exploit the code for them to decide to attack. Some areas are dark, and thus you need a light source to see the places to parkour to; sure would be a shame if the lights didn't work because the screen will not update a change in light sources so you are forced to wait for the game to work. Enemies have no risk, even bosses; it is akin to Dynasty Warriors with how little the enemies matter. 

The only saving grace for this game is the charm, characters(mostly fidget) call out things that only the player would question and it teases at the design of games as a whole. Other than that, this game is a waste of money and time.

116117915.review: My favorite game, so you can consider me heavily biased. The art style is great, the animations are smooth, the characters are cute. The voice acting is great and the sounds and music are fitting and nice. Upgrades are given at good times and are fun to use. overall game progression is smooth. The gameplay is fun, a good mix of platforming and combat. Speaking of, the combo system is very fun and simple to get decent at. 116010654.review: This is one of my favorite games of all time, if not my favorite. I adore everything about this game. I almost feel like reviewing it won't do it justice. The voice acting is amazing, it is such a wonderful cast of voice actors they chose. All of the animations are fluid and gorgeous, with the cutscenes being particularly well-animated. Which makes sense since the developer started as an animator! The score is lovely and dramatic, I still listen to it every now and then. I love the drama as well as the sarcastic humor, and the gameplay is great (honestly the combat system is so much fun, I could hack and slash forever). There is a perfect balance between slice-of-life and plot-driven storytelling, with the pacing being particularly well done to me. The twists are so well done as well (foreshadowing and everything). I like that it gives you subtle and not-so-subtle hints, but it never fully clicks until the twists are revealed. It also has some bonus content for the player, as there are optional challenges to test your abilities (achievements, treasure collecting, difficulty levels, and battle arenas). I adore the ending, it's so amazing. I love this game so much, and this is the first game that got me into games (specifically the indie scene). Even after years I still enjoy this game and would get new pieces of foreshadowing I didn't notice before. Everyone who worked on this game should be proud of themselves. I could sing this game's praises forever, but it really is a game you should experience for yourself. Don't let the detractors drive you away from this game, I consider it to be a wonderful game that is best played blind. Please just try it for yourself.

115239472.review:
Strawberry Cheesecake French Toast

Ingredients:

4 Slices Bread
4 Eggs
1 Tablespoon Vanilla
1 Cup Milk
1 Tablespoon Cinnamon
4 oz. Warm Cream Cheese
2 Tablespoons Vanilla Extract
2 Tablespoons Lemon Juice
¾ Cup Heavy Cream
1 ½ Cups Strawberry, Diced, Divided
⅓ Cup Sugar
Confectioners Sugar
Maple Syrup

Preparation:

1.Whisk eggs, cinnamon, vanilla and milk together in medium-large bowl to create egg wash.

2. In medium bowl mix cream cheese, vanilla, sugar, lemon juice and heavy cream (optional).

3. Take 2 slices of bread and spread mixture on both.

4. Press sliced strawberries on both slices & press together.

5. Dunk in egg wash.

6. Melt butter in a skillet on medium-low heat and cook bread for 2-3 minutes or until crumbs are crispy and bread is more solid.

7. Stack and garnish with strawberries and confectioners sugar. Add maple syrup to preference.

The first thing you see when you start it up is an E10 rating. That is so weird. At first it seems lighthearted, but the game gets weirdly dark. Not crazy dark, but definitely into territory I wasn't thinking about when I was 10.

It's very good. Most of the story is alright, although there is a point in the middle that shouldn't have gotten to me, but turned into this gut punch. I should have seen it coming, but it kinda got to me.

But bloody hell it's such a difficulty spike and I'm not sure why. This game, on this difficulty, is easily 10 hours long. The final battle doesn't need to be [spoiler]4 STAGES LONG!!!! 113108008.review:
It's an amazing port of an equally amazing Xbox 360 arcade game. Dust: An Elysian Tail, firstly, is NOT a furry game I swear. Anthropomorphic animals doesn't always mean furries, please get lost if you're about to throw that stuff this way.

The combat is very good (very fast-paced too, but not in the bad way!); being an action-adventure experience, it certainly does the job well. It's not too easy, and it's also not extremely hard. The controls are easy to learn and so are the mechanics.

The voice acting is a 10/10, the person who played Dust you can tell really had fun doing the character, and while Fidget is kind of annoying, I think that's actually the point. None of that will prevent me from keeping that spare Fidget doll. [i]Forever.[/i] :)

The art design and environments of this game are astonishingly beautiful, the soundtrack is truly incredible and that alone already makes this such a masterpiece of a game. The artstyle works very well with the environment and the combat animations fit so well with the rest of the game.

The story is also something to behold, this is Dust putting the pieces of the puzzle of his past together, all concluded in a great altercation with the final boss, which I would prefer not to spoil. I'd highly recommend getting this game even just for the story alone!

The cutscenes are amazing, and especially near the end are absolutely incredible. I honestly have nothing but good things to say about this game, it really is that good.

I rate it a 9/10, because if it were a 10/10, I would be lying as no game is perfect. But I think, this game is about as close as it gets if you're looking for a relatively short playtime-length in a game that is essentially as close as you can get to a masterpiece of a fully playable visual novel.

Oh yeah, and the 4th wall breaks are just hilarious. This game is excellent!

110795203.review:
SUMMARY (if you don't want to read the whole thing):

A game with stunning soundtrack and beautiful art. You get used to things that might be annoying at fitst (character design, voice acting) and it's not long enough for the imperfect stuff to become boring (combat, RPG elements). For me personally, audiovisuals, worldbuilding, story and character can definitely justify blander gameplay so if you feel the same, give it a try.

First of all is the absolute best aspect of the game - art an music. Now the character design might be a little off-putting to some people (because furries) but there is no inappropriate stuff and I got used to it pretty quickly. But the world and especially the parallax background is so beautiful! I especially loved the peak of Archer Pass, where there is a giant LOTR-like statue in the background that slowly reveals itself and when you get to the top, an NPC tells you the story of the place... it took my breath. My other favourite areas were the caverns and the mounintains - the levels are just so beautiful.

And man the music! Writing about it doesn't do it justice! I'm definitely going to listen to the soundtrack even now when I finished playing the game. But even though the songs are beautiful on their own, they work really well with the levels they play in. In connection with the visual style it draw me in so heavily, I can only compare it to playing Ori, no other 2D game got me so immersed in the world as these ones.

The combat is hack'n'slash that is not too technical. You get a few combos and techniques at your disposal but it's up to you how creatively you use them, you can basically just spam attack or Dust Storm with magic again and again. It gets repetitive but I wouldn't say boring. And some of the combos look really cool and make you feel cool if executed properly, even if you could win anyway without them. So it's more up to you to keep the combat fresh. I didn't get bored but I think if the game was any longer, I would.

It has some platforming which I really like and miss in some modern MVs even though it's not too technical either. Each level is pretty linear but is also filled with secrets so it makes sense to return once you get new abilites. What I really like is, that you can access some secrets even before you get the intended ability, by some clever play and using a technique you have from the start of the game! I won't say more but it's in a similar vein as nail pogo in HK to get over spikes.

It is an RPG, it has drops, gear and crafting but I kinda liked it. It's not too overwhelming and there aren't that many recipes. I think this is done much better than in Bloodstained: ROTN, where I was really overwhelmed by it. And can also buy most of the materials so you have a choice to either go grinding for the materials, or sell other stuff and buy them for a worse price.

Characters. At first, Dust seemed like an edgy OC with an UwU companion (which they kinda are) but after a few hours, they really grew on me. Even Fidget which annoyed me at first, had me laughing later in the game. And later in the game, I really started to love the voice acting, almost each character was voiced by a different person, they use different accents and in the cutscenes, they really put emotions in.

The story is nothing too special - you don't know who you are, you go on a mission to find out, basically saving the land on the way. But I quite liked the take on Dust's identity. I also like the world bulding. It doesn't have too heavy of a lore like or details but the small pieces are very interesting. Small bits of history, culture and visual details really add to the experience. Again, Archer's Pass was my favourite, I really felt like I was there.

It took me 24 hours to 117% with most achievements on Tough and I say it's the perfect length for a game like that. I'm going to probably forget some stuff but I'm definitely coming back to this game some they. If not just for the soundtrack and art.

VERDICT:
I've always been aware of this game but never had the interest to play it.... until now, it's another game that I wished I played when I was a lot younger because the story would have stuck with me all the way to adulthood. The game is clearly dated just from the gameplay/combat but the story line is top notch and is undoubtedly the main reason why the game was so popular and remembered to this day.

What's more remarkable is this game was designed by one man alone, going by the name of Dodrill, he was only aided for the soundtracks and voice acting. Well done to you Dodrill!
Total Score = 93/100.

SIMILAR GAME LIKE THIS? / REVIEWER PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE:
Hollow Knight, Dead Cells, Ori and the Will of Wisps.

GAMEPLAY:
Dust takes place in a world populated by anthropomorphic creatures, where the main character, Dust, comes upon a sentient sword, the Blade of Ahrah, and its guardian Fidget. Without memories of his past, Dust follows Fidget's advice and aids the population of the world against forces led by General Gaius. The game is an action-adventure game with Metroidvania-style exploration, requiring the player to gain power-ups to allow Dust to reach new areas. Combat is based on brawler-like mechanics, where Dust can use a combination of swordplay and magic from Fidget to defeat enemies.

■■■■■■■■■□ 9 / 10
Shocked that this hasn't been turned into a series/movie.

110598712.review:
This is a great metroidvania-style adventure game. The story is well paced and went in a direction I wasn't really expecting, in a couple of places. The dialogue and character interactions, especially between Dust and Fidget, are good at keeping the tone relatively light-hearted even as the story gets darker. The visual art style of the world is consistently beautiful, and all the conversations are fully voiced, with unexpectedly good voice acting.

In terms of gameplay, the fighting style provides enough variation to be interesting without being particularly complex to master. A variety of sidequests and challenges help flesh out the world while ensuring that there's enough to do without felling obstructed. While I never felt the need to deliberately try to farm experience or money, the game somehow manages the rare feat of making money matter even to the very end. I did encounter a few technical glitches, such as conversations refusing to advance if I tried to rush through them. (This matters more at higher difficulty settings, because every major boss has an extended dialogue immediately prior to the combat.)

Overall, an extremely well-done and enjoyable experience. 9.5/10

Otro de los juegos que llevaba tiempo cogiendo “polvo” en mi librería era este Dust. Tras la reciente experiencia con el anterior metroidvania quería probar algo parecido que aparentemente parece de mayor calidad y disponía de muy buena calificación por los usuarios de Steam, así que me decidí a jugarlo por fin.
La verdad que este Dust me ha recordado más a un Ori que a un Castlevania o Metroid, salvando las distancias, desde luego. El juego a priori te entra por el ojo, en sus visuales y trailers parece muy bello con diseños muy bonitos. Una vez que lo empiezas y llevas un rato jugando te das cuenta que el juego no es tan fino ni tan hermoso como de un primer vistazo, al menos para mí. Los diseños de los personajes principales no están mal, pero tanto los secundarios como los de los enemigos dejan mucho que desear. Tiene problemas con resolución de los sprites en los personajes cuando dialogan, lo cual echa un poco para atrás. Por otro lado el juego cuenta con doblaje recurrente, algo poco común en estos juegos, el cual está bastante bien, la verdad. A nivel jugable ha sido un puro machacar el botón de ataque. El juego cuenta con un par de combos, pero para nada necesarios. Los enemigos no tienen patrones, casi ni atacan. Y los jefes finales son piñata total, sin apenas dificultad, ni siquiera el jefe final. La historia es mínimamente interesante, sobre todo por el doblaje, que hace que le prestes atención, pero nada del otro mundo.
Realmente esperaba más de este juego con tan buena valoración. Supongo que el paso del tiempo lo ha castigado y lo que ofrece me sabe a poco. Aun así he jugado bastantes juegos del género mucho más antiguos y limitados y me han divertido mucho más. Pero creo que entretiene bien para acabarlo sin tener mal sabor de boca.

108533938.review:
Two years ago, I wrote a list of "my top 10 games released between 2010 and 2019."  Dust: An Elysian Tail was #7.  Here's the review I wrote for it after I finished playing it near the end of 2019



I've known of the game "Dust: An Elysian Tail" for a long time, but it wasn't until a few months ago that I owned a computer that could reliably play it; my last one could but it sounded like my fans were getting ready for takeoff the whole time so I didn't want to risk it.  So, to sort of inaugurate this new computer, I started playing Dust a few months ago, following my usual habit of only playing so much a day to make it last as long as I could.  Until I beat it once through; then I played it all the time.

It didn't take long for me to decide that this was definitely a game I wanted to get as much satisfaction out of as possible.  I like action games and RPGs and I love Metroidvanias, so a combination of the two with some RPG elements was right up my alley...and yes, it helps that it's full of furries, in my case ^_^ (nothing wrong with knowing what pleases you, and when something appeals to that, so much the better...and even if that were not so, Fidget is <3).  About 49 hours of playtime later, I'm satisfied, and want to share my thoughts on the game and why I recommend it.

I'll start with what might be the game's best feature: The presentation.  This game is PRETTY.  The screenshots from whatever store you buy it from don't lie, it's almost like playing a cartoon, a great-looking cartoon.  Even better than the visuals is the audio.  The soundtrack, while not especially large, is excellent and several songs have found their way to my iPod, and I generally add only a half dozen tunes a year to that at most.  There were a few points in the game where I just stopped for a little while and admired the area's ambiance.

The story is good too.  While the story's probably not what you're playing the game for, it tells a nice one with likeable characters.  In particular, as noted previously, Fidget is a precious little ball of attitude and fourth wall-breakery.

But, with this being an action RPG, the most important aspect of such a game is the gameplay, especially the combat.  And how is that?  It's fun and fairly easy to both learn and master.  You start the game with pretty much your entire moveset and have plenty of opportunity to experiment with it even in the first areas.  It's certainly cathartic to go hacking and slashing whether or not your enemies are much of a challenge, and even my third and last time through the game, I was still getting thrills out of it, mainly from playing on Hardcore.

Actually, speaking of "fairly easy," that's a fitting segue into the main issue I had with the game, and that's that it's just that: "Fairly easy."  Even my first time fighting them, the bosses were cake; for example, the one time I took damage during the final boss fight wasn't even from the boss.  Reloading a previous save rarely costs you much time or progress.  The presence of almost all secrets is clearly indicated by a symbol on the map or by paths you haven't yet taken, and while that's fairly standard for Metroidvania games (and, indeed, 2D Metroid games), the secrets themselves usually aren't hard to find.  You get the rewards for the challenge areas regardless of how well you did, and while some rewards are definitely better than others based on how soon you can access the challenge areas and how good your gear probably is by then, these areas easy to ace with some practice and patience...plus as far as I know you don't get any reward for acing all of them other than an achievement, which is fine with me, achievements make me feel accomplished.  Playing on Tough, especially if it's not your first time through, didn't feel much harder than Normal; it wasn't until I played on Hardcore that I even got a game over, and that's only because it's a lot easier to get one-shot and consequently not have a chance to heal.

That said, as with many action RPGs, the game is built to accommodate you if you want to challenge yourself and have a little discipline.  You don't [u]have to[/u] equip the best gear or use the best healing items (in fact, you don't have to equip or use either of those things at all) and you don't [u]have to[/u] level up any of your stats when you gain a level.  My last time through the game, I didn't get one of Fidget's power ups until I reached the point in the game where I absolutely had to, just to see if I could.  I'm just saying the default game made me feel overpowered at times, enough so that each time through I put limits on myself to keep it fun.

Then there's the other issue that I heard a lot more about when I was looking up reviews for the game: The length.  This one wasn't so bad for me.  Everyone calls it short, and while getting total completion and every achievement (other than "beat the game on Tough or Hardcore") on my first playthrough only took me about 18 and a half hours...with a modest while of that time being cutscenes, waiting around to heal via item regeneration because I'm a healing item hoarder (you're NOT going to run out of healing items, I'm just one of those people), or just going and hacking up enemies for fun, loot and experience...they were satisfying hours.

As for bugs, there's only one that I ever encountered: Sometimes the minimap doesn't show found treasures as having been "found" until you bring up the full map.

If I were to compare it to one other game, it would definitely be Samurai Legend Musashi on the PS2.  Both are action-adventure RPGs, they have great visual styles, the soundtracks are awesome (I've had some Musashi tunes on my iPods for almost 15 years), the combat is not especially deep but it is still fun, they're generally not very hard, and not everyone has played them.  Dust has better voice acting (Musashi's wasn't bad, Dust's is just better), though, and more Metroidvania elements.  And, in both cases, they left me wanting MORE, though Dust still feels like it has more content than Musashi (definitely for your buck if we're going by a sale price of something like $50 for a PS2 game when they were new).

If I were to give Dust: An Elysian Tail an overall rating?  I'm going to go with...an 8.5 out of 10.  A gem of indie gaming.  There's nothing dusty about this gem.  Just be ready to challenge yourself, because the game kind of won't.

If you own it or are considering owning it, here are a few tips for newbies:
* There's an item that makes getting a 1,000-hit combo a lot easier.
* The combo countdown timer goes something like a second since you last hit an enemy, unless an enemy you hit is still in the air; you don't get extra hits for striking enemies that are out of health, but it will refill your energy meter and keep the combo timer from going down.
* Make notes to yourself of places you can't go or treasures you can't get and why it looks like you can't.  It will make the "Metroidvania" part of backtracking a lot easier.
* The aerial Dust Storm is godly.
* There's one rather obscure secret that you're unlikely to find unless you know Dust's creator is a huge Castlevania fan.

108301587.review:
6.8/10. I remember seeing this in the App Store in 2015/2016-ish (after its release in 2012!!), and I've wondered about it since then whether it was actually worthwhile. These days it's just okay, but if I had played it when I was younger I definitely would have loved it. It's a fun action platformer that's a bit on the short side, and even shorter without the plot, but it makes up for it. Average combat, simple combos, quite a few secrets, and who doesn't love Fidget?

Plays fine, there are like three combos total, so sometimes it feels like all I can do is mash the attack button. I did like the Dust Storm attacks, although they're similarly limited. Basically, your little flying companion can throw ineffective projectiles that don't do much on their own, but if you use the special "spin your sword like a propeller" attack, it amplifies it a ton. Unfortunately, there's only three types that do more or less the same thing, save for different methods (homing projectile, pillar, chain attack) that don't make up for it. It's also best suited for distraction more than anything. Aerial dust storm gives you a ton of upward momentum if you're beneath enemies, which was fun to exploit.

The average enemy is a complete pushover, they never give you much trouble. They're only a problem when they can actively dodge, and that's easy enough to deal with. The bosses are meh, they're not outstanding. They all have a tiny moveset and aren't that imposing overall. The final boss has way too many phases, and kinda comes out of nowhere. It's also very silly to watch him run into position and kneel to wait for you to hit him once so he can go flying dramatically.

I was surprised to see so many little secrets hidden around the world, and they were fun to hunt around for. They weren't amazingly hard to find (at least, everything I found wasn't), and they count towards total completion so you can exceed 100%, which was very satisfying, especially when you reach them when you're not supposed to by launching enemies and flinging yourself at them before you get the ability specifically to do all that on command.

This game is SO Xbox-ey. Like, the sound design is that chimey gem-like Xbox 360 sound, it's so good. Straight out of some puzzle game demo on the Arcade, or an early 10's mobile jewel game. It does have a bit of crust in the art style, though. The anime eyes on Western cartoon look didn't age too well, I don't think. While it did it decently well and avoided some clunkyness, the characters have that "assembled" look to them, like they have separate parts for their head, body, and limbs that just get rotated around instead of full animation (I'm not complaining!).

It is fully voice acted, which was a bit surprising when it easily could have had none, or a weird mix of the two where only main character speak in important cutscenes. Fidget has that cutesy squeaky slightly exaggerated voice that might get on some people's nerves really quick, but probably not as much as Dust. I always wanted to skip the protagonist's lines, right? I don't know how to describe it but it's everything about him, I just don't want to listen to him.

VERY cheesy anime feel to it, a little too much for me, complete with that specific kind of protagonist voice acting that makes me want to skip everything he's saying, the sword that only talks to move the plot along, quests that don't develop anything since they conclude instantly for a character you'll never see again, very unconvincing internal struggle, two-dimensional "villain" that's just a character with a name to be the bad guy, rapidly escalating stakes from seemingly out of nowhere, et cetera etc you get it right?

As for story, it started out kinda boring, but eventually started taking things seriously, maybe a little too seriously, right? Like, that's cool, it's dramatic and profound but. This didn't come from anywhere substantial. At the very least, there weren't any super completely out-there twists, so at least I wasn't totally driven away.

You know those books which you pick up and don't put down until you finish them? That was "Dust: An Elysian Tail" for me. It wasn't eye-searingly difficult, but it wasn't a walk in the park, either. I thought the movement and control-response was very fluid: well put together. The story wasn't particularly deep, but it was enjoyable, and the world was charming. I couldn't put it down.

I worry this game will be overlooked because of the art (oft referred to as "furry" art), but I ask critics to consider this game along the same lines as Disney's "Robin Hood;" animal personification over an interesting story. Much of this game feels like a labor of love and it's a short, enjoyable adventure. I recall appreciating the environments quite a bit (both in game design and artistic rendering). 

At its heart, "Dust: An Elysian Tail" is a well-paced platformer with a clear story.

104807784.review:
Dust is a game I saw my father play the demo for all the way in the Xbox 360 days when I was a little kid, now I'm glad to say that now that I have played it myself that Dust is an amazing game which gets a solid 8/10 for me.

(TL;DR at the bottom)

To start, let me clarify, take all negatives with a grain-no, an entire shaker of salt. The team that made Dust was extremely small, anywhere from one to five people small. So all negatives are understandable and are not held to the same level as those of a major company's. Okay, now, we start.

Dust's artstyle is...a thing. I get you can make bipedal animals and not be a furry but I mean...come on. However if even a guy who's not a big fan of furries like me can look past that to enjoy a genuinely pretty map and well made designs, anyone can. Often though the presentation can be a little hazy. It feels like the game' graphics are blending together and can often make hoard fights hard to work through. But that's rare and aside from when fire or lava is around, it's not bad and can be gotten used to.

Music for Dust is great. While nothing sticks out or is that memorable, it's all well done and super appealing. I don't listen to any of it on its own but it certainly is by no means bad. The music helps set the tone of all the areas really well and makes it fun to explore and get immersed.

The characters are hit, mostly miss. I simply could not get into many of the characters, but the two most important ones, Dust and Fidget, are so fun. Fidget gave me heavy Midna vibes and Dust himself is a perfect mix of an amnesiac edgelord and a goofster punk. And while Ahra, the sword, is also funny here and there and serves as a great straight man and mentor for the two kids, he kinda fell short for me compared to the other two. However compared to the other characters, Dust, Fidget, and Ahrah are Shakespeare. I get it, small team, small game (compared to other metroidvanias), writing can be hard to complete. Hell, I'm a writer and it's hard fitting just five to eight characters into a single book, much less dozens into a 10 or so hour game, so I get it. 'Sides, it's not that big of an issue for me in general. But what is is the quantity.

Often Dust felt overbearing and borderline suffocating with how many characters and by extent sidequests they just throw onto you whenever you get into a new town. Made me simply suffer from overchoice and just not do any sidequests unless I stumbled upon it.

The world is beautiful and full of crap to do. Heck, when I stopped playing, I was nowhere near done. With time trials, combat trials, aforementioned side-quests, and just things to do. Really made it feel lived in and like, well, a world.

The story is serviceable. It's not bad, it's not good. It's there, and it helped carry the game to the end, which is what a story for a non-story focused game should do at the least. Now, that's not a bad thing, but I'm just not interested in the Moonblood wars or the world's story as a whole.

The bosses...look, I hate mincing words. They're bad. I did not like a single boss in this game, yes even contrary to what some YouTubers say, the final boss too was kinda poopy. Which is a shame that the bosses are, since well

I've been mixed but leaning to negative more this review so far, this is when it gets positive and almost single-handedly why I recommend this game. The combat. The combat is simple, yet so SO fun. There's mainly three things you can do, swing your sword like a dingus, have fidget attack, or spin your sword. These all intertwine into this fun dance of combat that flows so well and never becomes tiring (except with the bosses). Heck even the status effects in this game aren't too bad, which is super rare! The game is sheer bliss when you can to fight enemies, with only ONE type being one I kind of dislike, but they stop showing up around chapter 2 or 3 so they're not too bad. The momentum the dust storm gives you especially when around enemies is astounding. Then you combine your dust storm with Fidget's attacks and it just becomes the epitome of controlled mayhem. I love this game's combat.

The voice acting ranges from existent to great. No bad work here. From Gaius' soft but intimidating voice, to damn Xander Mobus as the shopkeep, to Dust being able to both be empty inside, yet still have a hint of child-like glee at petty jokes or pranks. But the best is...Fidget??? Yeah for some reason the squeaky small animal companion cliche is actually my favorite voice work in the game.Sure, she IS squeaky, small, petty, but it's in an endearing way that reminds me of a mix of Vi from Bug Fables and Midna from Twilight Princess, and I love those two characters (With Vi being one of my favorites of all time) so I may be biased but I liked Fidget.

I don't think I properly put into words how much the gameplay carries this game. Even if you ignored the story and just mucked around the world for twenty hours, put down the game, and never played it again, you'd still have had fun. Build crafting, combo practicing, hitless runs, no upgrade runs, time trials, there's a near endless skill ceiling for a damn metroidvania. Feels like a Devil May Cry game mixed with Hollow Knight and I love it. The combat single handedly sells this game, all the other positives are just icing on the cake and the negatives can easily be forgotten once enemies show up and you start seeing red.

(TL;DR) Dust is a game that, while has a lot of flaws due to the small team size, they can be looked past for the legendary and never-tiring gameplay that alone makes the game worth your $15, immersive music, great main cast, and decent world exploration. I may replay this game again some day. 8/10

102417599.review:
Dust is an action-RPG hack-n-slash game with a heavy focus on combat, platforming, and crafting items to improve the titular character, Dust. 

The story comes complete with voice acting for every character, ocassional cutscenes, and a lovely orchestrated score. While I'm not a fan personally of the story and found it at points to be very tedious and drawn out, it can easily be skipped. 

The combat can be very fulfilling and exciting, especially when facing hoards of enemies at once and have to manage your magic, health, and stamina to try and achieve the longest chain possible. However, I did find that once you reached a certain level or even found a rare item drop that increases your attack power, killing enemies gets to be too easy, even on Tough mode. Bosses proved next to no challenge (I only needed 3 tries to get through the final boss at level 30ish), and going back to explore previous areas means defeating enemies is as easy as hitting them once, even enemies that are deemed mini bosses. 

The game has Metroidvania-esque elements but I wouldn't really call it that as the game is fairly linear, even with various side quests sprinkled in. You can go back to find hidden treasures and keys, but they'll most likely just give you an item you already have, money, and some healing items, so it isn't very fruitful going back to look for any secrets, and it doesn't affect the games ending (to my knowledge).

The material system is really there for you to make some quick cash, since a lot of the materials  needed to craft certain items can be easily purchased or found in a couple minutes of combat. I only ever crafted a few items in the game, but more often than not I quickly replaced them with an item from a chest I just happened upon. 

Overall, for one guy doing 90% of the game by himself, this is a very impressive game with lots of fun combat and platforming, but it falls short in story, crafting, and difficulty.

==PROS==

-Great story

-Interesting combat for a platformer
-Completely voice acted game
-Meaningful dialogue
-Decent pace

98418046.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a light-Metroidvania game with a decent story and sense of progression.

The combat system in Dust is simple, fun and responsive. You basically have a light, heavy and ranged attack moves which can be combined to create basic combos.

There is a small element of exploration and back-tracking as you unlock new kinds of movement abilities which open up new sections of the game world. The map works in a similar way to a Metroidvania style game but it is more streamlined and not difficult to navigate through.

Some sections involve platforming above certain death and fortunately the controls here work as expected and are responsive, no accidental jumps towards doom to be found in this one.

Progression in Dust features a simple leveling system. Get kills to gain experience and crafting materials, once a level pops up you can choose to level up a particular statistic. As you play the game you unlock new Blueprints which can be used in combination with the crafting materials to create more powerful items which raise those stats earlier. Killing screens of enemies eventually becomes a breeze with a higher end character which can be fun.

All in all if you enjoy 2D Sidescroller action/rpg hybrid games then I would say Dust is a good time. I would recommend picking it up during a sale.

96970056.review:
This has a lot of positive reviews and I'm not quite sure why.  Maybe I've played too many games/metroidvanias and I'm too picky or whatever, but I found this game to be mind-numbingly boring and grindy.  

In terms of exploration or searching for secrets, there's no point.  You won't find any new items, upgrades, or anything interesting at all.  Instead you'll find more useless keys for more useless chests that give you more useless gold that you've already got so much of that you have nothing to spend it on. That's the only incentive to explore. Once you realize that every chest just gives you more of what you already have (but don't need), and reaching them is some minor jumping puzzle or whatever, you realize there's just no point at all.  Other metroidvanias encourage exploration, this game discourages it.

Admittedly the combat is fun and fluid at first.  The problem is, the levels are so long and basically all the same, with the same variety of enemies over and over and over again, that it gets extremely boring very fast.  There are only so many ways that you can string together combos, and once you figure them all out, there's nothing more to do or learn.  Unfortunately for me this happened about a half hour into the game, so combat and abilities effecting combat were figured out extremely early on.  Eventually it just got tedious and I started skipping enemies, because why do the same thing 100 more times if I don't have to?

Back to exploration.  I like puzzles.  I like games that make me think.  This has none of that.  No puzzles, no figuring anything out besides looking at a basic map and figuring out whether to go up, down, left, or right, and that's basically it.  Turn you brain off, button mash, and enjoy the story.

What about the story then?  Is it good?  Brooding protagonist forgets his memory, starts to do good things for people, slowly finds out that he was actually a bad guy in the past, and you know the rest.  Kind of trope-y.  It's not bad, but I really really really really really really cannot stand the voice actor for Dust (the protagonist).  His lines sound forced and that thing he's doing with his voice is annoying.  You'll know it when you hear it.  He sounds like a teenager who is trying to sound mysterious and tough/alfalfa.  His companion is also a bit much.  

I have some minor gripes with the movement/animations, namely jump height is fixed and there is a weird delay between when you think you've landed, and when you can actually jump again, so every time you land on a platform you have to wait a little bit to jump to the next one. It lead to me falling off things a lot and kinda pissed me off.  Other than that I guess the controls are fine though.

I'd prefer if steam had something in between recommending and not, because I'd pick that, but I really can't recommend this game for someone who wants to play a good metroidvania.  It really isn't a metroidvania in a true sense, it's a linear action platformer where you can backtrack if you want, but with no incentive at all to actually backtrack, no puzzles, nothing but beat em up and a story that you may or may not care about.  I'd give it a 6/10 I guess.

I spent about 19 hours to get through the story and 100% explore each zone. And what a 19 hours.

The character sprites, environment detail, visual effects in general, are just perfect for the setting. The sounds fit the actions, the controls are tight and responsive

The music is suitable without ever being distracting or tiresome. That being said, I can't remember one note of any of it now, and I literally just closed the game after beating it to write this.

I can't believe I waited so many years to try Dust. And now, like everyone else who played it, I want a freaking sequel.

If you're into Metroidvanias, and like smooth and satisfying combat, get it.

96234546.review: Dust: An Elysian Tail is perfection incarnate. I haven't submitted a game review in years but Dust was so magnificent I just can't help it. Not only is it one of the most visually stunning games ever made, but it has some of the most fluid combat of any video game I've played in my 30 years of life. Instead of a ridiculously huge laundry list of combos that other hack n' slash games possess (God of War, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania ect.), it's just a few different button combinations in conjunction with spamming magic projectiles with the help of your furry flying friend Fidget. The entire feel of the combat is deeply satisfying and addicting, and I found myself always experimenting and changing things up from time to time as opposed to just mashing the X button to get by because I forgot all the combos like in those aforementioned games. On top of all that, Dust: An Elysian Tail had one of the most compelling, and downright heartbreaking stories in gaming history. I'm a 30 year old man, and the ending made me cry like a baby, it's also hilarious at times so it's a great mix. Not only is the storyline emotional, it's incredibly well-written and full of lore to flesh out the world and its inhabitants. With TONS of deep and insightful dialogue, unforgettable characters, and plenty of awesome side quests, Dust draws you into its world every bit as much as any AAA BioWare-esque RPG. With loads of loot and treasures and secrets to find, there's simply no reason not to own this masterpiece! Also, Fidget is my new favorite NPC of all time.

95987775.review:
This is my full review, and I'll try to keep spoilers to a minimum.

TLDR: Yes, buy this game if you enjoy indie games, hack and slash games, and games with a brilliant story and soundtrack.

Full Review: I enjoyed the game to it fullest. The "true 100%" is actually 117%, and I try to only write reviews when I fully completed a game, just so I can experience everything. The fact that 95% of this game was made by one guy (Dean Dodrill) is mind blowing. The controls are fluid with the character, and the gameplay is phenomenal for a hack and slash game. The story had me cry multiple times, and it's a shame I will never be able to enjoy this game again as I did the first time. My emotions were a roller coaster, and that's how all games should be. They need to make you bond with the characters, and this game did just that. (And it has a killer soundtrack on top of all of it.)

I am honestly trying to think of any negatives for this game, but the only thing that comes to mind is not enough animated cutscenes. However, only one guy did this, so I cannot blame him for making the cutscenes like a visual novel. That being said, the visual novel cutscenes also had small animations and different poses/emotions for the characters instead of the characters being just a still picture of them. So I can't complain.

As for backtracking, it can be seen a good or bad. If you want the story to progress, you DO NOT need to back track at all. However, if you want some more powerful items/skills/etc for your character, then some backtracking will be required, but you will have new abilities to use when backtracking. So, that being said, you will discover something new when doing so.

With that, I recommend you get this game, and fully complete it. It was such a blast to do, and I plan on doing it again on the hardest difficulty for a challenge.

95716815.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail, while seemingly simple on the surface, is a game of hidden charm and deserves a closer look. Featuring a gorgeous, hand-drawn world, this 2D sidescroller may not innovate in many areas, but what it does do, it tends to do very well.

You play as Dust, an anthropomorphic animal (of some sort) who seems to have a mild case of amnesia. While on his quest to help the characters he encounters, he uncovers more of his past, comes to grip with his true identity and saves the day. While the story is not in itself remarkable, the mechanics of the game behind it are.

The combat, while simplistic at first, develops with light RPG-like elements and you grow more powerful as you progress. The fluidity and responsiveness of the controls and character is perhaps the best of any game I have ever played: if you die, you will know that it was your fault and not down to input or delay (other than your own). The voice acting is on par (perhaps nothing special, but fitting for the setting), characterisation is done well and the beauty of the game world and surroundings deserve a second mention. There is also no problem with settings or the game being demanding: it remained locked at my refresh rate at maximum resolution for the duration of my playthrough.

It is difficult to consider this game as anything other than a labour of love, and as an outstanding example (as well as an exceptional port) of what one person can achieve when they dedicate themselves to something; after playing it is difficult to believe most of the work was done by one person, but also easy to understand why it took years to accomplish. All in all, as a package it is wonderfully done and well worth the price of entrance.

Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys Metroidvania or platforming games.

Played on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any issues.

95579529.review:
This was one of those games that had been sitting in my backlog for some time now, and was something I had heard good things about yet just never got around to. Well, now I have, and I suppose it's time I gave my opinion on it.

The first thing I think needs to be said about this game is how the spirit of its development almost traces back to the infancy of video games -- think the age of bedroom coders where one to four people did all the work on the game. Such is the case with this one -- one guy did all of the programming, artwork, story, and everything except the voice acting and music, really. Had you told me that going in, I would have been skeptical of how good this could be.

Surprisingly, it all comes together quite well. The game blends several genres together in a manner that makes it hard to argue exactly what genre it belongs to, yet it never feels undecided or unfocused. First and foremost, the game is a 2D sidescroller. It is also a hack-and-slash, as the game is heavily focused on combat and trying to find ways to take out hordes of enemies. On top of that, we also get a levelling and inventory management system akin to an RPG, with a little bit of platforming thrown in for good measure and a pinch of Metroidvania (leaning more on the "vania" side of the equation). This amount of genre mixing can easily go wrong in so many ways, yet it somehow manages to make it come together. The combat is very fun and enjoyable to work your way around, and is engaging enough that it never feels repetitive.

The game makes it work even better by sporting an amazing hand-drawn look. Every element of the game appears to have a painted appearance, including the backgrounds, the character models, and all the enemies. It really does feel like a painted scene that came to life. Again, props to the maker of this game for having such a wide array of talents that he managed to weave together.

As far as the story goes, it's not especially original -- a chosen one is on a quest to save his people, and he visits a bunch of different villages who need help along the way. It's pretty much nothing you haven't heard before, but what carries the game isn't so much its story, but its characters, some of whom you may grow attached to and enjoy getting to know. And since even Dust doesn't know who he is when the game starts, it keeps you hooked in wanting to know the answers to that. At several points the game got unexpectedly dark too. All of the dialogue is voice acted as well, and that's all quite well done.

This isn't a particularly challenging game. Once you get a feel for the combat, it isn't long before you start using the same moves over and over again. That said, the combat is deep enough that you still have to be focused when fighting off enemies, so at least it never becomes outright boring. The biggest thing that breaks the game is the special abilities granted to you by Fidget, as they attack pretty much every enemy on screen. You can pretty much carry yourself through the game spamming her attacks.

The game isn't particularly long either -- it's only five chapters, but with the exception of the third which amounts to doing the same thing four times, they're all pretty good and have varied environments. There are also sidequests you can take on if you want to, but they're not mandatory and simply grant you extra experience points.

Dust is overall an alright game. It definitely shines compared to many other indie games, but still isn't anything I'd call must-play. If the art style appeals to you, and you like action games, then I'd say it's worth a play.

95378041.review:
I was quite surprised by how much I enjoyed this game. I had looked at it before I bought it and thought it might be good, but it was better than the reviews and my own initial impressions lead me to believe. The lighthearted banter between the characters is made better by the voice acting, which was cast quite well. The dynamic between the two main characters kept me invested in what was going to happen to them. Their struggle to find out who Dust really is (surprise, surprise, another amnesia character in a video game. I wish they would stop with this troupe already) is interesting and I will admit that I didn't see things turning out the way that they did. It was a pleasant surprise. 

	As far as the visuals, they look vibrant and colorful. Objects and backgrounds merge together in a very natural way so that everything looks as though it belongs, but there is no confusion about what you can interact with.  The music didn't stand out one way or the other for me. If the music isn't going to be noticeably good, I usually prefer it to be like this so it doesn't distract me from the game itself. Speaking of the gameplay, the puzzles aren't too difficult for the most part. There are a few that will take a bit of thought to figure out, but most of it is just exploring. And because of the loot you will want to collect to get access to new pieces of equipment, you will be exploring the world regardless. The equipment is on the basic side and the newest piece is usually the best, but there are some fun things thrown in there to play with too!

	However, the main reason to play this game is easily the fluid and enjoyable combat. Attacking is just plain fun here! I enjoyed the movement from the start and my enjoyment only increased as I got new abilities to make that movement even more dynamic. Id say the combat is something like Castlevania merged with Street Fighter. You have a few basic combos, lots of vertical movement along with different angles to attack your foes from, a small collection of magic attacks, counterattacks, and all of this plays out in a 2.5D world that lends itself to trying new attacks to react to different situations often. 

TL;DR

I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys the metroidvania style of game, fluid and fun combat, anime humour, and entertaining characters!

94683421.review:
Notice for this review: I played this game on its "hard" difficulty, Tough. I decided not to play it on Hardcore because I value my sanity and know where I like my challenge to be.

Like others may have told you, do not be so easily deceived by the game's use of anthropomorphic characters; it uses them in a way that allows some... gruesome concepts to be touched upon without muddling the message with humans in the mix. Also, many other movies and games have used such a foundation for characters and proved to deliver great experiences, so don't judge this game on that alone.

The gameplay is quite nice and is a combination of hack and slash combat and metroidvania progression. You'll be cleaving down hordes of foes with a fair few tricks in their behavior to keep you on your toes, and the environmental hazards like the tried and true spikes can actually hurt quite a lot on higher difficulties, and they're certain death on Hardcore as well. This game makes you feel like a unstoppable menace by the time you're halfway through, where even the toughest enemies in the earlier areas cannot help but deal less than 1% of your health with a single hit. This game can be completed relatively easy, especially if you like to check around every possible direction in an area like I do.

The score is wonderful and definitely fits the varying tones and environments greatly. My favorite environmental track would have to be the one for the [spoiler] Cirromon Caverns [/spoiler], though all the others hold up well. The artstyle is appealing and reminds me of a combination of Western and Anime styles, and a few little details here and there, like the bits when in the world map, are always nice to see. The characters are likable and never feel inherently annoying, and the trinity dynamic of Dust, Fidget, and Ahrah's personalities is charming.

Of all the things this game could be better including, I only have two small things in mind: a bit more enemy variety in some areas—[spoiler] 1 to 2 more enemies that had guarding moves or shields would have been nice to change up combat [/spoiler]—and just some neat idle animations to add more charm to the main trio. But then again, the game is still great to play despite this, and the fact that most of it fell under the effort of one person is truly remarkable.

In short, if you like beating down a bunch of foes with a sword and some magick with some mainline metroidvania progression built in, then this is the game for you. You even get a touching story to go with it.

94336591.review:
[b]A masterpiece cartoon-metroidvania.[/b]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]RATING:[/th]
        [th]🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟 5/5[/th]
[th]PERFECT GAME[/th]
    [/tr]
[/table]


[h1]Context[/h1]
Keep in mind that this game was hand-drawn and mainly developed by one person and has better quality than most triple-A studios have in their games full with bugs and pointless grind that try to sell to you for 50 bucks. Just take a look at how much Unity garbage is being released lately on Steam with the excuse that "it was made by one person"; well, that one person should be doing something else instead of garbage to flood Steam's indie category. This game is the proof that one person is capable of doing most of the hard work to create an excellent game, even if that takes 18 hours a day.


[h1]Atmosphere, Visuals and Music[/h1]
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a must have for everyone who enjoys minimalistic games with beautiful graphics. The hand drawn is exquisite as well as the colors and different map locations. The music fits the game's magic atmosphere perfectly. Voice acting excels too.


[h1]Plot overview (spoilers)[/h1]
You play as Dust, an unknown character that has lost his memory and tries to figure out who is he. Doing so he starts helping people out and he understands that who he was is not that important.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Responsive controls, plenty of upgrades that you can farm and also skills that can help you reach new zones. Where it really shines is at combat flow. You can literally make a combo as long as you want without even getting hit. The most intuitive metroidvania I had the pleasure to play.


[h1]Cons[/h1]
The only "downside" that I can think about is that it is too short, even with all the upgrades, you can complete it with 117% in less than 20 hours at max difficulty.


[h1]To buy or not to buy?[/h1]
Buy it and prepare for 20 hours of fun and unforgettable moments.

And just in case, if the apparently furry thematic is holding you from buying it, ignore all these "furry comments" and reviews, it has nothing to do with that. It's like accusing Walt Disney of drawing furry characters like Goofy or Mickey Mouse. This game is much more than a simple tag based on the characters design.

[b]Dust: An Elysian Tale[/b] is beautifully hand-drawn 2D platformer that captivates with both a gripping story and interesting characters. I won't delve into the specifics of the story as one should experience it themselves, but I can say that it kept me hooked since the very beginning. Apart from the exquisite environments and a likable cast of characters, the game boasts a very well composed soundtrack that blends in with the environments quite beautifully. The platformer aspect of the game is quite enjoyable too, and the various stages of the game house multiple puzzles that make very smart use of the game mechanics. Overall, a [u]recommend[/u] for whoever enjoys delving into "eye-candy" platformers that also have a pretty compelling story-line.

Ashes to ashes, dust to dust...

92420546.review:
A very good game that's actually worthy of the "metroidvania" tag unlike so many others. I got it on sale, but it's absolutely worth full price. Don't let the "furry" anime art style or independent (individual, really) developer put you off. Note that I played this on normal difficulty, with a controller. Casually getting nearly everything in the game took me about 18 hours, not including paused time. I never needed a guide.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Colorful and varied artwork and backgrounds.
+Good animation (game-wise) and decent animation (cutscenes).
+Character artwork and voice acting is well done. Every character is unique.
+Likeable characters, even without a ton of development.
+Proper metroidvania exploration.
+Puzzle, platform and RPG elements.
+Multiple difficulty levels.
+Very optional timed challenge areas.
+Map is helpful for tracking completion.
+Lots of references to other (mostly) indie games.
+Random weather, that's stopped by shelter (attention to detail).
+Enemies can be damaged by one another and environment.
+Family-friendly.
+Stable. No crashes or major glitches.

[h1]YMMV[/h1](spaced for readability)
~Everyone's an anime anthropomorphic animal, but it never gets furry.

~Similarly, one of your companions has an obligatory squeaky anime voice...but she's actually pretty funny.

~Combat is often a button mash, which may get old to some and makes some combos a bit pointless, except for the animations.

~Rather challenging at the start, but facerollingly easy by the end if you're a completionist. Leveling makes a huge difference.

~Some enemy/environmental knockbacks are a bit overkill. You also get knocked back by leveling, which can be a real pain if you're currently platforming.

~Had a bit of trouble getting this game to recognize my controller on startup. Had to plug it back in a few times for some reason.

[h1]The Bad[/h1](spaced for readability)
-Hard to see what items you've just picked up.

-Combo meter hides minimap.

-No way to sell blueprints you don't want, causing clutter.

-Dashing can get buggy if you do it in wind or while attacking.

-Damage input inconsistent, with some mobs and hazards doing enormous damage.

-Needs a way to reset trials if you goof up. A few of them are somewhat unforgiving on time for top rating.

-Majority of the equipment in the game isn't used. The pacing at which you get gear is just weird (in your favor).

-Shame that no sequel or spiritual successor appears to be in the works (even after all this time).

91549245.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a narrative driven game with a focus on story as opposed to challenging gameplay and intriguing mechanics. I'd owned the game for a while and managed to finish my first “casual” run years ago and found that I remembered very little about it with the exception of the visual design, a few locations and the story's twist-ending.

So with some time to kill and on a metroidvania binge I decided I'd run through the game a second time on “tough” difficulty.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a metroidvania, borrowing only the bare-bones elements of the genre such as abilities that are given at certain locations, a levelling system where you're given points to spend on four stats that increase your durability and damage output. There's a crafting system in the form of blueprints that drop form enemies or chests that you can use the make equipment that boost your stats even further or give increase in gold and drop rates.

I really liked the ability to sell materials that you found in your travels, eliminating the grind for them when you wanted to craft stronger equipment. Sure it defeated the purpose of killing enemies for loot, but I think it balanced out with the need for money to buy what you needed.

The game's strong point is definitely its visual design, with amazing animation, background art and level design. Along with a decent soundtrack that had a mixture of ambience for the areas and rocking tunes for the more action-packed areas.

Everything else is where the game falls a just a bit short and barely passes the “okay” mark, never trying to engage the player or allow them to explore and infer at their own leisure. The story is mediocre at best and doesn't try to go out of its way to expand on the world and characters by adding optional narrative fluff. There's only one example of a character that talks about the history of the area they're in and even that's glanced over in two paragraphs.

The characters themselves weren't all that interesting, which wasn't helped by the majority of them having awful voice acting to convey their personality. A few of them were done alright, but I particularly couldn't stand the main character's voice.

To allow some semblance of character development, the game forces you to stop playing to throw a brief cutscene into your face when you pick up a new ability, stumble into a puzzle or come face to face with new enemies. Which is a real shame, because the level design and the various mechanics are perfectly implemented to teach the player on its own merits without the game holding your hand.

What's left then is the combat which doesn't fare much better in engaging the player. Enemies are basically money piñatas with little threat beyond the odd enemy that explode or needs to be parried. They possess a sluggish AI that attacks at set intervals and occasionally jumps behind you, and with little variety in enemies all you did was clear the room and move on to the next. The main hazards are environmental pits, spikes, thorns and lava pools that do a significant amount of damage when you fall into them.

What about exploration then? That's even less of a challenge. Chests and pickups are literally thrust into your face, and the few secret areas that do require some thinking to get to aren't that cryptic. Besides loot and secrets, the game offers optional “challenge trials” to test your platforming or combat skills, and if you attempt to take these on as soon as you find them they might pose a formidable challenge. However once conquered there isn't much else to do with these challenges other than getting a four-star rating.

On balance I enjoyed Dust: An Elysian Tail as a game to pass the time, but its lack of interesting gameplay and mediocre story let it down. All it's got going is its visual design, but I wouldn't recommend playing it solely for that alone.
