90456953.review:
As I play I keep getting baffled that this is mainly a one-man production. The detailed environments, the graphical effects and the combat all feel so alive. The character art is adorable, and while the story feels light-hearted much of the time it is also quite dark, which makes for a punchy contrast. I didn't cry, though. I was just bleeding water from my eyes.

I played this back when it was released first. It didn't sync with me at all. I don't think I had the patience back then. This time around though I couldn't figure out what had annoyed me. Everything feels so polished. Sure, there are annoyances here and there (such as how far you'll fly back if hurt by hazards) but being careful and not getting hurt while dominating the screen with your massive streams of death - which is highly possible - makes those "fails" super rare and, well, fitting. It is clear that you're not supposed to get hurt at all.

The platforming is most of the time not masochistically hard, which I like. The game is not designed to make you angry, but it still has its tricky parts - especially the optional challenges spread around the world.

My only gripe, I think, is that while Fidget will mark rooms you enter containing undiscovered treasure, there seem to be no way of actually finding hidden rooms except stumbling upon them. I have cleared regions on the map without reaching 100% on them and unless I've missed something, finding the hidden rooms there becomes a tedious act of slashing at every wall.

Absolutely great game. And I [i]love[/i] the constantly fourth wall breaking adorableness that is Fidget.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of thousands of 2D retro platformers infesting the Steam marketplace.  This has a Metroid/Castlevania style persistent map and a focus on brawling, and light visual novel elements.  It's also a furries wet dream, with all the creepiness that goes along with it. 

Gameplay is dissatisfying as the hitboxing isn't great, due in some part to the focus on the art design before gameplay.  A lot of work went into the art, and it's not retro pixel, which is to be appluaded.  It is furry art, however, which is creepy.   You get interrupted by badly written dialogue constantly.   The camera could handle being zoomed out a little more, so you can see where you're platforming.

I imagine this was very successful amongst console peasants who are also furries, but this really doesn't feel like a PC game at all.   They're also charging $15 for a console ported platformer, so that's ambitious.  The same money gets you games where they could work out how to do 3D graphics, like Resident Evil 2 or Metro Exodus for less when on sale, it's just impossible to recommend this.

89129437.review:
TL;DR

Gameplay: 9/10
Story & Characters: 10/10
Writing & Dialogue: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10
Music & Sound Design: 10/10
Length: 8/10
Replayability: 7/10
A game that, to this day, proves the true potential of any one person if they simply strive for it: Near Perfection/10

-REVIEW-

So here it is, my twenty-fifth review. Twenty-five…yeah, sounds like a special number to me, so let’s review a game that is near and dear to my heart, even after so many years have passed since its release.

Even with all the dozens of titles I’ve enjoyed, even with all the positive accolades I’ve given thus far, not a singe game I’ve talked about has simply owned my heart like this one. Dust isn’t just a game. It’s a freaking EXPERIENCE. As far as I’m concerned, if you haven’t played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to buy this small slice of epic greatness and see for yourself just what a labor of love looks like.

I don’t normally gush like this to start with, but there’s so many good things to say.

Let’s start with the story, as I usually do. In this…tail? Really? Anyway, this tale sees you as Dust, the titular hero that appears out of nowhere one day and winds up going on an adventure with Fidget, a nimbat, and a sword that can talk. Dust’s main hook is that he is an amnesiac. Uh-oh, red flag right? Well, as it turns out, this amnesiac story is actually one of the good ones, as it doesn’t try to beat you over the head with the whole amnesia thing. Instead, Dust the hero is simply that: a hero that, having recently come into the world, decides to make the most of his time by helping out the locals, and boy, does he have some helping out to do! The big issue in these parts is that a genocidal authority figure known as Gaius is trying to exterminate a group of beings known as moonbloods. Along the way, Dust will eventually come to know his true identity, something I won’t spoil here. All I will say is that the story is magnificently told, with good writing and enjoyable characters all around. Even the folks that dole out side quests are fun to talk to. The mysterious merchant you run into here and there has to be my favorite, just because of how, well, mysterious he is and the curiosity he drums up. Ultimately, this game has all sorts of wonderful moments in the story that can really evoke some emotion. Pro tip: bring some kleenex for the ending.

In terms of gameplay, Dust shines further still. It’s basically a metroidvania filled with places to explore, quests to fulfill, and plenty of enemies to slaughter. That’s all well and good, but the combat really makes it all worthwhile. The main gimmick behind Dust’s fighting style is the dust storm, a maneuver that’s essentially “Dust the sword-wielding tornado runs over everything.” You can even combine it with various magic abilities to pretty much screen-clear most areas. It’s fun to use, but there was a clever sort of balancing effect added in. Simply put, if you use dust storm too long, you’ll take damage. Alternatively, there’s also various button combos that can be utilized for more conventional fighting. It all sounds simple, and yet it never gets boring!

In addition, the combat not only IS good, but also LOOKS incredible. Wait, scratch that. The whole GAME looks incredible! It’s amazing to me how even 2D games can be given such a visually captivating appearance, but Humble Hearts pulled it off. The environments are pure eye candy, and each unique biome stands out in so many ways. Plus, the animated character sprites have so much detail to them, and add to the world’s colorful vibes. Between that and the spell effects from the dust storm attacks, your eyeballs will be in for a treat.

Then there’s the sound design, which I believe was the only part the game’s creator had any help with. The official soundtrack has thirty seven pieces of music, and every last one of them is pure joy to listen to. Each bit of music adds to every area, with moods ranging from peaceful and mysterious to outright thrilling and suspenseful. It certainly doesn’t hurt that the various sounds effects, especially from combat, add that extra bit of oomph to the excitement. Finally, the voice acting…every last bit of it is very well done; not a single character’s voice feels out of place, the vocals themselves make the game that much more memorable.

All that said, I do admittedly have a couple problems with the game(Gasp! Problems?!). For one, the boss battles are a joke. Well, most of them. The last few phases against the final boss are actually challenging, but the others just seem to be no match for the dust storm attack. That isn’t to say they aren’t fun in their own way, but it’d been nice if the bosses as a whole could put up a bigger fight. The other issue is the crafting system. Now, the crafting itself is not an issue; being able to make gear in this game, heck, in any game like this, is fun. My issue is the fact that, at least from my experience, you really don’t need to craft. The game gives you plenty of items to help you through the game, healing and otherwise. In fact, there is an item(can’t remember the exact name) that auto-revives you after you lose all your health. I’m sure some people out there will find the crafting thing fun, it just wasn’t something I found really necessary.

So there you have it, a game that I loved so much, that during my short stints on youtube and vidme, I used Dust as my avatar! This game right here is, as I said, a labor of love; you can see all of the work, care and creativity that went into this project, and it shows in just how many accolades it has received. My hats off to Humble Hearts for this amazing game, and one of the handful of titles that shows how kickstarter should be used.

Now hurry up and make a sequel. Thanks for reading!

88271069.review:
6/10 Not worth the price, buy at a discount. Play if you're in need of a Metroidvania, but know that there's better out there.

Art: 4/10 the character aren't very pleasing, nor are they animated well. I was expecting more of a Korean vibe since it has Korean in it's name, but honestly, besides a few houses, it's very similar to the typical Western fantasy.
Plot: 2/10 Wouldn't know because I skipped the plot. All of their dialogue felt very intrusive, redundant, and unnecessarily long. They felt the need to comment on the most obvious things and make cut scenes where there need not be. From the start I was not interested in the plot. 
Movement: It tries to be a platformer. It's not great at it. The pov camera is too zoomed in so you can never tell where you're jumping more than one platform at a time, and due to the way movement works, it's hard to tell if some area's are reachable if you tried harder or if you're jumping towards an impossible task. You do sort of have a flying technique but it's hard to manipulate, though it can be pretty fun. But outside of that skill you move very slowly, making backtracking for treasure gathering a chore. 
Combat: Really the only best part of this game. It's fast and you throw characters around the screen a lot so you feel powerful, though near the end levels the screen gets so chaotic you're just button mashing hoping to hit something. Your defense is generally so low that you are incapable of tanking hits, meaning the best way to fight is to stun lock enemies mid-air, which gets boring fast.

85532555.review:
This is actually a neutral review - but Steam doesn't allow those, so here you go.

I didn't hate Dust. The game has nice art style and it was definitely a labor of love for a single person to make.

However... it's extremely simplistic in its mechanics. Exploration is not at all rewarding. Combat consists of mashing a key most of the time. The storyline is clichéd, the furry aspect rather creepy, and the constant chatter of this character or that one got old about five minutes in. To top that off, several aspects of gameplay design feel odd and half-baked, like the weird teleport system.

I played it to completion, because even with those things it isn't a bad game. It's fun, if you're looking for something extremely simplistic. For children [strike]and sexual perverts[/strike] the art style and storyline might be quite attractive.

Maybe if I had played this in 2013 when it released I would've liked it more. But as is, I played this in 2020 - and after having played through Hollow Knight, Ori and the Blind Forest, and Blasphemous. Let's just say all three of those games far outdo this one, though then again all three of them are also much newer.

Once again, not a bad game. But if you haven't played any of the ones I mention above, they're far superior products to this one. Go for those.

The only downside is the story, first I have to say I love the characters, and this is why the story is disappointing because It did not take advantage of deeper character development. You can not see how the "heroine" made a bond with the main character because after chapter 3 everything feels so rushed that the ending feels so anticlimactic IMHO.

Also, the game has a few to zero replayability value, exploring the map for secrets won't do much for your character skills or the story, no additional clues about the rest of the npcs, no alternative or special scenes for the ending.

Dust and Elysian Tail is a good game but it could have been a masterpiece with more time or more money.
PS: I love Haley.

Simplistic combat, poor soundtrack, 0 depth, boring story.
This game is what you would want if you're heavily invested into anime or furries and you don't want any kind of challenge in your games.

The whole combat in this game is simply mashing buttons and jumping around aimlessly. 
The art-style is okay for what it is, but I personally can't stand it.

I'd recommend you steer away from this game if you like rogue-lite games or anything that remotely poses a challenge. It will not deliver.
If you're in for the cruise and you just want some whatever anime story and cutesy, screechy voices, you're in for a treat. I've yet to hear any sound more obnoxious than that fairy helper. There's plenty of cliche stuff going on and the main character is as edgy as a freshly sharpened knife.

As for myself, this isn't my kind of game at all. I bought it simply because people recommended it as being similar to hollow knight, but I was quickly disappointed in everything it has to offer.

84271327.review:
Flawed, needs sequel, but truly wonderful.
It appeared at a time when platforming action games were mostly on handheld devices, yet somehow its creators made a wonderful product that reminds me of my youth watching Disney cartoons in the morning. Tailspin and Ducktales were quite something, and I heard that the man behind this project originally wanted to make a cartoon, but could not. 

I, for one, wish to see more.

That being said, the game has good combat, good platforming, an okay soundtrack, but the one thing that sells it is the characters and their stories. Summarized, these seem all too ordinary and not at all special, but presentation helped it convey so well that it captivated me. If I simply explain the story you might think "okay, well that is not so great", but it strikes a meaningful resonance with my early years. I cannot deny that I mourn the passing of a time when you could wake up and see a good fairy tale on the television.

84264732.review:
If this game had come out in more recent years, I'm sure this would be held up as some shining success of Early Access. But it never was an Early Access game. It is, however, a niche game that is a labour of love from one guy who spent several years making this, and boy, was it time well spent!

You'll instantly be struck with the gorgeous characters and animation and not for the first time wonder "one guy did all this?" But it's more than this.

The game is essentially a metroidvania style in the lightest sense of the word. It's 2D, and the combat is especially good with fabulous fluid animations, and you have a range of areas you'll need to progress through, and a few you may have to revisit. The story is quite lovely and thoroughly heartwarming and entertaining - and I usually ignore stories in a lot of games. It takes a lot to impress me on this point. You start off in the world with amnesia, and immediately come across an adorable sidekick - Fidget, a flying, squirrely, cat, fox type ... thing. Their interplay is again lovely to experience, truly endearing stuff. As you come across other characters, you will talk to them not just for exposition's sake, but the occasional sidequest too. As it's not a linear game, these side quests can largely be handled as and when you want, or ignored. As there is a basic levelling system (which really just helps keep you alive longer), you can either get rewarded with better equipment or some item involved in rudimentary crafting (for better equipment). Killing certain enemies drops particular items, of course.

The game probably wraps up in about 5 hours (or perhaps more if you aren't rushing through it), and it's absolutely perfect length. It never outstays it's welcome and it wraps things up nicely. Note that I don't have much playtime on here, as I've played it thoroughly on 360, and PS4. 

AS for the downsides, frankly I can't think of any. It really is a perfectly polished game.

So if you're perhaps wading through the massive choice of retro 2D sidescrollers/platformers/whatever, and don't know what to get, then this should absolutely be top of your list. It's a true testament to how good a labour of love can be, and how when given time to work, you can make masterpieces without having to cut stuff.

This game is so much of a perfect game, that it should be in a list of games that EVERY Steam user must own.

84058716.review:
I think the basic game mechanics, the combat and abilities, are fun.  But there are a lot of negatives when it comes to level design and story.  There's just so much backtracking in this game.  If you find a chest, you might not be able to open because you also have to find a key which is also hidden around the world.  So whenever you find a key or two then you have to go back and refind the chests you couldn't pick up at the time.  Also many of the quests involve you talking to the character you received the quest from again, well it's pretty tedious to walk through the quite large town area looking for the character again.  Everything is just repeated.

Also, playing on normal difficulty the combat is a bit simple, so I'd recommend you start on a harder one.  On this note, I question the experience point system.  There's an area near the beginning of the game where you have to do this flying attack thing to get a chest far above the level, it is difficult to pull off and if you empty the air of enemies you must leave the screen and try again.  Well, in a normal platforming game without experience points, trying the same thing over until you get it is fine, but here while I was trying and failing I probably gained half a dozen levels and each level gives you an enormous stats boost.  Now, I'm definitely overpowered for the nearby monsters.  Why have an experience point system at all in a game like this?  Just make the monsters for the area as tough as you think is appropriate for the player's skill level.

82686214.review:
I'm not sure, but... This game might have turned me into a furry?
Why is it so enjoyable... And yet so simple... And yet so damn charming?! I don't understand.
I only know this made me feel... Feelings for... (possibly Korean?) Humanoid rabbit-foxes wielding swords? (Is that what he is?!)
I don't know and I don't even care. Just give me more...

More seriously, though, while of course it isn't perfect, this game does have an irresistible charm. It's the kind of game that, writing this review some time after my second playthrough, has me wonder why the heck did I even enjoy it so much. It's simple, basic even, some secondary characters' designs look rough, it has a rushed third act... But I loved it.

There is something quite nostalgic about it-- so much of it being a homage to older classics-- but still manages to retain some freshness.
You recognise the archetypes (in the characters, in the aesthetics of the world, in the story), but at the same time all these elements manage to impose their own identity, thus feeling like their own thing rather than some pretty nostalgic mash.  There's something about it that definitely feels like a love letter to certain narratives, but it's somehow hard to be bothered by it. 

While the gameplay is quite basic, this makes for a very nice, relaxing experience. Movement is fluid. The animation is incredible. You don't have many moves but you'll still look insanely badass.  The music is fantastic. The story is surprisingly decent, even touching sometimes, and it has some quite memorable lines that don't even feel like petty one-liners (HOW?)
The voice acting might sound a bit off occasionally, but the main characters do a pretty good job, never breaking the mood with odd deliveries. They share a good chemistry, and they are often genuinely humorous, but also capable of making you feel for them when they are going through some turmoil. 
While some bits of animation and of secondary characters designs do look a bit off, it is generally pretty damn good.
Until you realise they're all the work of one guy... So, yeah, fucking stellar!

Some people have raised criticisms against the lack of difficulty and redundancy of the main game mechanic of smashing enemies to no end.
It is true that the game is focused more on killing enemies than on tough platforming bits, so if that's not your thing you might be better off with something else, but the range of difficulties shouldn't scare anyone away.
The game doesn't force you to use a strategy, but that doesn't mean you can't try to come up with alternative ways of playing. Avoid getting health items or something. Find your own way of playing.

I played the first time on tough mode, and the second one on hardcore. I thought tough mode was a pretty good way to experience some tension while also enjoying the moment.
Hardcore can be a bit of a nuisance, as you're easily one-shotted or severly hurt. There also isn't much time to experience the way bosses fight and their cool moves if you don't want to die, but then again it is hardcore. It's not as hardcore as other games' more punishing mechanics, but I personally didn't find it to be an issue.

My one issue/regret might be that there isn't more. Something about it made me feel like this was the kind of game that would bring you on a long-ass journey, but maybe that's just wishful thinking, derived from the fact that it felt epic enough to last a bit longer (even with 2 playthroughs, my displayed runtime is mostly due to costant background running. The game is in fact, rather short.)

Overall, Dust was a pretty neat game with a charming world, great art design, and nice music. 

It hits a lot of anime tropes, so if you're looking for an original story, this game felt familiar more than anything. Where the game shines is the precision of the combat and its world. VERY beautiful and tight. 

That said, the combat got repetitive after a while. I found myself executing the same combos for most encounters and by the end of the game it felt grindey. 

Rating: 7/10 
The game was fun for the most part, but the story dragged on a bit too long for its pacing. The game wasn't so memorable for its story or combat, but mainly its art. If you see it on sale it's worth a shot if you want a hack-n-slash adventure.

79635644.review:
Nice action combat. Nice mechanics and maps. I enjoyed the game while playing it. However: 

(Spoiler alert)

[spoiler]after hours of unlocking everything, the ending of the main story was simply a huge letdown. Throughout the cutscenes the main villain (and final boss) General Gaius has been depicted (with asides) as someone who is humane. This contrasts with what is actually happening in the game world, and what everyone else reports. So the player is set up to wonder about how this apparent conflict should reconcile, and is therefore encouraged to dig deeper into the story. Yet, at the end, there was nothing, General Gaius simply is the genocidal Nazi he is. And still, he is shown as almost 'compassionate', which makes no sense in the story (it serves no function in the story. We don't need such lengthy story to tell us a trivial fact that a character can be inconsistent). This is just a massive fail in the plot, and an intelligent player would simply feel cheated. There is nothing deep about showing that a Nazi can be compassionate. And if the idea was to show that a Nazi can be a good person in the context of his campaign to wipe out another race, then the author has missed his own point. Perhaps the author is trying to show the 'banality of evil' – just how misguided and stupid General Gaius is, even though he has a gentle nature. Sorry but these simply do not fit into the plot, which is a cliched 'save the world' plot. As I mentioned, throughout the story the player is presented with a conflict. At the end, this conflict isn't resolved, at all. In fact the ending scene just regurgitates the mystical conflicting element that permeated throughout the game. Except that when seen at the end, it just became an absolute failure, disappointing and irritating. The conflict was merely constructed as a tool to lure the player to keep on playing. Hence why I said the player will feel cheated, and let down. 

The player is presented with the illusion of making choices but they make no difference to the game. In general, there are too many random NON-FUNCTIONAL elements mixed together without thought about how they fit together and why they're even there (e.g. 2 souls). [/spoiler]

Therefore, I do not recommend this game, as I think it's just a waste of time. The game mechanics, while enjoyable, isn't deep enough to stand on itself. Exploring the story is a main reason why one would keep on playing (and there is no endgame post story). Unfortunately, the story is rubbish.

79377464.review:
I feel a little bad giving this a negative review considering how much passion was clearly put into it, but I really can't say I enjoyed myself very much past maybe the first three or four hours.  After that point the repetitiveness of the combat really started to show, and it's even more apparent with the sheer number of fodder enemies placed haphazardly across all of the (very linear) levels.  There's a few interesting elements to it, but the combat in the end just boils down to mindless button-mashing and the occasional special move when you feel like mixing it up a little.  It doesn't evolve very much across the ~10 hour story, and ends up getting very boring by the game's conclusion.  It isn't helped at all by the boring platforming that seems like it's just there because this game is a 2D sidescroller, and does pretty much nothing but take up time.

And the story... oh, the story.  It shows a little bit of promise at the beginning, but soon reveals itself to be cliche-ridden, predictable, and boring, filled with one-note characters and potentially interesting plot beats that very little is done with.  The voice acting, while not amazing, does a lot to help the experience, except when the lines the actors are reading are bad to the point of cringeworthy (which luckily isn't incredibly often).  The dialogue in general has a very amateurish feel to it, and is full of lame humor and misguided attempts to provoke emotion that more often than not just come across as forced.  It has a couple of good moments, but I'm not exaggerating when I say "a couple".  Most of the story is bland and doesn't feel worth investing anything into.

However, this game does have two glorious redeeming qualities that unfortunately don't make up for its shortcomings, but are nevertheless definitely worth mentioning.  One is the music, which is on the level of many classic JRPGs.  The game is full of absolutely amazing pieces of music, which set the scene perfectly in cutscenes and levels, and there's enough variety that you'll never get bored.  Even if you don't play the game, I'd recommend looking up the soundtrack and giving it a listen if you're interested.  
The second redeeming quality is something you've probably noticed if you've looked at any videos or screenshots of this game, and that's the art and animation.  Holy crap does it look great.  The 2D sprites, especially the player character's, move smoothly and look incredible, and the backgrounds are similarly impressive.  The guy who made this game is an artist, and it's very apparent that art is his forte.  There are a few fully-animated cutscenes in the game, and they're beautiful as well, each one leaving me wanting more.  Honestly, if this game was a movie, I'd watch it just for the animation and probably not regret it.

But it isn't a movie, it's a game, and at the end of the day it isn't a very good one.  Graphics and music can only carry an experience so far, and the "game" part of this game is incredibly repetitive and uninteresting, with a forgettable story running alongside it.  Still, I don't regret spending $4.75 on this game, although I imagine I would if I paid full price.  The graphics and music are great and I'm glad to support a creator who clearly has a lot of potential.  If he ever makes a sequel to this, I hope that he'll iron out the kinks and emphasize what's great, and if he does we'll probably have an excellent game on our hands.

Pros:

+Great sound and musical score.
+Wonderful story with a truly epic climax.
+Furry Metroidvania.

Cons:
-Enemy mobs can be difficult to manage when they fill the screen.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is an indie gem. A lot of love went into this fantastic metroidvania game from the anime-inspired artwork, fun and lovable characters, and it's deep and well written story. Even the musical score could rival modern AAA games, and the voice acting is not bad either. The final battle plays out in truly epic fashion with power behind the dialogue and score, which leads to a very satisfying ending that leaves it open for a sequel. There is also plenty to do with several sidequests, challenges, equipment, and collectibles. Even with some minor gameplay issues, I enjoyed every minute I had with Dust, and I recommend it to anyone looking for a richly detailed world and story with a dash of fast-paced metroidvania gameplay. The developer said he would bring us a sequel some time in the future and I greatly anticipate what Dust 2 could bring to an already exciting world.

78434337.review:
9/10 Enjoyable adventure/platformer. It's metroidvania-lite. Most of the time you're just hacking away or utilizing 1 of 3 Dust Storm abilities to clear the screen of enemies. Progression relies of navigating fruit bombs and just good platforming skills such as observing moving platforms and timing. Very few puzzles. 

Also very lite RPG mechanics as killing enemies gets you loot and experience. Get enough experience, level up, and invest in 1 of 4 combat stats. With the loot, you use it to craft equipment to boost you combat stats. Story progression is linear with few explorable dialog trees.

Visually speaking, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a good looking game in a cartoon-like environment. The animation looks like it received it a lot of effort. Also, I really enjoyed the audio from sound fx, spoken dialog, and most of all, the music. The voice acting is really good if you can look past some of the cheeziness of the game.

When I say cheeziness, there's several tropes prevalent throughout the game. Fortunately, I was able to look past them. Take them in stride. Honestly, it's a good story for the effort. The development team really have something mostly cohesive and competent, and I can definitely see a sequel (about 8 years since this game was release there is no sequel).

My only complaints with the game is just some of it feels repetitive or boring. There's one area where I wish I could just finish because I was so tired of it. I was tired of just beating up all the enemies. I had to take a break and do some chores to get over the monotony. After that, I was mostly driven knowing I was about halfway through the game and could power through. 

I might come back around to get some or all the remaining achievements. I might actually give this game another playtrhough on a tougher difficulty.

This was a great game. The story was really heartfelt and the ending kinda made me want to cry. 

The dialogue is pretty average. Lots of brooding and moping at times, but the voice casting was great. I love Fidget and the way she sounds, some of the side quest characters too. Fidget was really the life of the game, but did get kind of annoying after a while. Then again that was her characters role, so job well done, mission achieved. 

I really appreciated the flow of the combat. Yes it was very mash the buttons, however there was real skill involved if you were playing on a higher difficulty and didn't want to get demolished. I also love the side quests. They really helped flesh out the characters, and made you feel like these were real people with real issues. In fact some of them actually got quite dark, but considering the story it was really a good fit.... I still don't like to watch Fidget cry.

If you like good stories, good fighting mechanics, and need to escape for several hours, this is the game for you.

77541973.review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a platformer / action-adventure developed by Humble Hearts LLC.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

Dust An Elysian Tail takes place in the fictional world Falana, which is inhabited by human-like animals. The game world consists of two-dimensional levels. The player takes control of the title character Dust, who tries to remember his past. Dust has a living sword, the Ahrah Blade. Fidget, the guardian of the sword, acts as Dust's companion and can fire projectiles.

In the course of the game, the player can find power-ups that permanently change the game mechanics, such as the ability to perform a double jump or to climb to a previously unreachable level. The game also includes elements of role-playing games; Dust can gain experience points by defeating opponents and thus level up. Thus, various values, such as hit points or magic points, can be increased. The player can interact with non-player characters, buy or sell items, and receive quests.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ interesting scenario
+ intuitive combat action
+ magical staging
+ delightful character development
+ good soundtrack
+ attractive level design
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- Quests do not offer any variety
- Control takes getting used to

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a fabulous and addicting old-school 2D adventure that gives you a magical staging. Clear buy recommendation.

Der Spieler übernimmt die Kontrolle über die Titelfigur Dust, der versucht, sich an seine Vergangenheit zu erinnern. Dust verfügt über ein lebendes Schwert, die Klinge Ahrah. Fidget, die Hüterin des Schwerts, fungiert als Gefährtin von Dust und kann Geschosse verschießen.

Der Spieler kann im Laufe des Spiels Power-ups finden, die die Spielmechanik permanent verändern, wie zum Beispiel die Fähigkeit, einen Doppelsprung auszuführen oder zu einer vorher unerreichbaren Ebene zu klettern. Das Spiel beinhaltet zudem Elemente von Rollenspielen; Dust kann Erfahrungspunkte sammeln, indem er Gegner besiegt und so Level aufsteigen. Somit können verschiedene Werte, wie zum Beispiel Trefferpunkte oder Magiepunkte erhöht werden. Der Spieler kann mit Nicht-Spieler-Charakteren interagieren, Gegenstände kaufen oder verkaufen und Quests erhalten.

77267305.review:
Valdis Story + Hollow Knight + Sonic The Hedgehog

The soundtrack is gorgeous, the art is great (even though the Rayman-y sort of aesthetic isn't really my jam), the voice-acting is excellent, and the gameplay is smooth as butter.

Dust is a metroidvania with a lot of movement tech and combos, and with a servicable but non-excellent map. It's got RPG elements that you can break over your knee if you're having trouble playing it, but it's really not a hard game.

Unless you want to go fast. And then it's as challenging as you want to make it. 

I'm not sure why my playtime is displaying as three hours, since I'm pretty certain I've put a bunch more than that into it so far, but I feel comfortable recommending Dust based on what I've seen of the core gameplay loop and the overall level of polish.

If you strongly dislike cartoony voices or anthropomorphic characters, you might have a bad time here, but the writing feels pretty solid, and the voice-actors and animators do a great job with the material.

I'll update this review if my feelings strongly change, but otherwise this seems like a gem for both casual players and competitive folks alike.

77051516.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a fun game. The controls work well, the game is smooth, the music and art range from "not bad" to "very good," and all of this was done by essentially a one-man team.

But the story. Oh, the story. Spoilers ahead.

You play as Dust, an amnesiac fighting a one-athro war against a legion of monsters and soldiers threatening the land as you try to recover your memory. The problem is that the talking sword you get clearly knows all about your past, but it's not telling. [spoiler] "Soon," it says, as villages burn, caves collapse, and townspeople either turn away from you in fear. Plot twist, it turns out that you were created by forcing the souls of an omnicidal assassin and a random kid by a bunch of lizard people in order to create the ultimate weapon and save them from genocide.[/spoiler]

Is there any exploration of this? No, you're totally fine with it. You have no problem with being kept in the dark for 80% of the game, and even fewer problems with becoming exactly the weapon you were created to be. There is a Good Side and an Evil Side, and the story simply can't comprehend that someone might have questions when the Good Side is keeping a lot of secrets. The hand-wave for all of this is, again, that you've lost your memories; it doesn't matter who you were, only who you are now... but who you are now is a game protagonist on a railroad plot, which sure isn't satisfying. Not helping things is the constant allusion to some grand mythos that is never actually explained. What are the Blades of Elysium, the Life Thread, and the concept of a soul that are all so integral to the story? Everybody seems to know except the player.

All in all, the game is mechanically good, but there's too much story sprinkled in for mechanics to carry the game. The story that exists feels half-baked, a setting with flat characters and incomplete history that is full of holes that nobody acknowledges. I beat the game, but I did not enjoy it. I stopped caring about the characters and the story, including the cliché (and Purple-Prose-filled) ending. I was just staring at my screen, mashing buttons and hoping for a few rare drops before the plot ran out.

Oh, and the final boss is a joke if you've fully leveled up and spent some money in the shop for equipment. As in, even if he hits you, it does barely any damage that is healed in one second on the "Tough" difficulty. Maybe it's better on Hardcore, but the game is barely worth one playthrough, let alone two.

76068662.review:
Dust naturally combines the 2D level design of a "metroidvania" with the button slamming combat of a hack'n'slash, but fails to seamlessly integrate the two together through a dreadfully cumbersome user interface that weighs down the already sluggish pace.

WHAT I LIKED:
+ "I'm not afraid of the dark. I'm afraid of things in the dark". Voice acting, particularly in a small calibre title such as Dust, is a rarity and always a pleasure to discover. The moody yet courageous tones complement Dust's prowess whilst the high-pitched fourth-wall breaks of the ever so sarcastic Fidget grants his sidekick with plenty of personality. The lines of dialogue throughout is undoubtedly a high selling point for the game, with each side quest offering hilarious quotes that'll have the player laughing at the screen. Plus, it produces characterisation for each character, and the end result is an enjoyable and memorable time.
+ This "Elysian Tail" is a difficult quest, to which every level gained grants the player an incredibly important stat boost that they must choose wisely to upgrade. Whether it's adding to Dust's strength, life force, defence or Fidget's chaotic secondary power that fills the screen up with so much intensity and so much death, each advancement to one of the four listed attributes changes the game immensely. Consequently, this offers a strategy when building Dust up as a character, whilst keeping the sense of progression intact. 
+ Forests, caves and dilapidated churches. Each backdrop of the branching world were illustrated to perfection. Plenty of detail to spice up the world and appeal to the characterised visuals.

WHAT I DISLIKED:
- The user interface was dreadful. For starters, the title screen resembled a standard mediocre 'RPG Maker' game that had a font style which inadvertently juxtaposed the backdrop. However it was the menu system itself that was tediously cumbersome to navigate. Food items are of paramount importance in Dust, but in order to digest them they need to be equipped into the quick slot before being consumed. The map system was as basic as they come, mimicking 'Metroid's' blue squared notation. The quest log was insufficient, supplying minimal details. Crafting remained redundant with high item drop rates from enemies that never instigated fulfilling a blueprint. And basic menu navigation was mostly unsatisfying. It never matched the quality of the in-game mechanics.
- Areas comprised of sections. These ranged from minuscule two-sectioned areas to sprawling twenty-or-so-sectioned areas all interconnected by a world map. These larger areas were so vast, that they quickly became tedious to navigate. Spending two hours in the same area to unlock a chest or two never felt rewarding or satisfying. The lack of an intuitive fast travelling system, aside from a crystal that teleports the player out of an area and back to the world map, hindered the standard "metroidvania" progressional exploration. It never once motivated me to venture back to previous areas to discover all of its secrets.
- The hack'n'slash combat was unbalanced. Initially, Dust slashing his sword through enemies felt satisfying and required player intuition to quickly dodge enemy attacks. Shortly after completing the first area, Fidget becomes stronger and more reliable as a gameplay mechanic. This leads to the player spinning through the level while shooting millions of projectiles in every direction, obliterating all of the enemies on screen. It instantly becomes mundane and far too excessive. Attempting to maintain combos are essentially relinquished due to the chaos that rapidly ensues, which is an integral aspect to any hack'n'slash style.
- The boss battles were a huge letdown, and gauged little to no challenge...

VERDICT:
4/10 "flying weasels"

P.S. Dean Dodrill has obviously crafted a well-loved game, and the fact it was independently developed will always be appreciative. But as a fan of "metroidvanias" and as someone who has played hundreds of them, Dust just wasn't for me.

75897715.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail has a lot to offer for a game many put off due to the artistic direction and character design.

Combat is very intuitive and easy going. A lack of variety in move sets but your ability to cancel them with movement options kept it fresh and creative. It's also extremely satisfying hitting everything on screen for a massive combo while flying up 40ft in the air.

Game progression is as metroidvania as you can get. A formula we're probably all used to but Dust is one executed right. It keeps it simple and beautiful without losing that classic touch.

Story is pretty simple and cliche but the strong points were in the voice acting and writing put into bringing the characters to life. Some side characters are questionable with their heavy accents but the occasional 4th wall breaks created some of the most memorable moments. Also an excellent job from the main cast throughout the game.

Soundtrack is THE strongest element the game has to offer.

The game can suffer in the beginning in regards to restoring health and lack of enemy variety/attack patterns. But it does pick up relatively quick and fixes it. Other than that, Dust is a fantastic experience and one I will revisit again in the future.

73844520.review:
Upon picking up this game on xbox 360, back in 2018, I was hoping to have a good experience with it. I played it a small amount there, before I lost the xbox, and remember absolutely nothing about it. I bought it again on steam more recently to give it another chance, but I had just barely made it to the first village when I couldn't go any further. Personally, the character designs and backgrounds and music were decent to actually beautiful, but it wasn't enough to cover up the many glaring issues that the game has poking out.

-The character's voices are overly stereotypical or annoying to the point where I was skipping the dialogue, which wasn't an issue because:
-The map is just as linear as the new pokemon games, so there's absolutely no need to even bother with any of the plot, since it's just paved out for you in the gameplay.
-The plot is as bland as boiled chicken. A husky-voiced, face-hiding, backhand-wielding "swordmaster" wakes up with amnesia, and not only does he does he have amnesia, but he's got BOTH a talking sword, and a squeaky-voiced, small, flying companion.
-You get handheld harder than a 5 year old in a supermarket. You can't save your points without the game constantly poking you to spend them immediately (which force you to become a generalist anyways, so what's the point in even giving us dedicated skill points if you're just going to lock us out of desired choices anyways?), along with the skills that are just given to you as a reward for walking and pressing X and Y randomly.
-Speaking of the combat, there's absolutely no reason to have any combos on the ground after you get the combos and abilities to fight in the air. Once I got the X-Y air combo and the aerial dash, I hardly ever even took advantage of Dust's legs. It was broken to the point that jumping led you to an almost invincible state, where the *only* enemy that could hurt you were the slimes (which, when I first encountered them, they didn't even foreshadow their attack, and immediately spiked me from underneath).
-It's either painfully obvious, or almost impossible to tell when you take damage. Most of the time, you get hit when there are a metric ton of animations and details on screen, so it's difficult to see your own character turning red (a red vignette would've made it much more obvious). Other times, you try to parry, and even when it seems like it should be perfectly timed, the game smacks you in the face (what's the purpose of having a tutorial for parrying if you get the opportunity to do so more than enough times beforehand?).

I *tried* giving this game more time than I did, but there was no reason for me to. I had no desire to, I wasn't feeling a connection to any of the characters, and the level layouts were too cut and dry for me. It's not fun playing a game where you don't even *want* to listen to the characters, or where you don't *want* to go through the same level-creator-esque areas. It's boring, and, to reiterate one of my earlier statements, it's done to death.

73521745.review:
Juego precioso creado por una sola persona que tuvo algo de ayuda. Metroidvania sencillito que mezcla acción y exploración de una manera destacable, no inventa nada ni tampoco es especialmente bueno en esas facetas pero el resultado es positivo y cualquiera lo puede comprobar. Dudo que alguien que pruebe Dust no quiera seguir jugándolo porque es asequible, adictivo y está bien hecho.
Dust es el prota y aparece en medio de un bosque amnésico y acompañado de una espada parlante y la guardiana de ésta, Fidget. Los tres juntos debéis hacer frente a los diversos problemas de la región mientras vas descubriendo quién es el prota, algo que llevará alguna sorpresilla aunque nada especialmente original. Con esa premisa empiezas a explorar el bonito mundo hecho a mano que está a tu disposición, conocerás gente, los ayudarás y finalmente comenzará la trama final del juego que desemboca en un final bastante espectacular aunque previsible. Muy buen trabajo de este hombre y aquí dejo mi recomendación pero no sin antes mencionar sus cosas malas, que las tiene. Por descarte, todo lo que no diga será bueno como por ejemplo el aspecto visual y la música que son muy chulos.
Lo malo:
-Es muy fácil, pero mucho. Lo jugué en la máxima dificultad y morí 2 veces o quizá 3, no recuerdo. El prota es tan bestia en combate que es imparable, eso sí, al menos por jugarlo en difícil pasaba algo y es que el daño recibido es enorme pero de todas formas sigue siendo muy fácil.
-La historia está bien, te pica la curiosidad y todo eso pero han querido ser graciosos usando a Fidget y como mucho el juego es simpático, tiene un humor muy plano e infantil.
-El sistema de combate es muy chulo pero es caótico, te mueves tan rápido y se llena todo tanto de luces y cosas que a menudo pierdes la ubicación del personaje. Y a veces, en la parte final, confundes al prota con NPC's y enemigos porque hay muchos en pantalla y tienen un aspecto parecido.
-El control es deficiente, manejar a Dust cuesta bastante por imprecisión en el mando, no siempre responde a lo que pulsas, los saltos son muy falsos y difíciles de controlar,... no es horrible en absoluto, te acostumbras, pero no ha quedado bien este aspecto.
-El sistema de impactos también es un poco fallón, muchas veces atacarás a alguien y no le harás daño porque... sí, porque es evidente que has acertado el golpe. Lo mismo pasa con las trampas, a veces las tocas y traspasas claramente y no te hacen daño, otras veces solo con acercarte te dañan, en fin.
-Lo peor de todo, y ya para acabar, es algo que sí es grave y es un bug que afecta a la interacción con el mundo. Para hablar con la gente, guardar partida, entrar en sitios y comerciar debes pulsar Arriba, además Fidget te lo marca siempre. Pero claro, hay un fallo muy gordo en esto y es que tras jugar un ratito (y a veces ya está bugueado según empiezas a jugar) notarás que cuando pasas al lado de algo con el que sabes que puedes interaccionar, Fidget no dice nada y luego ves que no puedes hablar, guardar partida, etc... Lo de hablar con la gente no suele estropearse pero lo demás sí de modo que si quieres salvar partida no puedes, si quieres abrir un cofre no puedes y así con todo. Lo bueno es que, de alguna manera, se arregla solo pero luego vuelve a fallar. Esto da mucha rabia e inseguridad porque quizá solo quieres jugar media hora y si quieres dejarlo no puedes porque no te permita guardar y tal vez debas esperar 10 minutos a que se arregle. Un fallo brutal, molesto y absurdo aunque he visto gameplays por ahí y no les pasaba eso, o sea que tal vez solo me pase a mí pero en cualquier caso hizo que una buena experiencia fuese bastante disminuida por algo así.

Resumiendo, muy buen juego, muy recomendable pero tiene sus pegas y ninguna es relevante salvo lo del bug de las interacciones con el entorno, algo que para mí le baja muchos puntos, pero muchos. No obstante, es un juego digno de ser probado por todo el mundo.

Nota: 6,5

73147821.review:
I played this game 11 hours and got 14 of 30 achievements. I gave it a fair chance. At this point I'd rather replay any game that is actually good than continue on.

The Good
The art and music are really good to excellent.
The voice acting is good, the characters are cute and interesting.

The Bad

I played it on tough difficulty. Most enemies barely attack you, they are just there to absorb damage and slow you down. Then you come to enemies that your sword cannot kill, and you have to use Fidget's magic ability, which I never bothered to level up or use. So it took forever to kill these. So now I'm leveling up an ability I don't even like or use to get past once specific enemy.

The combat is mostly boring and easy until they sneak in an enemy that actually can hurt you. But it's hard to see their attacks because the screen is cluttered with damage sponges and the mostly worthless loot they drop.

The controls are weird (you use the right thumbstick to dodge), and you can't remap them.

The platforming is below average at best. Most ledges end before the shown edge, so if you try to jump from the very edge, you'll fall off the ledge. So far there's no wall jumping (except in designed areas), no double jumps...there's nothing interesting about how your character moves or what you can do.

There are some off limit areas and you do get abilities that allow you to access them later, but backtracking is a chore because each area pretty much looks the same with no platforming or traversal variety. I would not call this a Metroidvania (my favorite genre).

The secrets get pretty boring fast. You either slash through a wall or guide a flower bomb to a wall...over and over and over again.

Dust isn't a bad game, but beyond the art, music, and voice acting, everything else is mediocre.

Dust is quite an intresting game that stood out for me. I played it when I was younger but never completed it so when I saw it was on sale I bought it and played it since I rememberd having a good time. 

First of. This game is absolutely gorgeous with it's graphics and areas. It stood out immedietly and it's such a treat to just look at. Also the attention to detail in most areas is incredibly well done and it made the background even prettier. The animations for the most parts are solid and amazingly done. Some could use a bit of extra love, same goes with the animated cutscenes, but for the most parts they were awesome.

But that didn't bother me since the voice acting in this game for the majority of the characters are absolutly amazing. Some scenes will look weird due to the mix-match of 2d and 3d graphics but they're are far inbetween. 

The games overall story was intresting but it didn't quite "catch me" until the very end. However! The gameplay was extremly fun and not to challening to someone who's not famililar with the hack-n-slash genre of games.  

There was a few things I would personally change to make the game a lot more enjoyable mainly: SPOILERS!!! 

The ghost mansion missions. they we're so boring and didn't add much to the overall experience except dragging it out. same repetative shit over and over 4 times. Some bit of matchup for the 4 mansions would make this segment so much better.

Overall I would give Dust: The elysian tale a solid 8/10.

71290536.review:
Lovely game.

Aesthetically it can't be stated enough how beautiful it is. Each environment was wonderfully crafted and a joy to progress through.

Combat is fun and intuitive, though it does wear itself thin towards the later stages of the game. To break it up it sprinkles in platforming and puzzle sections which are decent enough distractions, barring some annoying spikes at times.

Voice work is a mixed bag, but the main cast (Dust, Fidget and Ahrah) do a fine job. Fidget in particular was the highlight for me. Brilliant delivery, and had some excellent lines that kept me listening to her. "MASH THE BUTTONS!"

The story definitely gets cheesy toward the end (plus a little bit of dialogue inconsistency), but it's treated with respect and the VA's make it work.

Overall it's an excellent game that I never got round to playing properly, and I'm glad I did.

71206402.review: I absolutely love this game. The mechanics are wonderful, and super super fun. The leveling up aspect is simple yet effective. The characters are voiced to perfection, and they have soooooooooooooooooooooo much personality and character. The side quests don't feel like a chore, they feel like they add to the game rather than take away (which is a FEAT in today's standards). The music? Ah. Amazing. I loved the music, and how well it fit in every single level. And don't get me started about the story. Unique, powerful, and gut-wrenchingly beautiful and engaging yet still fun and silly. This game is a masterpiece and I can't recommend it enough. I've recently played Bastion, but I think this game has spoiled me because Dust has done everything better than Bastion in my opinion. This game holds a real special place in my heart. Again, I can't recommend this game enough. Give it a shot, you might just love it as much as I did and still do.

I just finished the game. It is a short game, it took me about 11 hours to get through it. I didn't do every possible sidequest, but I believe I did around 60% of them. Others already described the game so I won't do that again, I'll just say a little about my experience with it.

It is a fun game to play, it is not hard to get going with the mechanics, you don't even need to master it to get through the whole game, just learn a thing or two. The story is very good and it is the reason why I didn't do many side quests, I wanted to know how it would unfold and it is worth it.

However, for those of you who are used to keep playing after you finish the game, with this one it is not possible, so either you do everything you want before going to the final boss or you won't have another chance. 

Will I play the game again? Not likely. 

Considering my experience with the game, if possible, would I play it for the first time again? Hell yeah! 

If you want a short fun game, go ahead, if you'd rather have something to play over and over, look elsewhere

69967785.review:
I'm astonished this game gets overwhelmingly positive reviews.  Maybe only because furries are the main audience and there are few games targeted at us?

Art style is cute and kinda pretty at times.  Odd rainbow/glowing vines detract from the aesthetic in many areas.
Fidget is adorable.
Voice acting is good.
Story is so-so.  Villain is one-dimensional and lacks motivation.  Dust's reactions to things are often simplistic and unrealistic.

It falls flat as a Metroidvania with only 4 skills and 2 additional fidget-weapon types to learn, each of them generic.  I found it frustrating that all skills were "learned" by touching a generic glowing ball with no attempt at explaining why the ball would grant abilities at all, especially supernatural abilities.  Balls rarely had guardians and felt carelessly thrown in almost randomly.

I love Metroidvanias and exploration, but with Dust I never had the 'that's really cool' experience of using a creative skill or finding secrets.  I explored 100% of the map and treasures but it felt more like a chore than an exploration.

It had a couple of decent puzzles.  I found a lot of puzzles/secrets were more frustrating than satisfactory to obtain because they required long periods of running, waiting on a platform, or spamming a certain button in a way that made it unclear if that was the intended solution.  One secret required matching a symbol on an object in inventory to something in the game, but the symbol in inventory was so faint I never realized what it was.  That was one of two puzzles I had to look up the solution to.  Both involved crouching for ~10 secs in certain locations and don't ask me how you're supposed to know that crouching for a long time will activate something.

There's also a janky method of using wind attack to fly to the top of almost any level by moving left and right through enemies.  I can't decide if it's a bug or intentional, but there are some secrets that can be obtained using it.  The intended way to get many (maybe all?) of those secrets is using skills acquired near the end of the game.

In one case I got a key using janky air rise before I should have been able to reach it and the game didn't count my obtaining it.  Now I'm missing 3% of the treasure on Blackmoor Mountains so I can never reach 100%.  I checked a video and two forums to make sure I wasn't missing a treasure other than the key.

Combat was mindless on Normal difficulty after the first 30-60 mins.  You just spam Fidget's attack plus wind attack.  It even works on all bosses, including the final one.  On rare occasion you must cure Fidget's silenced status during a boss fight using an item in the pause menu.  There are about 10 instances of an enemy you must parry once before spamming.  If you avoid the spam and fight with jumps and slashes, maybe combat is more satisfying, but personally I found it hard to keep track of where Dust was within swarms of enemies.  Regularly fighting 5-20 enemies at once gives a sense of feeling overpowered and goes with the theme of Dust being "able to fight an army", but I lost interest in that pretty quickly and found combat to be boring and repetitive after a little while.

Conversations started strong with additional dialog after repeated talks, but later people had less and less to say and the second half of the game felt rushed with little conversation.

The game is impressive for being mostly created by one person, but then again so was Axiom Verge and Axiom was many times more impressive and fun.  Fans of furry characters may enjoy it simply for the aesthetics but in all other aspects I can't say it felt worth my time.

If you do play, set "Portrait Quality: High" in Settings or you will notice pixelation/artifacting in the linework when characters talk to each other.

69793007.review:
This game is more of a sideways for me, rather than a thumbs up or down. The art style and music were good. It reminded me a lot of Sega Saturn style RPGs. The leveling up system and story were both more of a sideways thumb for me. You have to basically have at least a single point in everything to progress. So while you can "max" one stat, you can't leave the other stats behind. You end up with the joke of putting a point into everything.  The down points were the tediousness of combat and an unnecessary crafting system. The combat was essentially just a few buttons to mash, or throw in magic on the occasion. There weren't any layers too it. The crafting system was a waste of time. You either find what you're looking for, can buy it, or you don't need it. I never even found one of the items necessary to make the "best" items in the game. Still finished the final boss without any need though. 

The voice acting was also pretty terrible at points. You end up in a town with Australian, French, and a few other accents. Why do they have to have accents? Why does the guy with the ancient Chinese look have an uppity French accent? 

I had to ultimately give a thumbs down due to the amount of time it took to finish the game. I want one hour per dollar spent. While the amount of game time is higher than the price, there were periods I just left the game paused and did other things. 

If you're looking for a retro-esque platformer, I would only recommend this on sale. Thank goodness the game wasn't longer because I struggled to finish the last area.

69644903.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tale was a really mixed bag for me, and I was wavering between whether this would get the thumbs-up or not. I think as a project by one person, it's really quite an accomplishment. Comparing it to other Metroidvania games, it just doesn't hold up. In the end, I wouldn't tell a friend to play it. I'll run through points for and against.

For the good parts, I thought the backgrounds, attack animations, and general art style were all on point. The style of the animal characters is a bit weird, but I think it works for this game to make it stand out. Most of the time, the combat feels pretty satisfying as you mindlessly cleave through waves of enemies. The story was pretty decent as well.

Now, for the complaints. The combat overall is very simplistic, and it's basically just a button masher. You do the same few attacks constantly, spam magic, rinse and repeat. Towards the end, failing to constantly mash attack meant I would miss parry windows, or just miss with my attacks completely. For the majority of the game, you feel unstoppable, but near the end the enemies hit ridiculously hard and it's basically just luck as to whether you hit your counter or lose half your life. In general, your character feels sluggish and imprecise. Platforming can be quite a pain, especially where things like spikes or lava are concerned, because health does not come back and you always need to use healing items. I felt like enemies dropped a completely pitiful amount of gold for the amount you'll have to spend on food to heal yourself. For the final boss I basically spent my entire game's savings on food and it was barely enough. This makes me think you're meant to grind to be higher level, which I was not willing to do (finished at lvl 32 I think). People point to the voice acting as a high point, but honestly most of it was so cringe-worthy. The orange bat-thing, Fidget, is particularly annoying; the main character, Dust, is not much better, sounding like a moody anime teen while trying to deliver these serious lines. Some of the supporting cast did a good job, but the characters I need to listen to constantly really started to grate on me. Also, while I understand the limited art budget, I felt like the cutscenes were a particular step down from the rest of the game's look; they seriously look like they're done in MS Paint. I think that was a missed opportunity to lean in to the painted art style of other parts of the game. 

Looking at the size of the positives vs. negatives, I guess it really was more a negative review. Still, it kept me playing through to the end, for what it's worth. There was fun to be had in exploring around and slashing bad guys, but then there would always be something to annoy me (there were plenty more things I didn't remember to mention). I guess I was hoping for more payout, because the end was tedious and very frustrating to play. The end boss has like 4 phases! I wouldn't say this game is awful or anything, but there isn't enough here to make me recommend this to others.

69589469.review:
EDIT: I thought about this more and changed to a thumbs down.

This is a verrry conditional yes - I usually don't write reviews but this game is very specific. tldr don't play it if you value story a lot, otherwise it's fine. You might like the story if you're young - I probably would have in like 6th grade.

This game has a very colorful and unique art style and very fun gameplay. I don't know how many beat-em-up metroidvanias exist, but I've never heard of another one. Stringing together attacks and zooming around the screen with the aerial right click was very satisfying, as was collecting loot and exploring. The music is fine (with the exception of the cutscenes, which I thought were scored very well), but not memorable.

However, if you're like me and you really value story/writing, I absolutely don't recommend this game. The characters are pretty flat, the game's emotional beats seem cheap and not set-up, and there is barely any lore or backstory to most characters. Writing-wise, most things are very cheesy/overdramatic, with the exception of Fidget [spoiler] and her relationship with Dust [/spoiler] (she was over-the-top and didn't really have an arc, but I liked her dialogue). I believe I did about half of the sidequests before finishing the game and didn't get much out of it there either. Click the spoiler tags below if you want a full rant about why I really disliked the story.

[spoiler] Emotional beats with no set up: BoPo's dad dying, Cora's reuniting with her husband, Gaius's death. When BoPo's dad died, my only emotional reaction was from the fact that a child was losing his father, not that this character I know/love is losing someone close to him. That felt cheap - I had barely interacted with BoPo so I didn't really care on a personal level. The same goes for Cora - I was a bit sad/happy, but I barely knew either of the characters at all. From the way the other characters react, I felt like these were going for a bigger emotional reaction that just fell flat. And I'm the type who cried for like 2 hours straight after finishing To The Moon.  [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Besides those two, I felt like Gaius was poorly written. By his design and dialogue it seemed like they were trying to make him seem non-threatening to make you doubt yourself? But his character never hit for one reason: WHY WAS HE TRYING TO KILL THE MOONBLOODS???? Not ONCE did Dust/anyone ever try to convince him through any method besides "Stop or I'll kill you!". I was just waiting the entire climax for Dust to ask Gaius why he wanted to commit genocide and expected something like "They killed my family!" if they were going for more morally grey or at the very least "They are inferior/cause trouble/racism!" if they just wanted him to be the big bad. Gaius has absolutely no motivation to kill the moonbloods, unless this was hidden in some obscure place (which it shouldn't be, as it's the main villain's motivation???). He has no backstory besides "he was friends with Cassius", either. This all came to a head in the final scene, where he kills himself for no apparent reason, and we're supposed to feel sad about it, judging by the animation and the music. Except, I literally know nothing about this guy except he was friends with Cassius, who was evil, and that he wants to commit genocide for shits and giggles I guess. And then he gets a slow motion "Nooooo!" death scene? Come on.  [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Another general bad thing they did were the themes. I saw two attempted themes: Dust's identity and "Sometimes your best isn't enough". Dust's identity was alright, but I feel like it could have permeated the game much more. There was literally no hint of Cassius's personality in Dust until the very last scene, which is just cheap and majorly weakens the theme. As for the second theme, it's only brought up twice: when BoPo's dad dies and the very end. The first time I was like "ok, let's see where they go with this, maybe this can be Fidget's character arc." Except it really wasn't, it went nowhere, as did Fidget as a character. They just brought it up at the very end like "Heyy! It's a theme! Look! It came up twice!!".  [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Finally, there are also some inexplicable or lazy story points. It's kind of weird Dust basically just beat the shit out of people until they agreed with him twice? And those were the main two middle story beats. The water lady said she was under some supernatural "darkness" that was never explained. Unless the "darkness" was actually her desire for revenge and not a supernatural thing, in which case Dust literally just beat her up until she changed her mind. In any case, it made no sense. The Kane ghost was never explained, nor was the Kane demon, nor was the Flameless Light or whatever. There is minimal thought put into the world, it doesn't operate under a set of rules, etc. For example, Aurora is shocked by an attack from below, and show no knowledge of the Po people living beneath them - it would be obvious they should ask the Pos what happened, so they must not know of there existence, right? But Dust/Fidget don't seem surprised by the Pos, nor do they ask for an explanation of like their race, so they're probably some known entity? But also the Pos know the surface-dwellers exist, as they reference their dislike of them a lot. That implies that there have been altercations between them before, yet Aurorans don't seem to know they exist.
Anyways. 
tldr; writing bad. [/spoiler]
\rant
I wrote all this, but besides the story it's a decent game, so I gave it a recommend.

69513785.review: Great side scroller with wonderful visuals, good gameplay, and a good story. 69398346.review:
I first played it back in 2014 and while the combat seemed nice I was turned off by the cartoonish art style and child-friendly dialog so didn't really get beyond the first area and dropped it. Came back to it now in 2020 because of the lockdown and because my system can only support low graphics games and I had an absolute blast. There is a satisfying gameplay loop of hack and slash combat, looting enemies and exploring and platforming for hidden areas, all to collect resources for crafting more gear. Plenty of side-quests, a lovely hand drawn world backed by a beautiful soundtrack, a really nice story that while remaining kid friendly has its fair share of powerful moments. The combat is extremely satisfying and platforming is fairly fun, controls are good can't really find any faults. Surprised by how enjoyable it was as a whole. There are some nice nods to other indie games as well if you're into that kinda stuff.

On the negative side the sidekick might be an annoying character to some players but thankfully the game is generous with letting you button mash to skip through lines or just skip dialog sections entirely, though personally (surprisingly) I actually found it quite endearing. Some tiny annoyances like parrying an enemy sometimes throws you back into environmental hazards but those are nitpicks really. The difficulty can also be weird, on tough difficulty it's quite hard at the start of each chapter, but after gaining a few levels and finding or crafting some updated gear the rest of the chapter quickly becomes a cakewalk only for it to become hard again at the start of the next chapter. You will easily start to one shot enemies in previous areas and always have a surplus of resources. Which can either make you feel powerful like you play really well or bored like it lacks a challenge, you know what kind of player you are. An option for scalable enemies might have been nice I guess, but it didn't take away from my experience. Negatives are few and far between really.

Surprisingly polished and captivating game and can only imagine the amount of work the developer put into this. Will have fond memories of this. That world map music is blissful \m/

[b]Verdict: A must play for fans of Indie games, Metroidvanias & RPGs. If you fancy all 3 then this right here is a jackpot for you.[/b]

69202202.review:
Dust is an entertaining metroidvania style game where you wake up with amnesia with a powerful sword, Ahra, and a sidekick Fidget.  You travel the landscape in a 2D side scrolling platforming RPG taking on side quests to help the folks of Aurora, Mudtop, and other villages as you aim to complete your overarching quest...to find and defeat General Gaius.

The storyline is interesting as you learn more about who you are, the voice acting is generally well done, and the graphics are cute, not extremely detailed, but fit the genre and the storyline just fine.  The music and the sound effects are good, but nothing to write home about.  The action is fairly free flowing.  You have your usual combos that give you different attacks and finishing moves as well as increased access to abilities for both you and your sidekick to help you deal with an ever increasing difficult enemy to defeat.  Different levels take you to different style of scenery from the great outdoors to dark caves and snow filled mountaintops.

I found this game to be engaging and rather fun.  The abilities really add to the game not only for the metroidvania style of gaming, but for the attacks on your enemies as well.  I still can't believe this was made entirely, save the music and voice overs, by one person.  What an achievement for sure!  If you like metroidvania type game, this has it all: storyline, action, quests, things to collect, and it all comes together rather well.  I would definitely recommend this for those that enjoy a good game, just know that in my play through I played on normal and while I did die a few times, I didn't find it too difficult.  However, there is a hard and expert level of gameplay as well in case you need to ramp up the difficulty.

69154357.review: Juego donde se combinan elementos de exploración (de los llamados metroidvania) con un clásico juego de acción tipo arcade en done hay que completar niveles en los que tienes que derrotar a un número de enemigos para avanzar. La estética es muy buena y a envejecido bien pues pues el estilo de animación caricaturizada le sienta bien con los fondos de los escenarios de tipo más renderizado y  pesar de sus años lo disfrute bastante, sin que me encantara el diseño de personajes.  La historia es un poco genérica con un giro que da inicio al tercer acto del juego pero funciona para el estilo de juego pues da una motivación al personaje y lo encuentra en una dualidad extraña. Aparte de la animación la otra pieza estelar del juego es la movilidad, por lo general es rápida y los combos que puedes hacer te da una buena sensación de combate, Lo que sí es que creo que este juego esta inclinado al lado sencillo y casual, pro creo que si eres un poco clavado y metódico le puedes sacar mucho jugo a los controles (me imagino que se podría hacer un buen speedrun del juego). Buen juego, bastante disfrutable y entretenido, la verdad no pedía más, la animación me sorprendió y el combate y la movilidad se sienten bien, la historia tiene un giro interesante y sin duda lo recomiendo, sobretodo si buscas algo del lado más casual. Eso si creo que un control es necesario para en verdad disfrutar este juego

69147865.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail, es un RPG estilo Metroidvania, no vas a encontrarte un Metroid o un Castlevania, de hecho este juego es incluso bastante sencillo, pero tiene algo que engancha, el juego viene con textos en español y voces en ingles, el estilo de dibujo es precioso y tiene una hermosa ambientación, mientras juegas de vez en cuando hay cambio de clima que le da un poco mas de vida al juego (Aunque a veces puede ser un poco molesto para los ojos los rayos de la tormenta), una hermosa banda sonora, muchos enemigos interesantes, su historia es muy interesante (tal vez no sea una gran historia o la mejor que hayas leído pero una vez que lo empiezas te dan ganas de seguir hasta saber que esta pasando realmente, al menos a mi me atrapo), y si eres una persona algo sensible en ocasiones te llevarás un Crash en el kokoro.

Dust es un misterioso "chico" que a perdido la memoria, se encuentra una espada parlante y a su guardiana Fidget una criaturita adorable con aspecto dulce (pero no te dejes engañar por su apariencia en verdad es un poco bocazas y atrevida pero le da un toque divertidisimo a la trama)

Una recomendación a todo aquel que compre el juego, como muchos juegos este no es perfecto y a veces se puede volver un poco loco XD, así que recomiendo guardar lo mas seguido posible y en varios apartados (a mi me crasheo varias veces pero mi PC es un poco especialito así que quizás a los que lo compren no les pase nada, pero por las dudas mejor avisar), también advertir que en ocasiones el juego no detecta los "círculos de guardado" y ni guarda autimatico ni puedes guardar manualmente, así pues cuidadito, para solucionarlo normalmente basta con cambiar de una zona a otra, pero asegúrate de guardar siempre que puedas por estos 2 bugs (no se si son bugs que pasa normalmente o solo con algunos PC´S pero por si acaso os prevengo)

En definitiva es un buen juego para pasar unas horas bien entretenido, además en rebajas sale baratito, así que dale una oportunidad seguro no te arrepientes (yo lo encontre por casualidad y no me arrepiento de haberlo comprado).

67838224.review:
DeviantArt: The Video Game, hahaha.

I do appreciate all the work that must have gone into fully voicing this game, painting the backgrounds, etc. It's definitely different from most by-the-book platformers. It has aspirations and scope. But I also couldn't get past some basic choices the devs made, like making every character a weird-looking animal-person hybrid for no clear reason. (They're not even cute.)

Aside from that, I found issues with gameplay, especially combat. It feels like you can cheese a lot with your special attack; on the other hand, using your main attacks is often frustrating. The whole system is limited and results in repetitiveness. I also had trouble distinguishing between the foreground and the background when platforming.

The music is OK. Voice-over work for some characters is wonderful, but the protagonists sound super-cringy. The story was starting to get intriguing at a certain point but then went back to being silly. The antagonist's motivations are never explained and the whole thing doesn't make much sense.
