67773136.review: Good game with quite a few interesting mechanics, some of which are outside of the story line and require some hunting. It may be most enjoyable for the novice gamer or those looking for a retro gaming experience as its story is a little predictable and method of delivery somewhat dated. Most will want to play the game on its harder modes as most enemies don't have tricky fighting styles, and leveling up and equipment cause the player to be overpowered for most of the game. To keep the game challenging you may need to handicap yourself, which can be disappointing as it causes new blueprints to not be exciting. While I'm on the subject, as a completionist the treasure chest are disappointing as the loot is terrible. [9/10 for the chill or novice gamer -- 5/10 for the experienced and demanding gamer]

Dust: an elysian tail is en un metroidvania hack n' slash con un apartado artistico destacable donde controlas a dust, un furro con amnesia y una espada quien tendra que explorar un mundo lleno de mas furros en busqueda de su identidad, antes de comenzar tengo que aclarar un par de cosas, si, dust es un juego con furros de colores y si, algunos de estos personajes son altamente sexualizables, habiendo aclarado esto, me encanta este juego, y no por que tenga una extraña necesidad de hallar placer introduciendo cosas que no deberia dentro de animales, si no que por que dust: an elysian tail es muy muy bueno... [strike] y tiene furros [/strike]

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1] el hecho de que dust sea un hack n' slash suguiere un sistema de combate solido y satisfactorio y el que sea un metroidvania suguiere conseguir habilidades u objetos para pasar por zonas antes inaccesibles y seguir explorando un mundo abierto, bueno, dust cumple estas dos cosas pero a medias, empecemos por el combate, asumiendo que juegas con control de xbox (que deberias, no me veo jugando este juego con teclado) con (X) ejecutas un combo basico con tu espada, mientras que con (Y) puedes o hacer variaciones del combo basico o hacer girar tu espada, levantando a los enemigos frente a ti, con los gatillos esquivas en ambas direcciones, con el bumper derecho tu compañera fidget [strike] la gatielaga para nada sexualizada [/strike] disparara un proyectil y con el bumper izquierdo usas un objeto de curacion, son controles sencillos y clasicos en los hack n' slash, pero a diferencia de estos, dust no consigue mas armas con distintos combos o habilidades y tampoco aprendes mas combos a lo largo de tu aventura, dejando como resultado un combate divertido quizas, pero con muy poca profundidad ya que repites los mismos combos una y otra vez, y en cuanto al mapa, hay varias ubicaciones ocultas y sitios a los que volver mas adelante, pero estan todas separadas entre si, por lo que se sienten mas como niveles y no un mundo, estas cosas no arruinan la experiencia y el juego es divertido y tanto el control como hallar zonas bien ocultas se siente bien, pero un sistema de combate mas complejo y un mundo interconectado le habrian hecho muchos favores

[h1] Soundtrack: [/h1] me encanta la banda sonora de este juego, se compone de un par de instrumentos nada mas pero encajan tan pero tan bien entre ellos y las canciones estan envueltas en un aura mistica y poseen un caracter unico para cada zona, temas como el de las cavernas, o el del paso del arquero se me han quedado pegadas por unos dias

[h1] Historia: [/h1] dust tiene una historia interesante cuanto menos, se nota que el juego le da mucha importancia a su historia y lore, y algunos fragmentos de dicha historia estan muy bien hechos como las estatuas del paso del arquero, aun asi, la historia central no me termina de interesar del todo, es un tanto generica y si bien hay algunos personajes simpaticos, no me he terminado de encariñar con ninguno salvo por [strike] la violable [/strike] fidget, pero ella es un caso particular

[h1] Voces: [/h1] asi es, este juego tiene actuacion de voz, y esta bastante bien, super bien diria yo, salvo algunos momentos donde las voces parecen ser un tanto exageradas o momentos que directamente dan un poco de verguenza, el doblaje en general esta muy bien hecho y las voces encajan bien con cada personaje, ademas ya es increible que un indie tenga voces, ahora que mas en cima este bien hecho es admirable

[h1] Graficos [/h1] los que me conoces ya saben que yo solo hablo de graficos cuando estan o muy bien o muy mal, en este caso estan muy muy buenos, el mundo esta dibujado a mano (excepto por algunas cosas en 3D que no terminan de encajar), las animaciones del personaje hacen que ese sistema de combate tan poco profundo sea igualmente vistoso y satisfactorio, y algunas partes del juego son simplemente preciosas, y todo esto se complemento con el hecho de que lo que no es la musica y la actuacion de voz esta hecho por una sola persona, una sola persona hizo la historia, escribio los personajes, programo el juego, diseño los niveles y dibujo cada escenario y cada frame de las animaciones, y ante estas cosas yo me arrodillo

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] Dust:an elysian tail es un juego [strike] con furros y por eso se lleva mis dieces ayudenme porfavor [/strike] excelente, mirando sus caracteristicas mas ne profundidad se pueden hallar varias cosas que simplemente podrian estar mejor pero nuevamente, este juego fue hecho por una sola persona practicamente, y a pesar de tener su edad (salio en 2012) sigue siendo divertido de jugar y yo me la he pasado tan bien que me lo he pasado al 100% en la maxima dificultad, y normalmente yo no saco logros y solo me falta uno, lo he hecho todo practicamente, asique me siento comodo dandole un 8/10

67047182.review:
Standard fare game in the metroidvania style. Has problems but you get a decent experience for the price.

On the down side: 

The pace of acquiring new skills was much too slanted, feeling like the most development happened in the last few hours of the game. Since you're using tools which feel almost identical for the majority of play, I ended up spamming the basic attack button without much need for variety.

There were a few bugs. An occasional inability to interact with NPCs, shops, or save spots, which seemed to be rectified by a quick pause-unpause. Also, for some reason the audio would occasionally stop altogether and require a reset. 

The quality of art in cutscene animations was quite noticeably poor in comparison to the fluidity and clarity of the actual gameplay.

The final chapter dropped the ball on the storytelling. Lots of Tell-Don't-Show storytelling, nonsense Magi-babble, and a flat final boss encounter.

Good:
Exploration and movement feels great with the aerial dust storm. 
Very pretty scenery and effects.
Short and sweet.
Cheap.
Really it's the cheap thing that leads me to rate the game positively.. It's not an amazing hidden gem or anything, but it gets the job done and doesn't overstay it's welcome.

66814219.review:
Overall the game feels quite clunky. The art style looked alright from screenshots, but while playing the game, the graphics seemed mediocre and reminded me of old browser games. Also, the dialogue in this game is uninteresting and got a bit annoying after a short time. Strangely, it looked like I was getting experience from talking to people, perhaps as a reward for getting through the tedious conversation.

It seems like the game is a bad port from Xbox because the UI was a bit unintuitive to navigate on PC. There were a few things that required a lot of clicking around on various buttons that could have been made much simpler. Trying to look up the controls while in game shows a diagram of an Xbox controller and a wall of text.

I will say that I am genuinely impressed that this was designed and developed by one person. Other than the points mentioned above, it seems like a pretty polished game and it was satisfying to slash and blast through waves of squishy monsters. I just wouldn't recommend it now. I was only able to handle one hour of mashing the mouse for combat and mashing the space bar to flick through the dialogue before the game crashed.

66805541.review:
I played this game a lot when it first came out in 2012 on Xbox 360...and I mean a lot.  It was one of the few games that, as an admittedly casual player, I actively hunted for achievements on.  In fact I got all of them except the one that requires you to beat the game on tough or hardcore.  At some point a couple of years later I picked up the title for Steam, and played it for a little while before setting it aside. 

Fast-forward to April 2020, and I'm browsing my library looking for a game to take my mind off things.  I'm not quite sure why my attention settled on Dust, but I'm glad it did.  This game is still a blast to play, and might be my favorite metroidvania.  I spent a few days and about 12 hours enjoying this blast from my past.  Am I going to revisit my old achievement hunter days?  Probably not...but I might go back and tidy up a few of those side quests now that I beat the game again.

66792142.review:
Solid action game disappointing Metroidvania.

The games artstyle is solid you can definitely tell that the people who made this really put alot of love into this game. the cutscenes and a few of the characters show a bit of inconsistency but overall I like it and this game has aged well so far and will continue to do so.

the story is interesting and well done I defintiely can see this game getting a sequel. voice work is well done too!

The gameplay is great when it's at it's peak but it's frustrating at it's worst. The collision for platforming was just weird for me sometimes when I tried to jump on platforms it just would not register me landing on it. I managed to remedy this by swinging my sword as my jump. (this issue is mostly fixed by the time you unlock double jump which is kinda late game [kinda frustrating] ) it feels like a 2d action game with solid combos and a great loop, though I kinda wish there was more variety in combos as you hit late game I was doing the same 3-4 combos. this game could definitely be compared to a vanillaware game (Dragons crown or Muramasa) 

the Metroidvania elements was interesting.. the abilities you unlocked for exploration weren't too interesting and the rewards just didn't make me feel enticed to get them all. the odd platforming logic did get frustrating at times.

the sidequests were for the most part pretty nice side content it encourages you to explore to find cool items and some even opened up mini areas to explore which was neat. and they did feel like the made the world more alive.

Overall solid game, good story, Solid combat (but needs more depth than just 3 combos and the magic stuff and parrying) and it's metroidvania elements while not so good can definitely be improved on! having a sequel would definitely help this series!

**disclaimer i've only played this game on normal difficulty**
this game has some good replayability too I did most sidequests and got a fair amount of treasures too so definitely worth the 10-16 or more hours of content! :)

66650836.review:
Game #111										5.4.2020.

[h1] An Xbox 360 classic on PC [/h1]

Dust: An Elysian Tail was one of the surprise indie hits back in the early 2010s that graced the Xbox 360. While Sony wasn’t too keen on pursuing indie titles, Microsoft was more than willing to invest money into indie games like this one.
Dust: An Elysian Tail was one of the best indie games back on Xbox 360 but, a few years after it was released, it was like “POOF” and everyone stopped talking about it. People still talked about Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac
https://store.steampowered.com/app/250900/The_Binding_of_Isaac_Rebirth/
 and other Indies but it seems that the Dust (HAR HAR) has settled.

Actually, the last time, before playing this, I heard someone mention Dust was when Mighty No. 9
https://store.steampowered.com/app/314710/Mighty_No_9/
 came out because people kept comparing Mighty No. 9 to Dust saying how dust had a 1-man-team, less money and was made much better than Mighty No. 9.

I had never played Dust: An Elysian Tail before despite owning an Xbox 360 and loads of indie games, so I was excited. While the game was a bit bumpy, I can safely say that Dust: An Elysian Tail is still a good game, even years later. Good but not great.

[h1] Deadly samurai in action complete with a talking sword and a cute flying companion [/h1]

On the surface, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful, hand-drawn, 2D,  metroidvania/hack-and-slash game made by a single person. Love and care ooze through this game but it doesn’t hit all it’s marks.

The game opens up with our mysterious protagonist, an anthropomorphic cat(?) (maybe fox?) with the skills of a ninja/samurai. Dust is awoken by a cute, yet slightly irritating flying critter named Fidget and a talking sword. Dust can’t remember who he is or what he has done but the sword explains that he has a role to play and Fidget decides to follow him. What transpires is a rather good story with a few surprise twists along the way. The story itself is what kept me playing until the end.

[h1] Fighting over exploration and platforming [/h1]

Let’s start with the things I didn’t like first: 

Dust is a metroidvania game but it often forgets that. You will gain some abilities that will change how you navigate through the world slightly and will have to backtrack just like in most metroidvania games. Despite this, I often forgot that I was even playing  a metroidvania since the main focus of this game is the combat. While you will have to navigate loads of grid-like map screens, you will usually be fighting on each map screen.

Fighting in this game is very fast, fluid, satisfying, fun and looks incredible… at first. After a few hours with the game, you realize that you had seen everything when it comes to fighting. The game never does much to improve the combat beyond what you initially start with. Sure, you will learn a few new abilities and a few spells, but it largely remains the same from your first battle to your last one. It looks cool, don’t get me wrong, but it’s just like watching the same action film sequence for the 20th time. Each time it looks a little less cool.

[h1] Enemies don't stand a chance against Dust [/h1]

Combat difficulty is also an issue. Enemies don’t hurt you when you walk into them, however, they do loads of damage when they hit you. That is… if they can land a hit. You see, Dust: An Elysian Tail wants you to feel like an indestructible ninja God that mows down enemies and it does this really well. You only have a light and a heavy attack and handful of combos plus a few spells and you really don’t need anything else to absolutely destroy everything on the screen. Not even a 100 enemies can stand in your way. The game tries to balance this out by having Dust be very vulnerable (it takes only a few hits to bring him down) but that’s really hard when you consider how fast and powerful Dust’s attacks are. Like I said, it gets old really fast and I found myself just mashing buttons or running past enemies during my last few hours with the game. So, in other words, Dust: An Elysian Tail plays very much like a 2D Dynasty Warriors 
https://store.steampowered.com/app/278080/DYNASTY_WARRIORS_8_Xtreme_Legends_Complete_Edition/  
game... which isn't necessarily bad.

[h1] The nice story and beautiful presentation save the game [/h1]

Now let’s talk about the things I really liked:

 The graphics are beautiful. Dust, the environment and all other characters look like Anime-styled characters. Even the pause menu screen is breathtaking (seriously, pause the game if you get it and tell me if you have ever seen a more beautiful pause menu).  The characters are voice acted beautifully, every single character.

 Dust and Fidget are really likeable characters and I genuinely wanted to see them succeed in their quest.  The game is short but offers loads of replayablity with its metroidvania styled gameplay.

The game has lots of interesting side-quests and challenges.

The game, while monotonous, is still fun to play.

[h1] More good than bad [/h1]

Overall, when it comes to good vs. bad, honestly, the scale shifts back and forth. On one hand, you have a beautiful looking game, with a great story and, at first, fun combat.

On the other hand, the combat gets stale rather fast and you end up hating the game to a point where you just want to either finish or get bored enough to quit playing it. 

I’m happy I was able to make it to the end of the game as the ending was very satisfying. 

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a good game. If you are in the mood for a beautiful metroidvania-lite game with cool, but kind-of boring combat, you won’t be disappointed. 

Next game: Dustforce
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/65300/

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I’m trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

65995626.review:
Beautiful game, beautiful story, and entertaining gameplay.

Game page tags this as a Metroidvania, but I think that this only takes that tag loosely. The game certainly has a linear feel to it, even if some previous areas can be revisited and poked at with any new abilities to find things of worth. Mostly those items are equipable weapons or armor, which... you know. The mileage you get out of those items are up to your play style.

The story follows a chapter-based progression, and after the introductory chapter you have access to a world map where you can access "levels" to start. So it's not a single, unbroken map like, say, Hollow Knight or Super Metroid or Castlevania SotN. Some of those chapters put you in situations where you cannot easily return to the main map until you progress further in, which might limit some options or force you to grind for gold and Exp.
The combat can be simplistic, and sometimes can even get to the point of being button-mashing-y. Single encounters with foes can help with learning their timing and knowing when's the right moment to set up a parry and then strike back while the foe is stunned. With encounters against multiple foes at once, you'll want to trust in a combination of your alternate and primary attacks. The timing is key otherwise you can find yourself in deep trouble really quickly.

As for the enemies... There's a basic variety of them, with some requiring more tact in order to overcome them. On higher difficulties, expect their attacks to go from "death by a thousand cuts" to "death by a hundred spiked clubs". Really recommend starting at a lower level, playing through the game at least once, and then restarting with a higher difficulty.

Highly recommend for casual gamers and game design students. No competitive scene as far as I know.

65870844.review: Great game, amazing soundtrack, fun but tight controls, a story that made me cry at one point due to story spoilers, but overall, an amazing game worth getting even at full price. and the achievements, oh so much fun to get, not that hard to get them, (except the 1000 hit, 5 star arena, and beating hardcore mode) but even then, you'll fall in love with the characters and you can even say that this game is nearly perfect...but this is all my opinion. Hopefully you all enjoyed this game as much as I did.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#319 out of 612)... it's time for Dust: An Elysian Tale.

A gorgeous 2D metroidvania with very satisfying combat, explorations and visuals. The storytelling also seems interesting enough to keep playing, though the anthropomorphic character design might annoy some. Of particular note are the RPG mechanics which provide a nice layer of character progression -- as you explore the world and map everything out in your head, you're simultaneously growing stronger, making the frequent retreading that plagues the metroidvania genre become less and less of an annoyance the further you progress through the game.

64877949.review:
Metroidvania with many flaws.

On the good side this game has beautiful graphics and sound.

But on the bad side...

Combat is a repetitive mess. A group of five enemies appears and you spam two or three combos. Repeat this forever. Sometimes I wish there were less enemies and more platform action. Most of these enemies won't die by the first hit. There is this particular movement that makes you fly and it is overpowered. It is a boss killer and can make you fly 30 meters in the air (why?).

Item shopping and creation is redundant. They should have chosen one the systems. Sometimes you can a super armor which renders useless all items in shop. Why so many items. I didn't get to use most of them.

Maps are way too big. It's partly a walking simulator, but overflowed with enemies. Even the towns are big. Walk hundreds of screens, again and again. This is particularly the worst error, since it delays the game and makes it artificially longer, and boring.

Sometimes the map has traps so it can throw you back to the ground. This resembles very old videogames which made you repeat long sections of platforms. Maybe the developer had some influence on old unfair videogames.

Some puzzles are very arbitrary. There is one where you need an explosive pineaaple, but you cannot take the one that it's near, since it has a countdown of 3. You have to use it to open a passage and get a second pineapple with a countdown of 10. This is ridiculous, because it forces the player to make a detour. Why not make the first pineapple to have a countdown of 10? To annoy the player and make him do EXACTLY as the developer planned. Why not plan something more logic?

Poison and fire burns are some other mechanics that would have been better left out. At least with poison there is plenty of heal from drops. But you need to buy icecream for the fireburns and you only have one slot for a quick item, which should always be a healing one with a lot of stock. Instead, you have twenty different healing items. This abundance is actually annoying.

I lost interest on the sidequests and centered on the main story. But it has a slow development and a revelation that stands as very trivial.  It's as if you were being used. 

Cutscenes are kind of modest. It would have been better to use the game engine.

There is a tremendous amount of filler dialogs. You can even skip most of the dialog windows and you will still understand what is going on. This is the trademark of filler.

Story is like: [spoiler]help village, kill boss, help underground village, kill boss, help grandma (WHY), kill boss, get to village, lead LONG charge, kill final boss[/spoiler].

Bosses are cheese with the flying attack.

Final enemy is a nuissance: four phases on four different maps.

64016581.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a fantastic metroidvania set in a world of antropomorphic animals, with a great story that manages to have a few emotional moments, as well as great action.

The game begins with your character, Dust, waking up in the middle of a forest, with no memory of his past, and having summoned a magical sword, the sword of Ahrah. He's also joined by the guardian of the sword, a nimbat (a small flying creature) named Fidget. Hoping to find answers about his past, he embarks on a quest to help the people of this world.

The game plays like a traditional 2D metroidvania. While you start with limited abilities, as you progress you unlock more and more abilities that help you not only in combat, but also to traverse the environment, even allowing you to return to previous areas and find secret paths and such. The combat is pretty challenging; playing on the second hardest difficulty was tough at the start, as I could go down with only a few hits, and although you get stronger as you progress, even the late game enemies can provice a fair challenge.

The setting, like I mentioned in the opening paragraph, is a fantastic world of antropomorphic animals. While most of the villages you find seem to draw inspiration from ancient Japanese towns, there's still technology to be found, alongside magic. All of this combined makes for an interesting setting, not to mention that there's many different regions you'll be visiting. The soundtrack does a good job at setting the mood as well, and the hand-painted art style is phenomenal.

I had a great time with this game, and I can easily recommend it.

63952675.review: The art is fantastic and the story is well plotted out, it keeps you guessing and entertained throughout. The characters are all dynamic and multidimensional. Game play is fun, the player choices affecting outcome is a nice touch and ties into the main plot nicely. The soundtrack is epic. Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tale is a fantastic play and worth every minute. I would recommend to anyone who loves a beautiful story.

63504643.review:
Here we have a game that ain't exactly perfect but certainly has enough fun to keep you entertained if you're willing to make that purchase. "Dust and Elysian Tail" is a enjoyable 2D hack and slash action RPG that looks and plays amazingly. You'll be just amazed on how fluid this game is and how much damage you'll be able to rack up as the game goes on and you start to make Dust more powerful. It can be quite the spectacle that fits in with a lot of other bigger names in the action Genre. 

It's failings however come with the story, as you go through a quite cliche and uninspired tale of this skilled warrior with amnesia trying to find out "Who He is" and typically this type of simple done story is fine as long as they don't play it too straight, Dust however plays its story very straight with the only bouts of humor being in the sidequests and small ramblings of his nimbat partner Fidget. This makes the story kinda disappointing and a low point of the game, though if you don't care about story this won't be too much of a deal breaker.

Small spoiler warning here.

[spoiler]The other major problem lies in a major difficulty spike towards the end of the adventure that expects that you've done a lot when you might have merely been playing through the game just trying to enjoy the story without going through the motions of equipping items and gear and not doing too many sidequests or grinding levels. This sort of comes out of nowhere with no prior warning which might turn off new players. [/spoiler]

Overall while not a complete 100% example of indie game quality in every area, Dust an Elysian Tail will manage to keep those looking for a beautiful stylish 2D game, just don't go in expecting to get super engrossed by the story.

62474281.review:
[h1]Un juegazo furro.[/h1]
[u]Resumido/TL;DR[/u] - Eres alguien en busca de su propia identidad, saber quien es y su destino en el mundo, te acompañarán una espada parlante llamada Ahrah y una [strike]Tails[/strike] guardiana llamada Fidget.
Su combate te podrá recordar a juegos como Devil May Cry, y su estilo artístico a el Dreamworks de antes de los 2000, si te gustan los Action-RPG, este juego lo debes de probar.

[b]Historia[/b]
Para no dar spoilers, eres alguien en busca de su identidad real, con un pasado del cual ha tenido mucha sangre inocente de por medio; Con ayuda de Ahrah y Fidget te llevarán a esa verdad. [spoiler]Todo trata de una guerra por puro racismo/discriminación hacia otra especie, "Sanguilunos".[/spoiler]

[b]Combate[/b]
Como ejemplo, podría ponerte el de Devil May Cry, lleno de accion y combos que puede ser un non-stop de acción masacrando enemigos.

[b]Voces[/b]
Las voces de los personajes son de lo mejor. sin más que decir.

[b]Arte y Música[/b]
A nivel artístico, parece una película animada a mano de Dreamworks, con paisajes y escenarios muy bonitos; es un juego furro, así que puedes irte esperando animales antropomorficos parlanchines.
A nivel musical, no se aprecia mucho si estás en combate, pero puedo decirte que es muy buena y va con las circunstancias de juego.

[b]Opinion[/b]
Si te gustan los juegos llenos de accion, historia llena de magia, guerras y momentos que te hagan entristecerte y/o asombrarte, personajes divertidos, coloridos y que sean furros, con música que va de la mano con el ambiente, este juego te gustará.

Me encantaría una secuela del mismo...

[i]Fidget me parece la mas simpatica en mi opinion[/i] <3

A fantasic 2D sidescroller RPG. Solidly done across the board, even difficulty curve, gorgeous music and very decent visuals; above all a very well thought out storyline.

EDIT - Yknow, i should give this a proper review. Especially now that i finally beat it on max difficulty.

Gameplay - 9.5/10 - Excellent 2D sidescrolling adventure story, one that i would maybe add a few combat moves. Only thing I could penalise it on, and this is petty, is Id love to see a few more levels at the top end to make up for the amount of grinding you do. Its my one sorta petty beef with any game that has grinding - you never get to spend ENOUGH time at your top end once youve maxed out to kick ass and take names. TOS does this too.

Audio - 10/10 Oh. Dear. Gods. Absolute audio bliss, from start to finish. Easily one of the best audio experiences you will have, better than even Unknown Worlds or Sonic CD, both in music and SFX. Absolutely PERFECT.

Graphics - Again, for what it is? 10/10. Exceedingly well done, graphics that hold up VERY Easily even today. Eye Candy, with a camera that knows when to be close and when not to be.

Story - 10/10. The only thing you wish, is for the next part. Amazing story that sucks you in and holds you throughout. If yer not a furry fan, this game will likely convert you. It is THAT Damn GOOD.

Overall -- 9.75/10. As close to perfection as you are likely to find in this genre, bar none.

Antes de nada cabe mencionar que el hecho de que este juego haya sido creado por solo una persona, es algo totalmente increible y meritorio. No obstante, como jugadores, no estamos aqui para dar palmadas en la espalda ni para juzgar el merito de un juego, sino para jugar y entretenernos. 
Visualmente muy bonito, buenos colores, buenos efectos de sonido y banda sonora que cumple. Hasta ahi bien. Lo malo viene en todo lo demás, y no quiero decir que sea malo en si, sino que simplemente es un juego regularcillo. Los combates, se limitan a machacar un boton, aunque tambien hay combos, dejan de tener sentido al no tener ninguna ventaja frente a machacar el boton de ataque. El diseño de los personajes, es comprensiblemente poco inspirado, siendo todos ellos "animalitos" humanoides. De hecho el personaje principal parece que es una modificacion hecha a partir de la cara de Knuckes de la saga Sonic.
La historia no es ninguna maravilla tampoco, no transmite gran cosa ni emoción en casi ningun momento.

A los pocos minutos de juego la relacion entre los personajes es de confianza excesiva, siendo poco creible, algunos dialogos tiene un tufillo bastante infantiloide, y algunos intentos de hacer humor rozan un poco la vergüenza ajena. Para mi la conclusion, es que hay miles y miles de juegos mejores, pese al gran merito que tiene haberlo hecho un solo tío. Peeeeeeeero, se nota demasiado cuando los juegos son hechos por profesionales.

None of that would matter if the gameplay were good, but it's at best mediocre. 59508031.review:
[h1][quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]Sigue a "La Cruceta Inquieta"[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote][/h1]

"Braid", "Super Meat Boy", "Bastion", "Fez" (ya entenderéis por qué los menciono), "Dust: an Elysian Tail" y, seguramente, alguno más que se me escapa, pertenecen a aquella ya lejana y casi mitificada primera hornada de videojuegos indie que, a través de innovación, lograron transformar lo que pudiera ser una desventaja en lo que prácticamente hoy día es ya un género en sí mismo que llega hasta a trascender cualquier consideración presupuestaria. Todos ellos sin excepción conservan su vigencia intacta y, aunque con reservas, no es diferente el caso para "Dust: an Elysian Tail".

Si atendemos a su argumento, el videojuego que nos ocupa parte de la ya tan manida trama basada en la pérdida de memoria de un personaje que está llamado a ser héroe tanto en la lucha frente a un adversario mayor como en la lucha con su pasado. No obstante, y dejando de lado cualquier consideración subjetiva, es justo reconocerle que cuenta con una trama con giros y más desarrollada de lo que suele ser usual en el género "metroidvania", contando además con multitud de líneas de diálogo e incluso con animaciones casi en el sentido más tradicional de la palabra. Así, enlazando con este aspecto, de su apartado artístico tan alabado en su momento cabe destacar tanto unos escenarios dibujados a mano como unos personajes y efectos tridimensionales (2.5D, podría decirse) que imitan a la perfección el aspecto de dibujo animado; y en esto, al igual que sucede con el argumento, los gustos de cada uno darán mayor o menor valor al resultado final porque, personalmente y apreciando el notorio esfuerzo puesto en él, me hace recordar demasiado a cierto tipo de dibujos de animales antropomórficos tan de moda en los años noventa y que, si bien funcionaban como entretenimiento infantil, se apoyaban en un apartado artístico bastante pobre.

Respecto a su banda sonora y efectos de sonido podría decirse más o menos lo mismo que con los anteriores apartados: acompaña más o menos bien pero no resulta memorable en ningún caso y sólo destaca la poco común en estos juegos inclusión de voces (en inglés) en todas y cada una de sus líneas de diálogo.  

Por último, el "gameplay" que suele ser el apartado a destacar en cualquier "metroidvania" que se precie, en este caso resulta un poco complicado de encasillar en tal subgénero ya que se enfoca tal vez en demasía en la acción; teniendo, por supuesto, bastante de "backtracking", exploración, misiones secundarias y "plataformeo", pero menos del que debiera en comparación con tantos momentos de combate. Esto en ningún caso es malo si su vocación es la de ser un juego de acción, pero, como fan de los metroidvania, deja un sabor un tanto amargo al ver que con un mayor equilibrio se podría haber aspirado a un videojuego mucho más completo. Reflejo de esto son los escasos poderes ("upgrades") a los que tendremos acceso y que dan como resultado una menor atención en cuanto a la exploración de los escenarios, dejando todo el peso de las mejoras a las estadísticas de nuestro equipamiento y a un sistema de niveles claramente enfocado al combate. Además, éste último y ya sea contra enemigos regulares como contra jefes, resulta bastante sencillo en niveles de dificultad bajos cuando nuestro personaje posee unas estadísticas con las que ser capaz de arrasar con todo sin prestar apenas atención a lo que sucede en pantalla, lo cual, por cierto, muchas veces resultará bastante caótico, pero ciertamente disfrutable. 

En resumidas cuentas, "Dust: an Elysian Tail" resulta ser un juego con un apartado artístico, como poco, singular y una jugabilidad muy entretenida pero que, como "metroidvania", aqueja un enfoque demasiado orientado hacia la acción, la cual, aunque satisfactoria, podría haber ajustado algo mejor su dificultad. Si buscas más acción que exploración, juégalo en modo duro o extremo; y si lo que buscas está más relacionado con la exploración de escenarios y la búsqueda de secretos, puede que el modo normal te sea más que suficiente.

59135144.review:
If you like platform and action games then you will like this for sure. The thing that I probably enjoy the most in this game was the action, the movement and the combos are so fluid and dynamic that I never got boring of killing enemies. The story is another positive point, simple but addictive and touching, the amount of side quests and its complexity I think are done just right there are not a ridiculous amount of it, as well as collectables spread throughout the map, that kind of made you forget the main story.
As for downsides there are not many, I found the second half of the game way easier than the first half, that's because at some point I was to overleveled for the mobs and I also had plenty of recovery items even without buying any, which basically made me more careless about the way I played.
The collectables and side quests that I mentioned above, apart from a rare few, most of them do not reward you the you probably expect to and they do not add any to the development of your character.
Last those same combos and fighting style that I mentioned above, well in my case I loved it, but those combos are pretty much the same throughout the game so I can understand if someone might actually get boring at some point.

Overall I think it is a great game and is worth your money 8/10

59084538.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is an incredible and beautiful Metroidvania game. All right what’s the story.

The world is in chaos, monsters have attacked and innocent people are being killed, for no reason other than who they are. But one man has come to save the people and punish the guilty and the man’s name is Dust, but who is Dust.

That is what he wants to know, as he journeys through the land with his new friends a Nimbat named Fidget and a talking sword named Ahrah. As they go to save the world.

All right the likes, Well to start the story is really, really amazing, from its themes and its twists and turns to it’s funny and light hearted moments. It’s so amazing and really well made. The cutscenes in the game were all so really well made.

Then there is the art style and it’s really, really beautiful from forests to underground caves to even a haunted graveyard and beyond it’s all really gorgeous and it’s hand-painted which makes it even more incredible, especially you all the little touches.

Then we have the characters, they were really good, my two fav’s are Fidget, because she is so adorable and funny and Dust, he is badass and has a sharp wit and he can be funny too.

The voice acting is really well done from are main characters to even the NPC’S its really well acted. The game play and combat was really good, fast paced and fun, the music was really good too. 

And the best was all the little touches from the notes you could pick up, the side quests you can do. The mini game you can play and the sound effects like the rain falling and even the snow crunching as you walk on it.

Okay as you know from my other reviews this is the part where I talk about what is bad or what to dislike about the game. But there is really nothing bad about the game.

All those if you had to ask me, the game did crash on me but that was one time. And I would have liked two or three more unique bosses to fight, but that is just me.

Now with that said and done with, Dust: An Elysian Tail is an incredible and beautiful Metroidvania game, with so much to love from the story to the art style and to the characters. 

I highly, highly, highly recommend this game. If you’re a fan of Metroidvania games you will positively love this game.

58807044.review:
Dust: an elysian tail,es un juego que desconocia totalmente,hasta que lei de su existencia por un foro de internet. Tras ver algun video de el, he informarme del juego,me decidi a comprarlo en rebajas.Y seamos sincero,ha sido ponerse a jugar  y hasta que no lo he terminado, no he jugado a ninguna otra cosa.

 El juego estaria clasificado dentro del genero  de acción-aventura y exploración estilo Metroidvania, que requiere que el jugador gane aumentos de poder en las habilidades de Dust (nuestro protagonista), para así llegar a nuevas áreas. El estilo de combate está basado en mecánicas de tipo brawler, en donde Dust puede usar una combinación de espada y la magia de Fidget para derrotar a los enemigos.

En el aspecto positivo del juego estaria su musica(de echo se puede comprar la banda sonora del juego por internet),la opcion de poder dar los puntos de habilidad cada vez que subes de nivel donde tu quieres, y sobre todo un detalle que me ha parecido muy interesante, es el sistema de herrería. Al igual que en casi todos los juegos, podremos reunir materiales para fabricar piezas de equipo más poderosas de las que solemos encontrar en una tienda (siempre que tengamos el patrón correspondiente), pero se ha implementado de tal forma que no hará falta farmear un mismo material durante horas para conseguir los objetos necesarios.

En el aspecto negativo,esta que hay partes que no puedes pasar,( te sale una barrera roja) y no desaparece esa barrera,  hasta que matas a los enemigos de la pantalla.Pues bien,hay veces que si vas muy rapido por la pantalla,(es decir con la tormenta de dusk),dusk atravesara la barrera sin tener que matar a los enemigos. En el modo normal, la dificultad es aceptable,pero de vez en cuando, dicha dificultad sube bastante y toca repetir.Y quiza para los que no le gusten este tipo de juegos, se pueda hacer repetitivo.

A modo de anecdota,los personajes del juego tienen un aire al solatorobo red hunter de la nds,pero eso si,con mejores graficos.Un gran juego Dust an elysian tail

57553197.review:
Ok, the quality of animation is quite good, we can get that out of the way. 
The game is a bit on the weird furry anime vibe, but the graphics are well done.

The voice acting is passable.

The story is meh.

The rest however, is bad:
- Gameplay is very repetitive, and not fun.
- Combat is shallow and boring, a real chore. Towards the end they start adding a LOT of noise to the screen, sort of confirming that all you're supposed to do is mash buttons since you're not even expected to know what's happening.
- Platforming is awkward. The controls feel overly responsive and not responsive because of how the game choses to drop inputs depending on frame state and how it computes "momentum", added to attacks homing into random enemies.
- The inventory is basically numbers, and the crafting system is a complete grindy failure.
- The sound effects... The sampling is technically good, but the choices are abysmal. Hopefully this was a learning experience for whoever was in charge. But I don't think they played the finalized game before it was released.

57333901.review:
SPOILER WARNING

I love the art style of the game, the soundtrack, and MOST of the story. The fact that Gaius focused so much time trying to figure out what his closest friend and best assassin was doing, basically opposing him, instead of just going and exterminating the moonbloods with his supposedly overpowered army THEN going after his supposed old friend means that he has nothing better to do. This is a problem since it means that your ultimate goal, stop the wiping out of the moonbloods, is basically impossible if not for Gaius' sheer incompetence or unwillingness to order his army to advance, unwillingness to do it without his closest friend to be there to witness their victory that they promised each-other they'd have. 
This is only solved if Gaius literally arrived at the moonblood camp at roughly same time as Dust did, which would make sense in a scenario such as this one. The scouts in the mountains could have had additional spies hiding to keep tabs on the scouts, they could have switched the object of their focus to Dust when he killed the mountain scouts and followed him to the moonblood camp. They report back to Gaius that they have found the moonblood camp and Gaius moves his army to the final area of the game, final boss, etc.
But this is just my opinion of the story of the game, the gameplay is easy enough except for some instances of "I PARRIED! WHY DID IT NOT REGISTER!" or "COME ON I JUMPED! I DID IT RIGHT THIS TIME WHY AM I STILL HITTING THE SPIKES!" the game is a fun, relativly easy, slice and dice game with a nice touch of parcore that had great voice actors for all of its characters and amazing art and animation to go with it. It is very easily one of my favorite games and I recommend it to anyone who likes shoot-em-ups, platformers, great art and voice, good story or people such as Shadiversidy.

56196784.review:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a fantastic hand drawn metroidvania with brawler mechanics.  The animations are beautiful, really capturing the spirit of anime, in video game format.  You can play the game however you wish, with your companion Fidget, even joking early on, to just mash the buttons, but if you can pull off combos, mobs will fall faster.  The main story has you traversing 7 unique maps, each of which are hand painted.  

The storyline is good, but felt a bit too restrained, considering it's about mass genocide of another race.  You play as a Dust, your typical amnesiac protagonist who's trying to figure out who he really is.  When you reach Aurora Village, you discover that General Gaius, the game's main antagonist, has been waging a campaign to exterminate the Moonblood race, and such to prevent further atrocities you set your targets on him.

Dust is incredibly nimble to control.  Being able to fly across the map while auto targeting enemies made Dust untouchable in the sky.  Once on the ground you have access to combo attacks and parries to quickly eliminate anything standing in your path.  Single-handedly taking out an entire map of monsters in a single combo feels so satisfying.

55896584.review: a fun game that makes you feel cool while playing it.

55838161.review:
This is a Metroid-Vania with a very strong foundation. The gameplay is fun thanks to an excellent combat system and the story is entertaining to experience thanks to its memorable main characters. Unfortunately, the game is limited by certain facets that are not necessarily bad, but that are not necessarily good either.

Let's start with the main positive: the combat. While there's not a lot of combos to speak of, what is there is so damn fun. The saying "Easy to learn, hard to master" doesn't really apply to this game. It's more like….. "easy to learn, satisfying to execute" since combos are never too difficult to carry out, but they still look really cool. For example, your bread and butter air combo is 

Light attack --? heavy attack (rising upper) --> 3x light attack --> heavy attack --> 3x light attack --> heavy attack --> repeat.

The above is not that hard to carry out, but the reason it's so satisfying is that the heavy attack in mid-air will cause you to do an air grab on the enemy, causing you to slam them into the ground, "bouncing" you and the enemy into the air so that you can do the whole thing over again. That air grab is just so damn satisfying to watch. For a long time it made me go like "GET DOWN THERE BITCH" :D . 

The above works for any enemies that you can grab. What about enemies that you can't grab (i.e. enemies that are bigger than you)? Well, that's what the heavy attack is for. In this game, the heavy attack is a very satisfying "spinning" move. When you use it on the ground, you spin your sword in a circle, rapidly damaging any enemies caught in it. When you do it in the air, you become a spinning tornado of death :D :D :D. So for big enemies, you simply have to jump, hold the heavy attack button, and move left and right (i.e. if the enemy attacks right, go to their left side, and vice versa) until the enemy is dead. While this move is super powerful, it's balanced by the fact that you can't do it forever. If you use this move for too long, you will take damage and will be forced to stop using it. Kind of like overheating. 

While I listed 2 optimal ways to deal with enemies, the game has the flexibility to create your own combos so you can create your own fun. It helps that the heavy attack acts like a sort of "skill cancel". Having said all this, that doesn't mean that the game's enemies are pushovers…… Ok some of them are BUT some enemies require specific ways to beat them:

	• There's an enemy that you have to parry (hold attack the moment they attack) in order to damage them
	• There's an enemy that you have to stun with magic first before attacking
	• There's an enemy that can only be damaged with magic attacks
	• Etc.

You will have noticed that I said "magic". Yea, there's magic in this game. It costs energy, and you also use energy to dodge. Because it does so little damage in the beginning, you mostly don't use it and it's a better idea to save the energy to dodge. However, in the late game magic becomes absolutely broken. This is because you can get loot that MULTIPLIES your magic stat by 3. You can equip 2 of these items for a total boost of 9 times. This is end game equipment, but once you get it….. Holy shit. Magic pretty much becomes the default best way to kill any enemy. This is because when you combine it with your heavy attack, it becomes a massive damage AOE. All of you have to do is hold heavy attack and press the magic button, and watch the screen fill with pretty colors. There's 3 different magic to choose from, so you can choose 3 different colors depending on your mood :P.

While the combat is great, there's certain weaknesses in the game that limit its potential:
	• Bosses are too easy: All bosses are about your size, meaning they can be grabbed. They also get stunned on any weapon it. Therefore, it's very easy to constantly air grab them until they. When they take a certain amount of damage, they briefly become invulnerable, allowing them to use an attack. Still, that invulnerability only lasts for 1 attack, so you can just go back to juggling them. Most bosses are over in like….. 1-2 minutes tops. 
	• Loot is just stat boosts: All loot are just stat boosts. The problem with this is that you'll always know that the end game loot will be better than any loot you find in the early to mid-game, so why bother exploring? Just keep going through the main storyline and only explore once you have all the movement abilities. Unfortunately, at this point most of the loot you'll find will be worthless, so the exploring aspect of the Metroidvania genre is severely crippled in this game.
	• Levelling up is streamlined: You level up in this game, but you're not free to choose how you spend your stat points. All stats have to be within 4 points with each other. This means that you can't really create a "build" and a character that you create will likely be exactly the same as anyone else's' character.

In regards to story, there's a main story that's broken up into smaller side stories. The main story is about your character Dust and figuring out who you are. Along the way, you're accompanied by a talking sword, Ahrah, and a flying sidekick named Fidget. These characters are absolutely fantastic, especially Fidget. She's so god damn funny xD. For example, in the very beginning you face your first enemy, and Ahrah is all calm and says "Dust, focus. Remember what you've learned thus far" and Fidget is like "NO NO. MASH THE BUTTONS! DO SOMETHING!!!!" I laughed so hard. This game has plenty of fourth wall breaking humour, and I just love it. I also love these characters personalities. Dust is the sarcastic but generally well-mannered protagonist. Ahrah is the calm old Sensei. Fidget is a hyper-active child (she constantly refers to bad guys as "meanie"). These 3 make for a wonderful trio :D :D :D.

Unfortunately, while the main characters are very entertaining to watch, the same cannot be said for any of the side characters, and the story suffers for it. The story is about you ending the campaign of General Gaius, whose goal is to eradicate all Moonbloods from the world. In trying to achieve this goal, you'll defeat a guy whose trying to kill all Warmbloods as revenge for General Gaius killing all Moonbloods, bring back water to the world from an entity that stopped it in an attempt to kill Gaius's soldiers, and learn who are you and what your connection to Gaius is. These stories are focused around OTHER characters, and so whenever something happens to them, you end up not really caring. That's because there's just no character building done for any of the other characters. For example, there's a side character that dies near the middle of the game, and I suspect that the developer wanted me to care that he died…. But I just didn't. While the script is great and the developer is trying to get some good lessons across such as "sometimes your best isn't enough", none of it really sticks. Even General Gaius, the main villain of the story, does not get any character development. All you know is that he's trying to kill all Moonbloods, but you don't know why and you don't know anything about HIM. Therefore, the final boss battle ended up being way less epic than it should've been. You're fighting someone who was your friend in the past, but there's no weight to any of it because the game didn't show me any of that history or who this final boss was a person. The voice acting is great though and there's some great lines such as "I remember everything…. AND IT CHANGES NOTHING!!!" and "THIS IS WHERE IT ENDS GAIUS". Top quality stuff.

Overall, this is a great game with great characters. It was entertaining to play throughout the experience and entertaining to watch the main characters interact with each other. Easy bosses, average progression system, and poor character development hold the game back from achieving its full potential. Regardless, this is still an excellent game.

55615129.review:
Welcome to Furries vs. Scalies, the fighting game of the century.

More seriously, I'm not very good at games like this, but I still beat normal difficulty with no fuss (the final boss was kind of a pushover) and I'm working through the hardest difficulty. It turns out that if you focus on attack stat like I do (and you probably should if you want the fights to not take forever), simply flying back and forth in a swirl of blades trivializes almost all fights, especially aerial ones. Most of the time, if I'm doing something different, I'm spamming melee swings or am facing something that requires me to parry. Environmental hazards have killed me way more than monsters.

So yeah. This isn't a hard game, and cranking up the difficulty seems to just make it a little more important to grind some extra levels, which I haven't stopped to do. (I haven't done any grinding yet.)

And can we talk about the story and dialogue for  a moment? I got vicarious mood whiplash from all the about-faces of attitude almost every time I talked through a conversation with someone, even on the game-spanning main quest. Especially on the main quest. The overarching plot is kind of meh. The protagonist is kind of lacking in personality, and that's a shame because having a strong personality despite lack of memory would be a fascinating way to play with the story and probably do better things with the currently-bland amnesia plot.

I've had fun, though, probably because I'm a huge sucker for pseudo-RPG "character advancement" and the action is tailored less for elite action junkies and more for, you know, anyone else. It's pretty accessible, if bland.

Mediocre is still pretty good some days, I guess.

I'll give this a "sure, whatever distracts you from mortality" and recommend against buying at full price.

55321820.review:
It again and again amazes me to learn that games like Dust have been made mostly by one person alone. And I loved playing Dust. A fast, fluent platformer with role play elements, many many secrets to find, beautiful animations, well made, relatively large levels, a pleasant soundtrack and even a good story... what else could I wish for? 

Challenge, maybe. I always play my games on normal difficulty because I believe that's how the developers intend for their games to be played. But looking back, I should have played on hard maybe. And guys, I am not saying this to show off and brag with how skilled and hardcore I am. I am just a totally average player, and it's a simple fact that in Dust you level up very quick, and thanks to your skill points and weapon/armor upgrades it won't take you super long to become very very powerful. And especially if you try to find as many secret treasures as you can, which goes along with a lot of back tracking, you level up even faster and towards the end you become a one punch killer machine. Killing mobs with one strike, fine, but when you kill huge giants with just one hit, it feels a bit... underwhelming. 

But this is actually my only complaint about this otherwise awesome, enchanting game. Metroidvania and platformer fans definitely should give it a try!

55254746.review:
I absolutely loved this games, from the emotional story to the aesthetic to the super-responsive and fluid combat that really captures the fantasy of being an agile combo fighter.

Some say the combat is repetitive, and I'll admit that it could use more enemies forcing you to change your approach.

But I'd compare it to the Batman Arkham games' combat if you've played them, since the feel is similar despite the mechanics being very different.

In both you have some variety of tools, but you'll be reusing some bread and butter approaches that feel satisfying to master and mix things up with.

If you pay attention and your reflexes are quick, you'll rarely find yourself in a place where you can't dodge out of danger.

But if you love getting into the flow of taking down crooks as Batman - or slashing across the screen on the ground and in the air as Dust - you'll love both games.

If the combat feels stale, you probably won't.

Here's an old one. I recently played through this for the first time after not touching it for many, many years.
Dust hasn't aged gracefully. Some of it is just plain ugly to look at. Some of it is beautiful though too. It's an odd duck as far as art goes. Like it's from that post-paint era. You can definitely tell it's an indie game.
What's great about Dust though is the gameplay. When all else fails, the gameplay is legit still very solid. The first 5 hours are kind of slow, but once you start getting your powers and Dust becomes better equipped to take down some enemies, things get fun. The end couple of areas are some prime examples of sidescrolling fighting done gracefully.
The story is okay. Weak at first, great in the later half of the game. The music is alright, nothing amazing. The voice acting is passable.... and... well... all and all I recommend Dust: An Elysian Tale. With a bigger budget and the right steps taken, a sequel could be pretty stellar. I doubt we'll get one though.

This game really satisfies that feeling of "one man army", it's almost like a 2D Dynasty Warriors to an extent. You play as a samurai who proceeds to get more and more mobile and powerful via story events and a pseudo-metroidvania styled action RPG system. The combat in this game is like playing as a tornado, at least on Normal difficulty. You'll literally be flying around the map flinging near screen wiping spells and proceeding to slash and slam peons and fling them into the air. Sure, you might encounter a few brick walls which may challenge you as a metaphorical tornado, but in the end, you're still a fucking tornado, and you'll win the 1 vs 1000 fight 50% of the time, every time. The story is surprisingly well written with a slight tinge of Eastern influence that brings it up, and a peculiar amount of world building that comes from the characters as well. Speaking of the characters though, a lot of people critique about two things:
[olist]
    [*] The uncomfortable nature of anthropomorphic animals
    [*] Amateur but unprofessional voice acting
[/olist]

I don't have a problem with either of the two things listed, however I respect that other people may be put off by this. I would say however that those two points are really the only "obvious flaws" that the game has. The game is rock solid in everything else. Definitely a get.

54333197.review:
Dust is a damn impressive game for being mostly designed by one person. I remember thinking it was a bit too easy on my first playthrough years ago. However, more recently, I decided to revisit and bump up the difficulty to see if my impression changes; and it did, but maybe not for the best. I am having to consciously manage my actions and inventory a good deal more than the previous playthrough. However, I had to reset the game for my Tough playthrough because I was building my character a certain way and the game just became ruined when after like 5-6 hours, enemies that really can only take projectile damage show up. It absolutely crushed the pace of the game to the point where it made more sense to restart than just tweak my build. Even after changing the way I leveled up, I kind of felt that it almost would have made sense to use the 'auto-level' option instead of risking mistakes that can ruin a playthrough. That gripe aside, the story is pretty entertaining and the writing strikes a really solid balance between lighthearted and serious. The voice acting talent is high quality, also, for being an indie game.

A couple of other cons after completing my Tough playthrough: exploration for the full map and treasure can really only realistically be done when you are about 95% done with the game, which kind of sucks for a Metroidvania. The lack of convenient, faster travel across the map is also a disappointment and makes the game pace really slog the further along you get.

Overall, this game is worth at least a playthrough on normal for the art and story, especially if you like metroidvanias. Given it's a been a number of years since release, it's frequently on sale for a low price, so there is a low cost to entry for a few hours of decent gameplay.

Absolutely loved this game.  I typically don't write reviews, so please forgive me for the brevity of this review.

The artwork / visuals of the game are absolutely beautiful.
The visuals along with the soundtrack help to make the game very immersive, and I noticed multiple times that I had stayed up until 2-3 am playing when I normally stop around 11-12.

The combat system feels solid, though I noticed there are definitely a few ways to make life WAY easier in the long run based on which stats you choose to focus on (won't spoil that though).

Puzzles / getting to 100% of each area sometimes took a bit of pure exploration and guess and check, very much like Metroidvania style games.  I enjoyed the challenge, and was proud of myself for reaching items in inventive ways without having the later skills that I should have actually used to get them!

Ultimately, I would give this game a 9/10.  I will most likely replay it again, but I don't see huge replay value, or I would have given it a 10/10.





** SPOILER BELOW **

For the extra challenge... try leading enemies to areas above an item that appears you need double jump / super jump to access, and then whirlwind up toward that enemy.  I was able to access many items much earlier by 'dragging' enemies to the right spots lol.

54275955.review:
Difficulty selection in the beginning only increases damage taken as far as I see. Boss fights are very easy and most of your deaths would be fighting trash mobs that one shot you throughout the course of the entire game regardless of how many points you put into life and/or defense. 

I honestly would not recommend high difficulty to even hard-core platformers such as myself just to save you the agony and it does not introduce any real difficulty to the game.

I was so bored with this game, I was basically at the end of the game and I haven't bothered to launch the game to finish it, and honestly, probably won't. The combat at first seemed interesting, but then every single encounter in the game was basically: Launch enemy in the air using same weak weak strong attack w/e combo use magic and spin in the air. The counter mechanic is very generous. Often times I miss it because I tried to get a frame perfect timing. Game looked promising in the beginning where you were forced to counter the big mini boss golem thing and the game had potential but the difficulty did not increase at all throughout the game in terms of mechanical difficulty. Of course, enemies leveled up and did more damage. That was it. It was pretty mind numbingly frustrating to die 20 minutes past a checkpoint from some one shot ability. 

Also, if you play on high difficulty I'd highly recommend you put stats into the magic damage ability because at one point of the game you are forced to use it to kill a necromancer enemy. I did not have it and it literally took 10-15 minutes of constant fighting and dodging to kill it and there were multiple occasions I had to do it. Bad game design to do that but it was my fault for trying to not get one shot and have most points in life/defense.

54113875.review:
So, I finally got around to playing this game. It's short, but a worthwhile experience, in my opinion. All things considered, it's not actually that great a game, but I found it very enjoyable nonetheless.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a short, hand-crafted work that you can tell its creators put their hearts into. These kinds of games have much more "soul" than most AAA releases out there, but usually come with their own issues.

I'll start with the negative. I think the worst thing about the game is the size of the holes left in its story. The pace and execution of the story itself is not bad. In fact, it's engaging and, most importantly, it was fairly unpredictable. However, the game is very short, and therefore the story is too. Unfortunately, while the writer(s) came up with a very interesting and engaging story, the length seemingly disallowed them from expanding on critical parts of it. Though I suspect it might also have been some negligence, too. While the main protagonist's course is clear, the main antagonist has no background. We are presented with a situation on a grand scale, but the foundation for it, as well as the ramifications, are not covered. The story solely focuses on the main protagonist's personal journey, without regard for developing the rest of the story.

Besides the story issues, I would say the combat, while fun, is not actually all that complex once you figure out how to abuse certain combos. It has a very fast-paced combat system that feels really awesome to play with. It's also very easy to pick up, with minimal control inputs. The depth that there is largely comes from movement interactions with the signature Dust Storm technique. However, by the end of the game, I was basically doing nothing but using Dust Storm... which kind of makes the rest of the kit redundant. This leads me to the final negative: the difficulty. I decided to play on "Tough" mode (the modes are Casual, Normal, Tough, Hardcore). In retrospect, I should have picked Hardcore. Most dangerous enemies, including bosses and even the last boss), have limited move sets that are very easy to deal with for experienced gamers. Factoring in how incredibly overpowered Dust Storm is, bosses are not much of a challenge. If you're keeping up on gear via crafting, you will also passively end up over-leveled. It is very easy to level up, and the bonuses provided from it are based on an steep curve, meaning that being even one or two levels over the area's average grants a massive advantage.

As for the positives, I already mentioned the positive aspects of the story and combat. I would also mention just how unique I thought the main characters' story really was, though. I have played a lot of games, watched a lot of movies/anime, and read a lot of books/manga, and the concept used at the core of the story is not one I have run into very often The story's original parts of the concept are most definitely unique. The greatest positives for me include the audio and visuals. The environments are drawn in a sort of hand-drawn or painted style that is really nice to look at (it's not Ori level, though). The music is a little bit hit and miss for me, but in general, the music is really nice and echoes the environment/atmosphere that it is played in. I think the greatest part of the game is actually the voice-acting. Kudos to the voice actors for doing a phenomenal job. Unfortunately, the dialogue wasn't the greatest at times, and the aforementioned background plot holes blunted the dialogue's impact, but even so the voice actors made the characters feel real and believable. It's remarkable how much of a difference good voice acting can make. Every character is voiced, and even the side quest characters speak with a realistic, believable character of voice that actually manages to draw your interest to random tasks, such as finding some lunatic's enigmatic lost box (which then has some interesting results which I will not utter here).

Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a game I can recommend. It has some issues, but despite them, it's well worth playing for people who appreciate games that have soul. I guarantee you'll have a blast with the combat system, even if the more experienced among you don't feel challenged by it. And as a final note, you'll probably enjoy the little easter eggs too. I know I did.

Halfway through I decided to find some reviews from the time, and PC Gamer had a great line about fidget, the sidekick: namely, that she was "alarmingly curvaceous".

That does transition this review into addressing the elephant in the fursuit-er, room. Is this a "furry" game? Well, no more than a series like "Redwall" is a furry book series. There are some games available on steam that just SHOVE furry in your face, and I'm not too interested in those, but this is not one of them.

54011970.review:
[quote]This review is a part of the Completionist's Point of View curator (the link will be added once the curator is up)[/quote] 

When I first saw this game on the Steam store, I was hesitant. The reviews were great, the combat looked slick and it's a metroidvania - a genre I really love! But the art style... didn't instantly click with me, because of some furry vibes I got from it. I started looking through reviews and opinions on the game, and I've stumbled upon one which said something along the lines: "If the art style is the only reservation you have about the game, just give it a chance". I decided to follow this advice and today I'm extremely happy that I did. While it's true that all of the game's characters are anthropomorphic animals, I'd say that its esthetics are a rather unique blend of "slightly anime" and old cartoons from the 80s and 90s. Even the game's subtitle (An Elysian Tail) refers to such cartoon ("An American Tail" from 1986). So, what I want to say by all of this is - even if you're not particularly fond of the game's art style, you should absolutely still give it a go. At some point in the game, you might even find yourself surprised that you ended up really liking this aspect of it, just like me.

With that out of the way, I need to say that the fact that this game was pretty much a one-man project is absolutely mind-blowing to me. I could accept that "Braid" or "Papers, Please" were done mostly by a single person. But when I heard that one guy (by the name of Dean Dodrill) made this awesome game with around 20 hours of content and only got help on the soundtrack, the voice-acting and half of the script, it wasn't something I could easily believe. When he started thinking about making this game, he was merely an illustrator and animator whose only contact with game development was some animation contributions for Jazz Jackrabbit 2. He only started learning programming and making his first simple micro-games about 4 years prior to Dust's actual release... What an absolute madman.

Let's talk a bit more about the game's design - shall we?

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a metroidvania with light RPG elements, slasher-like combat and rather simple, but humorous, charming and touching story. The game is divided into a prologue and 5 separate chapters. Each of the chapters introduces a new main location. Aside from that, there are also a few mini-locations you can visit as a part of some of the game's sidequests. In total, there are 12 unlockable locations you can choose on the world map upon exiting each of them. The metroidvania nature of the game obviously means that you'll need to revisit each of them if you want to unravel all of their secrets, but I didn't really feel an urge to do that before nearing the end of the game when I acquired the last of the character abilities, which would allow me to make the second run through the game, this time without skipping anything. This meant that a lot of the chests I now could reach were accessible to me sooner than at the end of the game, and they contained wearable items that were already far worse than my endgame stuff. I could still sell them and buy something more useful for me, but it's definitely an area of the game that could use some more balancing.

The combat is a thing you'll spend at least half of your playtime on. Thankfully, this is also one the game's biggest merits. It consists of several types of attacks you can easily chain into simple but striking combos. Once you get used to it, it becomes more of a dance than a fight - you fly all over the screen, cast really flashy spells and obliterate troops of creatures stubbornly trying to block your way. Even though I really enjoy the mesmerizing nature of the combat, it's also tied closely to my biggest issue with the game - the difficulty. There are 4 difficulty settings you can choose from (and apparently change in the middle of the game, but I only found out about that after finishing it...): Easy, Normal, Tough and Hardcore. But the thing is... according to both my own taste and many other opinions I've read, these are actually easier than their names suggest. I think they should be called (respectively): Beginner, Easy, Normal and Hard. I've played through the whole thing on what the game calls "Tough". I died a few times in Chapter 1, but once I got past the beginning and leveled up a bit, the difficulty curve dropped. The second half of the game was a breeze for me, including the final boss whom I defeated on my first try, despite dying a couple of times on the first boss. It's definitely not how it should be, but it's also nothing game-breaking (at least for me). I'd just recommend you to use my renamed difficulty levels to pick one for yourself and remember that you can always tinker with this setting in the options menu.

Another part of the game which really deserves some praise is the soundtrack. It's mostly composed by HyperDuck SoundWorks, who are not really well known besides their work on Dust and Kingdom Rush Frontiers. It's so surprisingly good that it instantly joined my collection of favorite game OSTs, and I still listen to it quite regularly, even though I finished the game over 4 years ago.

Overall, despite some small issues, I consider this game to be a must-play.

Oh and by the way, if you decide to give this game a go and you happen to be a person who likes reading about game development, there are a bunch of very nice articles talking about the hardships of Dust's development processes. I really recommend checking them out, once you finish your playthrough ;)

[h1]Achievement review[/h1]
My time to 100%: 23h
Estimated time to 100%: 10-30h (depends on your playstyle, skipping the dialogue or not and whether you'll keep playing after getting all of the achievements to do everything else there is to do in-game)

[b]Warning:[/b] there's 1 missable achievement (play on Tough or Hardcore difficulty) and a pair of limited ones (you need to save before choosing between 2 dialogue options to be able to choose them both in one playthrough).

In my opinion, the achievement design of this game is close to perfection. The achievements encourage you to explore all of the things the game has to offer and to try out some of the extra challenges. The ones that are missable or limited make sense to be there and avoiding skipping them is not a hassle. Once you finish the game, you can still load up the last save and continue on with the rest of the missing sidequests and collectibles. There are some tiny things I'd possibly change in some of them, but honestly, the developer did an absolutely amazing job with this aspect of the game.

[h1]Suggested completion roadmap[/h1]
[olist]
[*]Start the game on either Tough or Hardcore difficulty.
[*]Play through the whole game working on the achievements whenever you feel you have a good opportunity to do them. The only thing you really need to keep your eye on is the fact that to collect both of the limited achievements in one playthrough you need to save in a separate slot once you receive "a laundry sidequest". During this sidequest, you'll need to make a certain choice. Once you get the first out of the two achievements, reload your save and pick a different choice to earn the second one of them.
[*]Once you reach the last location in the game (Everdawn Basin aka "the volcano location") and acquire the last skill (Boost Jump which allows you to do very high jumps above air currents), you can go back to all of the previous locations and clear them out. Depending on your playstyle, you can either just get all of the missing achievements OR collect absolutely everything there is to collect to achieve the maximum 117% of total completion.
[/olist]
